name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate with the Prime Minister of the Republic of Greece, Alexis Tsipras, on the future of Europe (2018/2730(RSP)). I thank the Prime Minister for accepting Parliament's invitation to take part in this debate on the future of Europe. As you know, Parliament wants to be at the centre of the debate on how to build the Europe of the future. Many things are wrong, of course Europe must be changed, but it must not be destroyed. Parliament wants to be a protagonist, we want more power for the European Parliament. Progress has been made with the Treaty of Lisbon, but we want parliament's power of initiative and we want to have discussions with the Member States not only in the Council. I have insisted to Prime Minister Tsipras on the importance to us of the Dublin reform, which is a key point supported by the European Parliament. We will all have the opportunity today to discuss, after listening to him, Alexis Tsipras, whom I thank once again for accepting our invitation, and I invite him to take the floor from the podium.

name: Αλέξης Τσίπρας
text: Prime Minister of Greece. Mr President of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for the honour of inviting me to set out to the European Parliament my thoughts and concerns about the future of Europe and to discuss with you.  It is important but also symbolic that this opportunity is given to me only a few days after the end of a great adventure, after the end of the memorandums and the net exit of Greece from the support programmes, after eight whole years. Last time I had the honour of addressing you, Greece was in a great vortex. The politics of deficits, the breakdown of public money and the widespread corruption of previous governments had thrown my country on the brink of bankruptcy. But, at the same time, the inability of the institutions to prioritise the necessary structural reforms in the first two programmes, combined with the persistence of some of them in a recipe for extreme fiscal adjustment, had driven the country to the limits of social suffocation, economic suffocation and social explosion. From 2010 to 2014, Greece lost a quarter of its national wealth. Unemployment, poverty, social exclusion have soared, public debt too. Foreign investment has evaporated, young scientists have left the country by the thousands. Greece's economic crisis and the failure to manage it had also turned into a political crisis in Europe. And when I spoke before you, you will remember that half of you cheered me on, the other half disapproved of me, but few, very few, were among you who thought I would have hoped to make it.  And yet Greece did it! Three years later, it's a different country. Part of the problem, from a source of the crisis, became part of the solution for Europe. The clean exit from the last three-year programme is a success, above all, of the Greek people, who shook their teeth and fought the battle, which made great sacrifices to keep the country in the heart of Europe. But it is also a success for Europe as a whole, which has shown that in a spirit of solidarity and cooperation it can overcome crises. Through this adventure we come out stronger. Today we stand on our own two feet and look to the future with optimism because, for the first time since the outbreak of the crisis, the sacrifices of the Greek people have taken place. We've cleansed up the public finances. We have made deep cuts and reforms that should have been made decades ago. We escaped the spiral of recession and put the economy back on a growth trajectory. We have moved forward with projects and investments that make Greece a commercial, transit and energy hub in the wider region, but, at the same time, we have proved that there is a way out of the crisis without breaking up the social fabric. We supported the weakest. We've stopped the humanitarian crisis. We gave access to the health system to millions of uninsured people. But, at the same time, we also achieved primary surpluses, which, three years ago, no one could believe, because we control uncontrolled tax evasion, we stopped the waste and the party of corruption in public health and public procurement, because we have made key reforms, such as the consolidation of insurance funds and the rationalisation of the insurance system. And today, not only have we come out of the memoranda, but with the sustainable regulation of public debt, we are regaining our economic sovereignty and regaining the place we deserve in European life.  Last year Greece returned to growth with forecasts for this year approaching growth of close to 2.5%. Over the last three years we have proved to be champions in the absorption of European development resources. While also in 2017, we were the second country to absorb funds from the Juncker plan, while foreign investment reached 3.6 billion euros, which is the highest return of the last decade. In three years, we have reduced unemployment by more than 7%. We have created more than three hundred thousand new jobs. We supported public hospitals. We are implementing an integrated public primary care system, while drastically reducing organic gaps in schools and increasing spending on scientific research to 1% of GDP. At the same time we are fighting to turn the "brain drain" into a "brain gain" by incentivising youth entrepreneurship. We have also implemented the social solidarity income, the Greek version of the lower guaranteed income, from which more than 650 000 citizens currently benefit. We are thus reducing the rates of poverty and social exclusion by creating a web of social policies that protect the most vulnerable.  At the same time, however, and against the current of the time, Greece is one of the few countries that have extended the individual rights and freedoms of its citizens in Europe. For the first time, we are providing citizenship to second generation immigrants born and raised in Greece. We have enshrined the legal recognition of gender identity, as well as the cohabitation pact and child support for gay couples. We have abolished the mandatory application of Sharia law for the Muslim minority, and, at last, after years, we are also completing the construction of a mosque in Athens. Moreover, in a Europe where racism and xenophobia are reaping, Greece has done its best to manage the huge refugee flows in terms of humanism and the protection of international law. At a time when other countries were unilaterally breaking European decisions and raising fences, economically battered Greece resisted the sirens of hatred. Local communities have given lessons in humanity and civil society has been effectively mobilised in cooperation with the State, the European Union and international organisations. Today, the Asylum Service, which did not even exist five years ago, manages the largest number of applicants in Europe in relation to the population. At the same time, Greece, with its important geopolitical position, makes a decisive contribution to peace and stability in a more widely destabilised region.  Despite all the problems of instability and nationalist flare-up in Turkey, we have kept open channels of communication, preserving peace in the Aegean, promoting cooperative solutions to the refugee crisis, starting talks on a just and sustainable solution to the Cyprus problem. Together with Cyprus, we are the only European pillar of stability in the destabilised eastern Mediterranean region. We are expanding multilateral cooperation with Egypt, Israel, Palestine, Jordan and, at the same time, deepening Balkan cooperation and co-development, thus unlocking the European perspective of the Balkan states, with the crowning of our efforts the historic agreement of the Prespas with our northern neighbour and the ongoing dialogue with Albania. After twenty-six years of disastrous domination of nationalism, we managed with the Prime Minister of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Zoran Zaev, to turn the page and reach a mutually acceptable agreement without the imposition and use of power, but on the basis of diplomacy and dialogue. An agreement that can be a model for dispute resolution in our region.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out this: Greece's exit from the last fiscal adjustment programme does not mean that the country is returning to its past. On the contrary, we are determined not to repeat the mistakes and behaviours that led to the crisis. The end of the memorandums is not a return to the past, but a historical intersection with the past. It is a new beginning that strengthens stability and security. He's healing wounds. It gradually corrects injustices and open up new development prospects for our people and our country.  In the coming period, I would like to assure you that we will continue the reform effort, with an emphasis on further streamlining the functioning of the state, modernising public administration, combating bureaucracy, deepening democratic sections through the forthcoming constitutional review. But we will also continue on the path of budgetary balance, while at the same time prioritising fair growth and the protection of work.  Greece and the Greeks have demonstrated in recent years how deeply committed they are to the idea of European unification, enduring and insisting on the European course of the country, even when Europe itself, or even its dominant expression, has often hurt and underestimated the Greek people. So let us try, from this eight-year Greek crisis that we are leaving behind, to draw our own conclusions and, above all, to draw conclusions about which Europe we want and how to shield it against possible new crises in the future. The stakes for Europe today are, I would say, existential in nature. The management to date of the economic and refugee crisis and the security crisis has highlighted huge deficits and contradictions and tends to turn all these crises into a structural crisis of the European project. From this step I would like to warn that the failure of the European Union to provide democratic and functional answers to modern challenges will inevitably result in the triumph of chauvinism and the resurgence of nationalist rivalries. It will make it a fragmented continent without unity, without cohesion, without an international role and perspective. During the economic crisis, the European Union, instead of becoming more democratic, taking advantage of whatever institutional political tools the Treaty of Lisbon has attributed, has become more technocratic and ethnocentric, with critical decisions unfortunately taken behind closed doors by informal bodies that do not answer to European citizens and keep citizens away from the Union and in the form of technocrats, such as the troika, holding the keys to economic sovereignty and not being held to account anywhere. The European Commission, the European Parliament and even the European Council have been second behind the institutionally unregistered Eurogroup and the technical ranks of the technocrats of the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Fiscal fetishism in the management of the economic crisis has further exacerbated socio-economic disparities both between and within the Member States. It has exhausted large sections of society and caused even greater economic insecurity and fear among our citizens. It is this failure of neoliberal crisis management that ultimately fuels the monster of chauvinism and far-right populism. He moved the far right from the stand of the accused of history and from isolation to the political scene.  The refugee crisis that followed simply confirmed Europe's inability to move forward, when a large part of its members did not embrace its founding values, when the logic of isolationism over cooperation prevailed, the logic of 'everyone alone' in the face of burden-sharing, the logic of national folding over European solidarity, when the poison of hatred and xenophobia , unfortunately, it springs back to the heart of Europe more than seventy years after the all-human tragedy of fascism. Because today we are not only faced with the electoral rise of some extreme forces of the nationalist and populist far right, but we are faced with the infiltration of its xenophobic and chauvinistic agenda within the democratic political spectrum, where racism and xenophobia become a hegemonic political discourse in traditional conservative forces and beyond, shaping the correlations in countries critical to Europe. It is this development, if not interrupted, that threatens Europe with decay.  Some of you in 2015 were afraid of SYRIZA and the left that was claiming and claiming a better Europe. You believed that anyone who questions today's Europe of neoliberal hegemony and social inequalities is a danger to our common edifice. Today, those of you who believed that, you have to admit that you fell out. If anyone really threatens Europe, it is not those who are fighting to change it, but those who are fighting to abolish it. Those who are on the opposite side of the umanist ideas of solidarity and cooperation of the peoples. All those who believe, friends and friends, ladies and gentlemen, in this European vision, must put aside our existing and great differences in the face of great danger. We must not let the European idea be crushed between destructive neoliberalism and the nightmarish far right. We must resolutely reply that the only way to save European unification is to revive it with bold reforms of democracy, transparency and justice. In other words, to support the prospect of a better Europe with European solutions to European challenges, to refugees and migration, to climate change, to security, to democratic reform of the euro area, so that hope can overcome far-right fear.  What we need today in Europe is not less solidarity and more borders but a new social contract for the social cohesion and prosperity of our peoples, deepening political integration, a stronger Parliament and stronger European institutions with democratic and social control. What we need is not a new priesthood of austerity and discipline but a growth-oriented eurozone with mechanisms for balancing inequalities; a multiannual financial framework that supports social cohesion and convergence; a legally binding European pillar of social rights; the revision of the common European asylum system with a fair distribution of burdens; a common European civil protection mechanism to deal with natural disasters; the promotion of Turkey's dialogue and accession path in order to respects international law and brings this great country back to democratic reforms;  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by saying that Greece has managed to become part of the solution to the problem for the last three years. Europe. It has overcome the economic crisis, put this great refugee crisis on its back with dignity on behalf of the whole of Europe. It paved the way for peoples' friendship with a consistently peaceful foreign policy that transforms it into a factor of cooperation and stability in a more broadly unstable region in the South-Eastern Mediterranean and the Balkans. All these examples of writing over the last three years are, I would say, a positive sign in the cloudy sky of the European Union. We've shown there's a way, if you believe it and if you fight it hard. I believe that this is also the way to Europe's future.  We have tough battles ahead of us. Next May's European elections will be more than just another election. It will be a political battle of principles and values to defeat the extreme neoliberalism and far-right populism that threaten Europe. To upgrade the European idea, to strengthen the unity and solidarity of the European peoples. In this battle, all progressive, democratic and pro-European forces have a duty to find themselves on the same side of history and not to let Europe turn back.

name: Presidente. –
text: Are there any Members who have an interest in intervening in catch the eye? Well, then we can proceed to the closure of the system for electronic recording of catch-the-eye requests. I now give the floor to The Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Dombrovskis.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of President Juncker, who is preparing the State of the Union address that he will deliver tomorrow to this House, I am delighted to take part in this debate on the future of Europe, in the presence of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. I have had the opportunity to work closely with Prime Minister Tsipras over the past few years. Most recently, we had a very good exchange on Greece and the future of Europe when I visited Athens in June. Before I turn to our debate, let me first express our deep sympathy and solidarity to those affected by the terrible forest fires. The Commission stands by your side, Prime Minister, and we must make sure that such tragedies are never repeated. Greece, its people and Greek civilisation have shaped Europe and its underlying values. One can safely say that the Greeks invented democracy and, above all, they knew how to defend it when it was under threat. This allowed their country to join the European Union after enduring a terrible dictatorship, thus proving that the future belongs to those who have the courage not to succumb to resignation, and the determination to face up to difficulties and take their fate into their own hands. Yes, the future belongs to those who choose to be architects of history. Greece is not only of historic importance to Europe, but it is also important to the future of Europe. It is impossible to imagine the future of Europe without Greece’s contribution. I am thinking in particular of its vital role in the stability of the Western Balkans, a region with a turbulent history, which needs firm reassurance about the prospect of EU membership in order to avoid a repetition of the tragedies we witnessed in the 1990s. And I would like once again to pay tribute to the courage and leadership of Prime Ministers Tsipras and Zaev, who have acted in a spirit of openness and compromise in order to break a long-standing deadlock that served the interests of neither country. (Applause) They have set an example for the whole region and the wider world. I am also thinking of the future of our Economic and Monetary Union and the harsh lessons which, together, we had to learn from the crisis of the last ten years that hit Greece so hard. Although others took a different view, the Commission has always believed that Greece has its rightful place in the euro area. I would like to pay tribute to the unprecedented efforts that have been made by the Greek people to maintain Greece’s rightful place at the heart of the European Union. This summer Greece has turned a new page. It has brought the stability programme to a successful close: it has put its public finances in order and even exceeded its budgetary targets. Its economy is on the rise: this year and next it is set to grow by 2%. Unemployment has already fallen sharply, although it remains unacceptably high. Over 100 000 new jobs have been created since the stability programme began. The credit for this achievement is shared between the Greeks and their European partners. It is a product of Europe’s recipe for success, which combines solidarity with responsibility. The solidarity shown by the European partners has been unprecedented – both in terms of financial assistance and in terms of support for reforms. The people of Greece have been strong in assuming their responsibility. Their efforts and sacrifices have laid the basis for this sustainable upturn. These are solid foundations on which Greece can now build. Yet, there are still economic challenges to overcome. The best investment that Greece can now make is to build confidence in its economy. That requires staying the course of responsible fiscal policies and reforms. This is the way to ensure long-lasting economic growth and a constant improvement of living conditions for the Greek people. In such a case, I do not exclude the possibility of the Greek economy surprising us on the upside. When I see the courage and determination which the Greek people have already shown, I am confident that they will succeed. And Greece can continue to rely on the solidarity of its European partners. In our Union, responsibility and solidarity go hand in hand. We proved as much when we drew lessons from the crisis and made our common currency more crisis-resistant. In order to arm ourselves better to face future challenges, we must take the necessary steps to complete our Economic and Monetary Union. The Commission’s roadmap is clear, its agenda is well-known – and this is an urgent priority for the autumn. We are finally making progress to complete our Banking Union and I trust we can move swiftly towards a real Capital Markets Union. The example of Greece shows that we can overcome problems when we join forces. The euro area has emerged from the crisis united and stronger because we chose common European solutions. As we look to the future of Europe, we must apply this spirit of finding common solutions to common challenges right across the board. This is what being part of the Union means: working together to address the issues affecting us all. Managing migration is one such common European challenge – it is not the responsibility of only one Member State or another. That is why we stood side-by-side with Greece when it mattered most. Thanks to the EU-Turkey Statement, arrivals are now down by 97% in the Eastern Mediterranean. We backed up our action with the financial resources to match, with Greece receiving a total of EUR 1.6 billion of EU funds to address migration challenges. And we set up a European Border and Coast Guard to make our borders more secure. We now have more than 1 600 officers across Europe, including 662 officers in Greece, at the borders with Turkey, Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The decisive action taken by the European Union has worked. But we can and must do more. Together, it is time that Member States agreed on a long-term solution covering all elements of migration, to help us balance solidarity and responsibility. There would be no stronger or more tangible proof to Europeans that the Union will deliver on its promises and stay united on the things that matter the most. I believe that to achieve this we should look to the teachings of one of Europe’s, and Greece’s, greatest minds, namely Aristotle. He taught that virtue is the middle between extremes; that understanding and compassion are central to the way a society works; and that we are all, above all else, social beings. In our long and often tragic history, we can see the damage wrought when we lose sight of this humanism. So the lesson for our future is simple. We must never lose sight of what binds us together: the values that we share; the living together in a society that we hold dear; and the compassion and solidarity that we show each other. That is what our Union is built on, and that is what our future must be built on. (Applause)

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, I also speak a southern language, with a southern accent and southern pain. The last time we were lucky enough to hear from you was in July 2015. I'm very changed. You came in and left this House with the applause of the populists and the Europhobes. You'll remember it perfectly, and so will we. Today, as we entered, we all applauded him. Greece was then immersed in an unprecedented economic and social crisis. It was a country on the brink of eviction. You remember it perfectly, and so do we. We Europeans were by their side, we were at the side of the Greeks when they needed us, we were at the side of the Greeks when financial markets shut down their government's money tap. When the rest of the world turned its back on the Greek people, his European family reached out to him. And together we managed to get ahead. Together we have. It wasn't easy, but we did it together. You'll remember it perfectly, and so will we. I will not be the one who detract from your government's merits, Mr Tsipras. His government has been an essential and necessary actor, as was That of President Samaras. But your intervention today—let me tell you—has sinned of triumphalism and personalism. And he has omitted, I do not know if coincidentally or intentionally, some clearings that still weigh on his management. Greece's departure from the rescue programme is a success that we all applaud, but if anyone deserves to be applauded, it's not their government, it's the Greek citizens, because they have suffered and fought more than anyone else to get their country ahead. The Greeks are admirable, and their pain has been admirable. I have heard you speak of the merits of your Government, but I have not heard you speak of the merits of your people, I have not heard you speak of the merits of the Greek citizens. Greek citizens voted to continue in Europe and the euro, as some of their ministers fought windmills. I'm sure you still remember, and so do we. This success story you have told us today about Greece is incomplete if we omit the European contribution, but not that of governments and institutions, but that of European citizens. Today you have played to confuse the European Union with neoliberalism, with troika, with speculators, with money merchants. And yet that European Union, which you believe has become more technocratic and more nationalistic, has been the salvation of your government and the salvation of your country. Both have criticized stability policies from their party, which you should recognise that, thanks to stability policies, countries such as Greece, Portugal, Spain or Ireland are now emerging from the crisis. They're no worse, they're better off that they were economically and socially. You know that it was not the Europe of banks and corporations that lifted Greece out of the abyss, Mr Tsipras, but the Europe of taxpayers, who every morning get up to work. It has been savings from retirees, wage earners and small entrepreneurs across Europe that have made greece's bailout possible. I'm sure you remember it perfectly, and so do we. Europe is not just a market. Europe are values and principles, it is attachment to democracy, justice and the rule of law. Europe is solidarity, it is understanding, it is support, it is to help each other when we need it and not to throw stones at the glass ceiling, as should be the case with the migrant crisis, not only in Greece, but in all the southern states, just as happened this summer when the fires swept through Greece, and the Greek people had all our solidarity. Europe, Mr Tsipras, is to live up to the word given, is to sit at the same table, to see ourselves as allies and as friends, never as enemies. Just the opposite of what your Government did at the beginning of your term of office, when you were here precisely - you will remember and we remember too – when precious time was wasted criticizing the European family and handing over to the worst economic populism. Surely you will remember that EUR 100 billion has been lost because of the irresponsibility of your minister, Mr Varoufakis, your famous star minister. You remember him for sure, and so do we. Fortunately, that's the past. I see you changed, Mr. Tsipras, very changed, and I'm glad. Positive steps have been taken, but there is a long way to go and some doubts to be cleared. We are concerned that, nearly a month after leaving the bailout program, markets will continue to be suspicious of their economic policies. Understand that we're worried. We are concerned that growth will continue to stagnant and that the forecasts are not very optimistic, and understand that we are concerned. We are concerned that there will continue to be shadows of clientelism in Greek government procurement, and understand that we are concerned. We're worried that almost 500,000 young Greeks have had to leave Greece, and understand that we are concerned. We are concerned that a forthcoming election will change its political style and a return to opposition means a return to populism for your party. And understand that we care, because we, as we have already shown you, are your family. There are many lessons to learn from the crisis, Mr. Tsipras. We know that there are things that could have been done better and others that perhaps it would be appropriate not to have done. Now you have two options: continue on the path of reforms you have just undertaken or return to populism and radicalism. In your hand is, and we expect the best of you and your government. He was wrong in 2015 when he was here, as time and facts have shown. I trust you know how to choose the right choice this time. Because populism is neither right nor left, it is populism and always will be. Remember one thing: the far right is as dangerous as the far left, at least for democrats. I hope you remember, because we're not going to forget.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me start by saying to the Prime Minister that we are very sad about how many lives were lost this summer in the forest fires in Greece – in other places in Europe as well, but especially in Greece – and let me add that we are very sad, seeing him here today, reminding us of the hardship the Greek people have had to go through, especially over the last eight years.  Prime Minister, you did not mention this today, but you could have mentioned it. How many children were put into poverty during the last eight years in Greece? How many families lost their homes? Here my dear friends from the PPE will disagree, but it is your austerity that caused this, it is not our austerity and it was the representatives of your family in Athens offering the Greek people to leave the Eurozone with an unforeseeable impact on the Eurozone, with an unforeseeable impact on the Greek nation and all over Europe. Don’t mix things up. You can be sure we will come back to that.  But we know exactly, Prime Minister, and you rightly did this in your great speech, to outline that Europe has to start on new endeavours and that we have to be bold and that we have not only to talk about the past but also about the future and that we have to shape the future, the European future. If you would like to do that, we need a new vision, a new objective, a new dream, a new policy and also our institutions have to be prepared for that.  This is the topic of today. But let me also be clear that if we would like to have this new vision in Europe, all revolutions start at home and each and every country has to contribute to this new endeavour. That also goes for Greece. You found a lot of problems in front of you when you took over in government and we have to be blunt on that. Our societies cannot be misled by greedy elites. Our societies cannot be fooled by those rich people who do not like to pay taxes and our societies cannot be irritated by public administrations working according to nepotistic politics and not according to the rule of law. Here everybody has to do his and her homework, but especially also Greece. You know that, Prime Minister, and you have reacted to that domestically. You have reacted to the situation in foreign relations; I can only praise what you did with Prime Minister Zaev. You are solving problems in the Balkans for the future of Europe, for peace in the Balkans. My Group is going to full—heartedly support you on that because this is a good step forward, a cornerstone for the new Europe.  I can only encourage you not to stop domestic reforms but rather to continue with the domestic reforms which are necessary, on the public administration, on the functioning of the rule of law, on striving towards a more fair and equal society.  Let me tell you the following: my Group started two years ago to renew our own programme. We decided that we cannot talk anymore about the economy without talking about the environment. We cannot talk anymore about the environment without talking about the social dimension. We are suggesting for the new programme for this European Union to strive towards the United Nations sustainable development goals, because we think this is the correct compass for the future. I do not have to give advice to you, Prime Minister, but only one idea. What if you go to Portugal? The newly—reshaped society of Greece goes to Portugal, talks to António Costa. You go to Spain, and talk to Pedro Sánchez. You could say, look, I have an idea. You could also go to Italy. Salvini will perhaps not listen to you – but Italian society I am pretty sure would listen to you – and you could say, look, this Mediterranean area has a great heritage, but it could also have a great future. What about developing a master plan for safe and sustainable energy? A master plan for better logistics, on land as well as on the sea, for fair and smart mobility. A master plan for high quality services, in tourism as well as in agriculture, for better products for a better future of the European Union, for a better world. You can say this master plan will be put up together, as the region, as the societies, as the countries of the south. Once we have this master plan for the Mediterranean we say, look, European Commission, we need your support, and you could support us on that because this is the future of our region, this is the future of the European Union and this is the future of the Mediterranean. Then you could say, look, political parties, if you come up with the lead candidates, if you would like to form the new mandate, the new governance, we will only vote for somebody who is full—heartedly supporting us on this master plan because the whole European Union needs a master plan like this for the sake of the next generation. If you go that path, we will be with you, we will support you, and that would be the best for our children and grandchildren. I wish you luck.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Prime Minister, Mr Tsipras, since I am the first of the Greek MEPs to speak, I would like to welcome you here to our European Parliament. Listening to you, you reminded me of Mr. Samaras who four years ago sat where you sit and told us about the success story of his second memorandum. Today you told us about the success story of your third memorandum and when, when you leave burnt earth, and I do not mean the Eye, when you have turned Greece into a vast social cemetery, when we have thousands of unemployed, when we have millions of poor, when our youth leaves the country, when there is a pension cut, when we have hunger wages, when there is looting of public property , with the Occupying Fund that will operate for 99 years, when we have a tax resalto in the pockets of the Greeks, the tax ENFIA, the increase of VAT on the Aegean islands, which cannot stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. You left unanswered unrelenting questions, Mr Tsipras, that is why Mr González Sons and the European People's Party are shaking your hand, you did not tell us where the EUR 288 billion that Greece took as loans went because, if you gave us an answer, you would say what Mr Dijsselbloem still said, that these funds went to save the lenders. , to save foreign banks, to really save the euro itself and not Greek citizens. Because that's the reality. You must tell us, Mr. Tsipras, why you are applying the memorandum measures at 100%, but you have taken only 70% of the loan capital of the third memorandum and returned EUR 24 billion, as a tip, back to the lenders, when you could use this money to create a Borrowers' Salvation Fund so that the Greeks would not lose their homes to the crows. , to recapitalise the insurance funds so as not to reduce pensions, to create 300 000 new jobs in order to have growth. And you're implementing the lenders' austerity budget. I ask you, Mr. Tsipras: will you implement what you said in 2014? Will you enter the German allowances in the state budget? Will you order the implementation of the Distomos decision on German reparations? Once you have implemented the enhanced supervision that you have accepted and Regulation 472, apply at least one point of this regulation, which allows you to audit the debt. That is the reality, but there is another way, Mr. Tsipras.  There is another way to go. You told us about the despicable agreement of the Prespas that really makes Mr Zaev a free dude, who will come here on Thursday and pretend to be Macedonian, talk about so-called Macedonian ethnicity, talk about so-called Macedonian language, talk about so-called Macedonian citizenship and not About North Macedonians. We therefore believe in a special relationship between Greece within the European Union and within the euro area, a special relationship with regulations in important sectors of the Greek economy that will breathe new life into Greece, in order to have a strong Greece within the Europe of nations and homelands, within Europe that respects national identity, respects national traditions, protects the Greek family , it will protect the European family and solve the demographic, not through mass migration, but with the support of the European family itself. These are our positions, Mr. Tsipras. We remain unrepentantly anti-monumental and we fight to throw the troika out of Greece and take back our country.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, to Prime Minister Tsipras, I should say ‘Welcome back to the European Parliament’. You know, four years ago, Prime Minister, you were a little afraid, I thought, to come here to this plenary, but today, unlike four years ago, you are not here to talk about the Greek crisis: you have rather more solid ground under your feet, if I may put it like that. You want to talk, and you have talked, among other things, about our common future, the future of the European Union. Nevertheless, let me say something first on the Greek crisis. I think that, whatever our opinion about what happened in recent years, we can all say it is good news that Greece no longer depends on European aid. But, I have to tell you, I’m not as enthusiastic as the German Minister of Finance, Mr Scholz, who said the three Greek rescue packages were a sign of solidarity. If this whole exercise was a sign of solidarity, then, as far as I am concerned, he can keep it. I am more of the opinion of Mr Dijsselbloem who said, a few weeks ago in his assessment of the Greek crisis, that both sides were to blame: Greece, on the one hand, for not reforming deeply enough or fast enough and, on the other hand, Europe for focusing only on pure accountancy and austerity instead of asking for reform from day one. What didn’t happen were deep reforms in the Greek economy and in Greek society, and that has been, and still is, my problem with what happened in Greece. So the key question now extends beyond this Greek crisis, Mr Tsipras: is Greece, and by extension the whole eurozone, ready for the next crisis? Because we know that the next crisis will come. We don’t know when. If we knew, we would be rich, of course, but it will come. The end of the economic cycle is there and the question is: are we ready for that? Well, my answer in this debate is ‘no’. Europe is not ready for the next crisis that may overcome us. Greece was, in fact, a small problem, let’s be honest. I call it a small problem and, from another perspective, Mr Tsipras, you naturally call it a very big problem, but let’s face the reality: the accumulated debt of three decades was EUR 300 billion. You know what that is: it is 2% of the yearly European wealth that we create, EUR 15 trillion a year. I was in China and in the Treasury in America, explaining the Greek crisis, and I have to tell you that when I tried to explain it, and I gave the figures, they said to me: ‘What is the problem?’ The problem is, naturally, that 20 years after the introduction of the euro and the single currency – and this, I hope, will be the conclusion of our debate with you – 20 years after the introduction of the euro, Mr Tsipras, we are still not capable of facing such problems as we have had with Greece and as could happen tomorrow with other countries in the European Union, because we do not have the right institutions. We do not have the right governance. We have, in fact, only the European Central Bank and Mr Draghi to steer the European Economic and Monetary Union. And you know, and I know and everybody in this House knows, that this is impossible. We need a fully fledged banking union, and, Mr Dombrovskis, although you say that we are making progress, we don’t have it today. We need a common eurozone budget, which we don’t have today. We need a safe euro asset, which could be a eurobond or something similar – although the Germans will call it differently – to compete with the other big currency, the dollar, and we don’t have that safe euro asset. And we also need a European Minister of Finance (instead of three commissioners responsible for the euro as today), and we don’t have it. And that is the problem. The conclusion is that if, tomorrow, something happens again in Greece, in Italy or in another Member State of the European Union, this monetary union will not be capable of addressing the reality, and the worst will happen again. You will remember, Mr Tsipras, that four years ago we had an energetic – some have even said a ‘ferocious’ – exchange of views in the House here. This time I will keep it moderate because I have to save my energy for Mr Orbán this afternoon, so please be aware of that, but you will certainly remember that I asked you a question at the end: how do you want to be remembered in history, as an electoral accident or as a revolutionary reformer? Well, you’re certainly not an electoral accident, that is clear because you are still here, but my answer today is that you didn’t become one or the other. My feeling and my assessment, in terms of the reality on the ground in Greece, is that – in spite of all the efforts that so many people, so many ordinary Greek citizens, have made – the old Greek system is largely still in place. I don’t see markets opening, I don’t see professions being deregulated, I don’t see a vibrant private financial sector active in the Greek economy. But the same is true not only for Greece: the old system of the eurozone is also still in place. The word ‘crisis’, as we know, comes from a classical Greek word meaning, in fact, a moment of truth, a moment of decision, a moment of choice. Well, I think that Greece, Italy and the whole eurozone will remain under threat if we do not make a choice in the coming months and years, at this moment of the end of the Greek crisis, to bring about the re-foundation of our Union and reform of the Monetary Union. If we were not to do so, it would be a scandal, a tragedy not only for Greece but for Europe. So, what I would say to you, Mr Tsipras, is that I liked the end of your story, when you made an appeal to all pro-Europeans to come together. I liked it. Why? Because you did not fall into the trap of the extremists on the right or on the left (because they exist on the left, too), of saying ‘no’ to Europe, making war against Europe and thinking that only national recipes can save us. I liked that, and it is good that you said what you did to the face of your own friends.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for joining this debate on the future of Europe. There is much to talk about on the future of Europe and much is at stake because the very existence of this amazing project, here on this continent, is being called into question. We need to find new strength for our European project and, actually, I think a look back will be helpful in looking forward. For me, one of the key things about the Greek crisis was that one of the fundamental promises of the European Union was thrown into doubt – the promise that the European Union would bring prosperity and well—being to its citizens. That promise was broken. All of a sudden, Europe was bringing poverty. We can argue that it’s all right because there was a reason why there was a crisis and it was not in Europe, and you can say it was obviously national finance ministers who were doing the main part of the job, so not really Brussels – that’s all true, but it doesn’t solve the problem that Europe was not able to find a common solution of solidity and solidarity.  Prosperity and well—being: that is one of the Union’s fundamental policy goals. That is why we do policies – to fight for our citizens to bring them a better life. So far, we have had a lot of nice promises, including here in the EU, about how nice it would be to have a social Europe and to have more social policies, but we don’t have them yet. One of the key lessons from Greece is that we need to finally create that social Europe, and that we get binding social targets, which are on the same level as the economic rules that we already have. We don’t need more empty declarations. We need access to proper housing and to medical care for all Europeans. We need an unemployment support scheme to protect citizens from economic crises and to allow Member States to cope with asymmetric shocks and to recover more quickly, and we need a framework directive on minimum income schemes so that we have a safety net everywhere, ensuring well—being in the European Union. More than anything else, we also need to address the big problem of youth unemployment, which is becoming even more than an economic problem because if you have a whole generation without a perspective, this is also a problem of democracy. I would agree that since 2008 we still haven’t come to terms with how to prevent any future financial crisis. We have Member States who are blocking the banking union parts, like the Deposit Guarantee Scheme, and any proposals for mechanisms to absorb asymmetric economic shocks have been spineless so far. Also, our economic policies are being held hostage by national politics and we are not getting where we need to be. Crises can happen at any moment and we need to be prepared and resilient. We should really abandon the dogma of fiscal consultation for its own sake and instead focus on sustainable investments that soften the effects of economic shocks and prevent their escalation and proliferation. We also need a support mechanism for Member States in economic hardship that fits with European principles and European rules. This is not only an act of solidarity – it is not just a nice handout; it is a very vital piece for the survival of our Union. To have a sustainable economy that provides good jobs, we also need to finally start the social ecological transformation of our economy. We have some good examples of that in Greece. Local initiatives, such as on the island of Tinos on recycling and the energy social enterprise in Karditsa, are very important trailblazers for the future economy. It’s very good to have local initiatives, but we also need to have a European plan for social-ecological transition. Already, more than one million jobs exist in the renewable sector, so leading the way as regards the climate will also pay off in terms of jobs. Joint European action is also needed with regard to refugee protection. Greece was the main point of arrival for Syrians, Iraqis and Afghanis fleeing from war and persecution. Later on it was Italy, at some point it was Spain and Malta. Who knows – maybe it is going to be Poland tomorrow. We don’t know, but we can no longer leave a single Member State, or even an island, alone to do the job that we have to do all together. The European Parliament has put forward a good proposal. I really hope, Prime Minister, that your colleagues in the Council will finally make a move on that. It was the fishermen from Lesbos, it was the grandmothers in Idomeni and it was the many helpers all over Greece who saved so many lives, but they also saved humanity itself and they saved the face of all of us in Europe. I wonder – what are we giving back in return? (Applause) Those courageous people who are saving lives should not be criminalised, as we are seeing in some Member States. Greece has been hit hard by climate change. Many of the previous speakers mentioned the forest fires, which were really, really severe. Of course, it was not just Greece; we even had forest fires up in Sweden. Europe needs to get its act together finally to combat climate change. This is really a vital question for our planet and our continent. Greece has much to offer in regard to a solution: it has plenty of sun and plenty of wind. Oil drilling, though, is a thing of the past. It poses serious risks to the environment and it harms the climate that we all depend on. I really hope that Greece will abandon all drilling plans and that it will be a frontrunner in renewables and lead the path as it can be. Islands like Tilos show the way and I really hope that there will be more examples like this. Lastly, Prime Minister, I really want to congratulate you on your truly historic achievement. You have found a solution to a conflict where all predecessors have failed. The agreement on North Macedonia is an example for Europe. It’s an example of how to solve conflicts peacefully – without violence, without a big struggle – and try live in harmony with your neighbours. That is really an example for Europe. Thank you for that. (Applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Yes, the third memorandum came to an end a few days ago. This is his great success, but – and here I expressly disagree with Mr Gonzalez Pons – it has not been an act of solidarity, but has been an enormous burden that has been placed on the people of Greece. And it cannot be seen as a prime example of how crises in the European Union will be dealt with in the future. That must be made clear. What has happened here has been a humanitarian disaster, and the institutions, and the right in particular, have helped to create it, because they felt that they had to put a left-wing government in check and say that alternatives must not be thought of in the first place. That was their approach! However, and we agree on this too, euphoria is not appropriate today. It really is not all over yet: the debt still exists. They have not disappeared with the end of the memoranda. The demand for the creation of budget surpluses remains. The country remains under some kind of control, and securing humanitarian supplies for refugees requires a great deal of commitment from the whole of the European Union. The conditions must now be created for Greece to really be able to act. What happened to the debt conference? Not just for Greece, but for all the other states that are also under a debt burden? It is quite clear that in a country like Italy, for example, you cannot act in the way that we did with Greece. We all know that we are facing an imminent financial crisis. Should the whole thing collapse like a house of cards again? We need sustainability, we need stability, we need more democracy, we must finally give the people of Greece, in other Member States, a sign of hope and common ground, of solidarity.  What is not possible, for example, and we must clarify this retrospectively for each other: it is not acceptable for a member of the European Union to be removed from European law, for the EU, including the Commission, to accept the violation of fundamental rights. The fact that we are no longer talking about the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Charter of Social Rights – none of this is possible! Here we expect a rethink! Only then can we also give the people of the European Union the signal of what it is all about to be in a common Union.  Moreover, who represents the future of the EU? For me, these were above all those people, those Greeks, who built social networks of solidarity with great courage and commitment, be it as neighbourhood aid, medical care, much more. You have sent the message that it is solidarity between peoples, solidarity also between the peoples of the European Union, that holds us together. There must also be a people's Europe and not simply to get the highest possible profits or repayments for the banks.  Greece, as Prime Minister Tsipras noted, has endured its modern odyssey and reached Ithaca. But this is only the first step. This is only the first step, this is a stopover. We must now fight together to secure the future of the EU together with Greece, together with the other threatened states. In this sense: for more solidarity, for cohesion, for social justice between The Member States, for the reduction of imbalances – this is the future of the European Union. And greece has taught us great lessons.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister Tsipras, I say this straight away: a tragic case such as that of your country, Greece, must not happen again in the future of the European Union. A case in which Europe has shown its most ruthless and evil face, with bureaucrats and professors intent on playing the greatest socio-economic experiment in history. A few months ago you celebrated the end of the austerity programme. But the results of the troika are clear to everyone: 95 % of the 216 billion disbursed up to 2016 did not benefit the citizens, but ended up in private banks, also their own. As with privatisations: much of the public assets – airports, railways, ports – have ended up in the hands of German and French companies. Always them. And I do not list the dramatic litany of GDP data: income, poverty, unemployment, pension cuts, homelessness, suicides, starving children. And to think that for professors such as Mario Monti, former Italian Prime Minister, proclaimed by the spread and not by the people, Greece was the most concrete manifestation of the great success of the euro. A few days ago, he also announced that he was considering a return to politics, because the citizens are asking him to do so. Perhaps the first unfortunate attempt to deal with popular consent was not enough for him. Prime Minister Tsipras, you have not lost to Europe, you have lost to your people. Initially, it is true, he tried to resist. Then, Europe asked, indeed ordered, and you executed. And luckily he had to build another Europe. The truth is that this Union is always the usual one: either Germany, and a few others like it, or it is not. The Mediterranean countries, those that were supposed to be close to you, turned their backs on you. Even the previous Italian government, in words, promised you help, but then he was the most convinced accomplice of the unholy austerity policies. This is what Matteo Renzi did with Greece, and you know it. That is what the governments of the so-called Socialists have done. Prime Minister Tsipras, you are not asking me, but I want to give you some advice: think about it, two, a hundred, a thousand times, before joining the European Group of Socialists in the next parliamentary term. Think about it before you ally with those who humiliated Your people. That is the problem: a Union in name and not in fact, a huge gap between North and South, a strong Union with the weak and weak with the strong. And the truth is that we Mediterranean countries do not want to continue to be the useful idiot of Europe. This issue must be put to the European tables immediately. The European Commission and Mr Juncker must approach it with the same exceptional footing and the incredible determination with which they resolve other priorities, such as daylight saving time. Europe has been cruel to the Greeks, it has made a historic political, economic, social and moral mistake. On behalf of this institution, which is the only one elected by the citizens, I would like to apologise to the Greek people, and for the sake and future of Europe all this must never happen again with any other European people. Never again!

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I welcome Mr Tsipras to this Parliament and I tell him, the future of Europe is getting brighter every day. But that is not because of all these ‘hallelujah’ stories about a Greece that it is going so well. Mr Tsipras has achieved a lot, but is it over now? No. Still, the future of Europe is brighter every day, and that is because of the strong ties that are being built between Italy and the Visegrad countries, which show a victory of rationality over the destructive forces of socialism, liberalism or whatever they want to call themselves. These are countries with bright politicians that truly represent the people’s fight against the destructive policies of the EU: they fight mass migration; they fight a killing policy of austerity and they fight growing terrorism. And, therefore, I welcome Mr Tsipras, who was the hope of the Greek people. And I also understand from his words here that he has been forced by the Troika to bend to their financial demands, and now he is speaking their language. It has whipped and tortured the people of Greece into unemployment, into poverty and social disruption. Not least because of mass migration. And everybody knows it was not about the adjustment of the Greek economy: it is about saving German and French international banks. And that more or less succeeded. But is the ordeal over for Greece? No, it is not. I think that Greece will be enslaved by this financial burden for years to come. Perhaps for eternity. So I hope that the next elections in Greece will see a change, the true change that was promised by Mr Tsipras. and perhaps since he has been let a little more off the hook he can also adjust his government policies into ones that really and truly listen to the needs of the Greek people who are suffering. they are suffering because of the euro, they are suffering because of an EU project that was not prepared to step in for Greece and to protect the democratic rights of the Greek people.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, the so-called new era announced by Mr Tsipras is the maintenance of the 700 memorandum laws, a commitment which he has also given here, is the supervision of the European Union, the bloody over-excesses of decades, is the financing and tax exemptions for the profitability of capital. Crumbs over a four-year period are a challenge for workers and are zeroed in on hard taxation, a new reduction in pensions and tax-free. It turns out that fair growth in the unfair exploitative system does not exist, that the European Union only gets worse for the people. The future of the European Union is the hollow collective agreements that in Greece leave out 90% of workers and those who work for EUR 300 and 400, with unemployment and flexible working are skyrocketing in the working galley of the SYRIZA-ANEL government, as well as under the governments of New Democracy and PASOK. It's the house auctions, it's the blow of the right to strike. It's the deportations of immigrants or their entrapment on the islands. It is pro-capital politics that fuels far-right forces, and that is why it is a fraud to fake progressives on the one hand against conservatives on the other. SYRIZA's vision is what it has agreed with the United States, the European Union and the Capital. All it has to offer the people is a perpetuation of poverty and exploitation, new greater risks than the country's involvement in American-American planning in the Balkans, the promotion of dangerous agreements, such as that of the Prespas, which puts people on new adventures. The Communist Party of Greece is fighting against imperialist plans. It fights for the abolition of all the memorial laws, the recovery of losses, the satisfaction of modern needs. Only the people with their struggle can enforce them.

name: Αλέξης Τσίπρας
text: Prime Minister of Greece. Mr President, this lively debate in Parliament, and in particular in the European Parliament, is always very pleasant for me. Perhaps I did not cause the same enthusiasm or controversy as in my previous presence here, as Mr. Verhofstadt and other MEPs, but I imagine that I have provoked – and it was my aim to provoke – a strong and meaningful dialogue. Because indeed the case of Greece is a matter that must be studied very much by Europe. Because Greece was an experiment that set out our common European values. Because the crisis did not start yesterday, the crisis began in 2010. The adjustment programmes started in 2010 and it has been eight whole years since 2010 so that we can now look to the future with more optimism, so that we can today talk about the definitive end of the economic crisis and the adjustment programmes.  Allow me, dear and dear Members, to tell you that I am happy and happy that it is my government that has succeeded where three consecutive governments failed from 2010 to 2015. This in itself is an extraordinary political success. But what makes me really happy today is not that we have succeeded in completing the adaptation programmes. Because this could be achieved by another political force following a recipe that would leave the vast social majority in the works, leave it unprotected, as it did from 2010 to 2015. If I feel that we have achieved something, it is that on the one hand we have managed to deepen structural reforms, which have led us to fiscal consolidation and the exit from the crisis, while at the same time we have managed to protect, as much as we could in this budgetary margin that we had, the large social majority. This was the great difficulty and great success of these three years: the fact that, in 2015, when I had come here, Greece was on the verge of a major humanitarian crisis, because it had two million uninsured citizens who were not entitled to access health care; because there was no possibility of the minimum guaranteed income for 600 000 people. , social solidarity income; This picture today in Greece does not exist. No, I do not want to tell you here that it is the success story. But it is a path that, step by step, paves the way for the future. And if there's one thing I really want to tell you that I'm happy about, it's that we've succeeded in deepening structural reforms, in giving a path of consolidation of public finances, in achieving primary surpluses that no other government has managed to achieve with much, much tougher fiscal adjustment measures, while at the same time we have managed to protect the most vulnerable, not just the uninsured, not just the poor. , but above all to give a sample of writing to protect labour rights. For there was the core of the neoliberal hegemony of the policies imposed both before the memoranda and during the memorandums in Greece: the shrinking of work, the dissolution of work. Because some believe that only in this way can space be created for development. We believe the opposite: that space for development can only be created by supporting work and supporting social cohesion. This is a great ideological intersection and a difference that we, the progressives, have from the neoliberals. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like – because I have indeed listened with great interest to Mr Verhofstadt – to ask ourselves together: Why did Greece need three programmes in a row? Why did Greece take eight years, while other countries in this difficult economic position – Cyprus, Portugal, Ireland – managed to exit in three years? Big mistakes were made. Mistakes by both the Greek governments and the European institutions. And we have to admit that. Because the first programmes, instead of deepening the structural reforms that the country needs, rather than prioritising structural reforms, have prioritised an unprecedented fiscal adjustment, which has de facto led to an economic impasse. It has led to an unprecedented internal devaluation, a fall in consumption and a vicious cycle, a spiral of recession and austerity. On the contrary, we reached a difficult agreement in 2015, but it was a milder budgetary adjustment agreement, with prioritisation in structural reforms, which previous Greek governments did not want to prioritise. They preferred to cut pensions and wages instead of making structural reforms. Precisely because there were organized interests, which they did not want to touch, and customer relations. That's the truth, whether some of you like it or don't like it, because you want to defend political forces that belong to your own political families. I come to reply to Mr GonzálezPons, who has certainly told me that I have changed. I don't know if that's a bad thing. It is bad for some to remain incorrigible and try to defend what is not defendable. I have, of course, heard you criticise. And I think the criticism is very beneficial for the Republic and I am very happy that you did it to me. I want to remind you that today is September 11th. In addition to the horrific day of the terrorist attack in the United States, it's another black anniversary. It's the anniversary of Salvador Allende's death. I am sorry, Mr González Reasons, that in your speech you have reproduced – I do not know if you are doing so consciously or not – the theory of two extremes. I hope at least you do not think, like some of your friends, like-minded people in Greece, that dictator Pinochet has implemented interesting policies to copy, especially with regard to the insurance system.  But I would like to answer two things specifically from what you said. You talked about nepotism and populism. I would therefore like to remind you that, if you want to talk about nepotism in Greece, there is unfortunately a faction, the conservative faction, which has offered Greece so much – because I want to be fair and fair – in which the children of some successful or non-successful prime ministers usually become leaders. This is the tradition in Greece. Is this anywhere else in conservative parties across Europe? Don't look to us for nepotism or for a client state.  You also talked about populism. I'm sorry, but again in your own party you have to turn when you talk about populism. Because there's no greater populism than playing with national issues and changing your position to fish in the murky waters of the far right and not to break up your party. The attitude of the New Democracy party, which belongs to your political family, in relation to what is necessary for Europe, what is necessary for the Balkans, what is necessary for our region, to solve the problem of the name of our northern neighbour, the Macedonian problem, is an attitude that will be described in future history books as the definition of populism and opportunisticism. I would like to close my remarks to everything you have said in response to something that I imagine you have said without knowing much detail. Mr. Marias said a lot of it, inaccuracies. Mr Marias, of course, has come a long way from the left benches to be on the right benches of Parliament today, but I will reply to you, not to Mr Marias. You talked about 100 billion costs – you say it and many of your conservative fellow politicians say it again – which is the cost of negotiating Greece in that difficult six months; a six-month period in which mistakes were made on both sides, there is no doubt. But it is good that, when we speak in this Chamber, we do not speak in terms of political communication and inaccuracies. Because, if there were indeed a cost-burden of so many billions of euros, public debt would have increased accordingly.  But what exactly do those who claim that there was this cost say? They say that there would be growth momentum on paper in 2015, 2016, 2017, of the order of 20% of GDP, i.e. that the cost to the Greek economy that lost 25% of its GDP, i.e. a quarter of its national wealth, in the first four disastrous years, would supposedly be won if there was no political change in Greece. And how do you really? What policies? With what mr Samaras' previous governments, which you mentioned, had not even managed to have a positive balance, surplus budgets? When the primary surplus, for which he had signed up, was in the order of 4% and 4.5%, but had not managed to reach even 0.3%? With growth rates of 0.3%, which managed 0.4% in just one year in 2014? How would it achieve these rates that would bring back 20% of GDP? Well, these are targeted inaccuracies. As is the inaccuracy of the fact that, supposedly, Greece spent 40 billion on the recapitalisation of banks during this three-year period. Forty-five billion was the total cost of all three recapitalisations, but the recapitalisation made in our own years cost only 6 billion out of the 24 available from the third programme budgetary adjustment. I say this because some things have to be answered. And I say this because I believe that, if we want to look ahead, we must, with our existing ideological and political differences, at least, when we are at a dispute, stand against the real numbers and the reality that we have all faced.  I would like to conclude by saying this: during my speech I tried to point out, I tried to warn of a great and real and danger to Europe. This great and real danger, which concerns the very future of the European Union – an existential danger to Europe – from what I understand from many of the speeches, is not being treated as such. And I would like to say that we are faced with this great risk and because, if not mainly, of the fact that in previous years policies have indeed been prioritised with extreme signage, which were of course aimed at economic balance, but, in order to achieve it, have tried to save the banks without accounting for the cost of social. It is these policies that give the floor today, with a leading role, to extreme political forces. I would like to address once again the whole democratic arc, from the left of social democracy to the liberal centre, but also to you, the People's Party, because these forces are within you and are becoming dominant, hegemonic in political discourse. When you are forced to turn your political rhetoric towards nationalist, extreme, chauvinistic positions in order to reverse or stem the rise of the extreme right in your countries, you do nothing more than feed these extreme forces that will soon reach rates that will be worrying for all of us in Europe. And we have to stop that! To stop this, we must return to the founding values of the European Union, which are solidarity, which is social cohesion, which is the well-being of citizens.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Mr Prime Minister of Greece, I welcome you to the European Parliament. That's a big change you've shown since 2015. Only it did cost the Greek people EUR 100 billion, Mr GonzálezPons did not say so, said Mr Regling of the ESM and Mr Wieser, who told you about EUR 200 billion, of the Eurogroup Working Group. You cost the Greek people the mortgages of state property until 2114, for a century, and you built a society, Mr. Tsipras, not of the 700 euros you were accusing but of 350 euros. What you sign, as you were rightly told, cannot be solved, even an OPEC oil-producing country is. But I would like to ask you two questions. The first issue is what you also referred to, that there is a great enemy in Europe and we are concerned, populism and indeed, there is right-wing populism in both France and Germany; there is centrist populism in Italy; there is liberal populism in Britain. What do you say to those who accuse you of being the most authentic representative of left-wing populism, you and the Podeos in Spain? And one more thing: on Thursday we will be visited by your colleague, Mr Zaev, from Skopje. After 17 June and after the referendum, it will represent the state of Northern Macedonia. What should we call him in the European Parliament? North Macedonia representing Northern Macedonia as a nation and speaking the North Macedonian language or plain Macedonian representing the Macedonian nation and the Macedonian language? I would like an answer to that, Prime Minister.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Kefalogiannis, you have one minute. I shall then be obliged to take one minute away from the Group of the European People's Party. I am sorry, but if you do not keep to the timetable, I am obliged to remove members from their speeches.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, thank you for your words, your commitment and the strength of your convictions for a Europe at the service of Europeans. I am a French socialist, and you know that President François Hollande and Commissioner Pierre Moscovici have been very committed to working to ensure that Greece is kept in the eurozone. We share your priorities, which should be Europe's priorities for social progress, in a protected environment, for more solidarity and humanism, respect for values and intransigence against the violation of fundamental rights. And you have a lot to do in this Council, which is increasingly resistant to it. And you are right, Europe cannot be limited to two sides of the same coin: populists on the one hand and liberalism on the other. There is another possible path, a path to progress, and you can count on us in the Socialists and Democrats group to move this Europe forward for The Europeans.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: Mr President, in recent months all european leaders have said that they are so pleased with the developments in Greece and that this is because of the three bail-outs that have been there. They say: there is economic growth, so it's going well! I think: that's the paper reality! The everyday reality in Greece is completely different. Unemployment is 19%, youth unemployment is 40%! Three quarters of Greek students have said: we are leaving the country! And Greece's public debt is 180% of GDP and rising! The daily reality for millions of Greeks is bleak. It would be better for Greece to leave the euro area and for the public debt to be written off substantially, but that the country would remain in the European Union. With this mix, exports can grow again and the country can continue to claim European funds. That is the route for hope for the Greeks! Does the Prime Minister agree with me? I would also like to say to Mr Bullmann: the biggest austerity we have ever had came from his political family! That was Mr Dijsselbloem!

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Welcome, Prime Minister, to the European Parliament! Three years ago when you came here, the fear of Grexit was dominated by the euro and now everyone, even your fanatical opponents here, attests to Grexit from the memoranda. I understand that the European right and the European far right are annoyed that a left-wing Prime Minister has achieved these positive objectives. We are not done with the crisis but we have taken a big positive step and I note that today's speech is distinguished by left-wing realism, plan and effectiveness in practice for what we have launched in Greece, but it also forees a clear progressive plan for Europe, which can lead to alliances of wider forces, progressives, democrats, against the regression caused by the rising extreme right and the rapid "orbanization" of the European People's Party. The positive comments on your speech from the presidents of the Left, the Socialists, the Greens and the Liberals show positive change.

name: Presidente. –
text: Please keep to the timetable, because then I have to cut off other members of your group.

name: Florian Philippot (EFDD).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, when you came to power in Greece, you gave rise to a great deal of hope: among your people, on the one hand, of course, but also among all those who are committed to democracy and who are aware of the misfortunes that the European Union inflicts on the peoples. I was in it. Then you betrayed, and how? In a well-known way - unfortunately - of the Europeanists, by sitting on the result of a referendum. While your people had spoken out massively against the austerity plan imposed by the Troika, you imposed it on them. What for? Because it was the price of staying in the European Union and in the euro, in defiance of health, pensions and prosperity. Betrayal is the lot of all those who refuse to leave the European Union. And unfortunately many of them, today, in your footsteps, are raising hopes that will inevitably be dashed: Mr Salvini, if he does not decide to take his people, his country out of the European Union, and of course your ally, Mr Mélenchon, whose insubordination is already faltering when he meets Mr Macron. I am not here to lecture you, Prime Minister, but to learn from your failure. I hope that a new generation of politicians will stop going to bed and take a path that, necessarily for nations and for France, will pass through Frexit, that is, leaving the European Union.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Today is a special day, as we can listen to the two prime ministers of two EU Member States. In the morning, a good student, Mr. Ciprasz, and in the afternoon the so-called bad student, Viktor Orbán.  It must be very interesting for analysts and the people of the European Union to compare the two models, but Mr Ciprász, who is applauded and celebrated, says that he has already done almost very well. Not quite yet, because, as the Socialist speaker said, he has not yet handed over his entire economy, his full sovereignty, to the European Union, but he is on the right track. Politically, however, he did very well, because what were the key words: building a mosque, mass resettlement of migrants, allowing same-sex marriage... Let us listen to the other model in the afternoon and in May 2019 we will allow European citizens to choose! Thank you very much!

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, the figures are there, it is 500 billion aid - 300 billion by the redemption of the debt, 100 billion for the banks that have cancelled their debts and 100 billion for the various deferrals, which have a cost. $500 billion in support to divide your gross domestic production (GDP) by 50%. Could you explain to me how such a policy can be made, when if Europe, as I suggested in 2012, had invested wealth, had forced the production of new wealth in Greece, by the monetary creation of the Central Bank, it could have balanced Greece's balance of payments without recession and unemployment. And this plan was rejected because Europe is just a decoy! There is no solidarity, there is no cooperation in the current institutions.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, tribute be paid to the Greek people and their efforts. Let us recognise that the European Union bears its share of responsibility for the long-term period of the Greek crisis, and let us draw two lessons. First, there is no reason why a central state's inability to repay its debt will result in the country leaving its currency zone. California, New York, Puerto Rico went bankrupt, and no one offered to exclude them from the dollar zone.
