Eight years ago, the general lack of composure in diagnosis cost Greece and the eurozone dearly. Secondly, the Greek economy could have recovered earlier if the European capital market had really worked, but for several years national regulators have banned the abundant savings of the strong economies of Northern Europe from financing the large projects of Greek SMEs. Let us make a definite remedy for this.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Prime Minister, first my solidarity with the Greek people for the victims of the fires. As Portuguese, I know very well the pain you're going through.  Secondly, says the Prime Minister that he does not know why Greece had three bailouts. It's easy, because in 2015, the Tsipras/Varoufakis alliance undid for eight, nine, ten months, all the work the Greek government had done so far. That's why things went wrong.  And now let me tell you this: I would just like to know if the Prime Minister has ideas - because he has not presented them here - for the future of the euro zone and for immigration policy. We were hoping that Greece would make that contribution here, but it only came to talk about the changes. Now, changes we know, even our President of the Eurogroup came to welcome the departure of Greece and the whole austerity programme, Mr. Centeno, when, in Portugal, he criticized a much more successful programme. We had much more success at first and he came to criticize, and Mr. Tsipras is the same thing, was against all programs, but implemented a much tougher program than those who had their previous rulers.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D).
text: – Mr Prime Minister, I welcome you here to the temple of the Republic, as you called the European Parliament in 2015. Some time later you found the fortitude but also the prudence, you personally, to sign a new agreement with the European institutions which, while not again avoiding harsh measures or failures, put an end to the barren confrontations but also to the anguish of the Greeks. Since then, and while the future of Europe has been undermined, as you said, by various forces, Greece has been following a different path and in line with European values. I will briefly mention the response to the refugee wave, the agreement of the Prespas and the smooth completion of the loan agreement. But as you know better than I do, the road is still long and difficult and requires political consensus on the big issues, genuine political alliances and the avoidance of the civil passions that have only caused suffering in the country. I hope you share these needs, Prime Minister, and I welcome you again.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it has been declared that the Greek crisis has ended, even though there is more than EUR 300 billion in debt. Weak tax collection and widespread tax avoidance are still major problems.  Prime Minister Tsipras, you have just said that you have succeeded in combating tax evasion. My friends who have been holidaying in Greece have told me how they have often been informed in shops and restaurants that the cash register is broken and only cash is fine. A friend of mine tells me about his experience when he wanted to pay for his big purchases in the store with a card, but the cash register was broken. Because he didn't have enough cash, he decided to give up his purchases. And strangely enough, the cash register began to work and the deals were made. Do you, Prime Minister Tsipras, have any information on the problems caused by these broken cash registers and how to make them work again in Greece?

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr Prime Minister, you describe the future of a Europe of peace, solidarity and the well-being of the peoples, as we envisioned it. But in the absence of the peoples and the Republic, policies are being implemented that disregard these values, that turn to the far right and revive fascism. You boast about what you have achieved with Greece's bailout programme, that you have protected vulnerable groups, but you have forgotten to tell us that you have stopped even cutting widow's pensions. The people with trampled dignity on the verge of survival, the country pinned down by its saviors drives away immigrants its studied minds and its leaders obedient and willing ready to rewrite its history at dictation. This is the shaped future of Greece and Europe in today's Europe. In this moment, what future are you planning? Prime Minister, we were both elected denouncing these policies because we knew very well that they were man-made and destructive to the country. But you have baptized them as "salvation" and you apply them faithfully while we both know very well which alternatives you should and could apply. You don't have an alibi. Do not hope for any leniency when the time comes for both your political and historical judgment.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a few years ago, I was very critical of Prime Minister Tsipras when he appeared before Parliament. I said it was time that he stopped giving interviews to all the TV stations and radio stations in Europe and showed leadership to his people.  I have to say now, Prime Minister, that you have done that. Congratulations. The evidence is there for all to see: tax evasion has been decreased, growth in the economy, the job market improving. You also sensibly let go the showman on the motorbike – the man with all the answers and no solutions, the finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis. But my question to you is this: from your dealings with the Troika and the European institutions in particular, what are your feelings now about them and what reforms would you suggest should be introduced at that level for their dealings with countries like yours and like mine, which are also in the bailout programme, into the future?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr President, what humanist values did the Greek Prime Minister speak of? For those with whom they sent citizens and young children to the hospital the day before yesterday in Thessaloniki? Mr Tsipras's presence in the European Parliament demonstrates the evil, divisive, traitoric and self-destructive future of Europe. A prime minister who, in order to seize power, cursed and blamed all those who today praise him for the dissolution of Greece from NATO, the European Union and even America, a mirror prime minister of the Left who seeks to abolish borders, alter responsibilities and de-obsolescence of family, religion and friendship. Mr. Tsipras, your government presence confirms left-wing fascism and ethno-zeroism. You have signed agreements that are disastrous for my country, succumbing to threats and interests. Operating with cynicism and self-interest, you deconstructed a brilliant nation. You surrendered the name, history and culture of the Macedonians, and stifled the Greek reaction of the Greek people with chemicals and beatings. Unfortunately for you and fortunately for my country, there are still Greek patriots who believe and shout: first Greece!

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I must say: I am surprised. But I also really like to see a Greek prime minister here with a lot of confidence, a Greek prime minister who finds the energy to think about the future again. The future of the Greek people, but also the future of Europe, and let us be clear, the two are very closely linked.  We do not agree on everything, but your analysis of neoliberal policies is supported by this whole group. The future of Europe does not lie in neoliberal solutions. It lies in solutions that have to do with how we can combat social inequality. Because that is the basis of nationalism and xenophobia today. How do we combat the climate problem and how do we ensure – as my group leader has already said – that they are looked at together? How do we make a transition in our economy that is a proper transition? You have also spoken about this, and I think that is really worthy of the support of our group.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased Greece has succeeded and wish to thank the Prime Minister for his share in that, as well as for his efforts to stabilise the Balkans.  We can’t have one strong European Union with different understandings of the dignity of human person and the rule of law. I don’t think that neoliberalism is the main European problem, but rather a lack of political will to do more together. We can succeed in working together only if we really believe and respect the same values, principles and rules. We get into trouble when we don’t respect our common rules.  Prime Minister, you mentioned the eurozone, and I would like to ask you, can you tell us a little bit more about your vision of democratisation of the eurozone and how you would strengthen the role of the European Parliament?

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to inform the Members of the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe that all the time available to the group has been used by the chairman of the group. This is not about the Presidency and I would ask you to be polite and respectful towards me, because rudeness is not acceptable in this House.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D).
text: Welcome, Prime Minister! I admit, I'm confused. Four years ago you were demonstrating against neoliberal austerity, but if we believe Mr Moscovici, you have so far implemented its recipe, the third memorandum. You also co-govern with a small nationalist, often far-right, party, but you have resolutely supported the union-saving agreement with Turkey vis-à-vis your most entitled friends and boldly promoted the promising agreement with YROM-Macedonia that offers stability to the Balkans. Today, you rightly pointed out that we need more Europe in solidarity. On the pro-European and progressive front you are proposing to us, where do you draw the dividing lines? Does the entire radical left fit, which some of its members have already applied to export you? Are Verhofstadt's liberals finally devils or angels? But the five stars who co-govern with the far-right Salvini? Is Macron a hope or a banker after all? Please give us a clear signal because we are in the run-up to the election.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (ECR).
text: Mr. Prime Minister, on your previous visit, I defended you. I defended the government and the Prime Minister of Greece. I disagree that then all of you stood by, as has been said. On the contrary, you have received harsh criticism and insults from both you and every Greek. Of course I do not absolve Europe of its responsibilities for everything that happens to us, everything that happens in Greece. However, today I cannot do the same. I can't defend you because I don't believe in your success story. I have strong disagreements, but I cannot refer to them. I don't want to, I can't do it. I will say only this: you have been said to have been brave in granting the name to Skopje. Unfortunately Skopje has not taken any steps towards compromise, instead celebrating the conquest of Macedonian identity ...  (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Tsipras, thank you for the debate on the future of Europe, a future of which I am pleased that the Greeks will be an integral part of it. Because frankly, four years ago there was no certainty about that at all. A future in which solidarity and responsibility will go hand in hand, despite all the progress greece has already made.  Let's be honest. You may be out of intensive care, but that's not why you're completely cured. That is why I ask for guarantees, guarantees that we will not go back to 2014, to the start of your mandate. It also guarantees that, without memoranda, we will not go back to the way in which you and Yannis Varoufakis managed to do 200 billion damages in six months, a figure that I do not find here on the spot, a figure that Jeroen Dijsselbloem confirmed this weekend. I ask for assurances, Prime Minister Tsipras, that if you want to continue to count on our solidarity, we can continue to count on your responsibility.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have the impression that we are having a debate on Greece, not on the future of the European Union. And speaking of the future of the European Union, we would have liked Mr González Pons to have told us, instead of attacking Greece so much, whether they will go from allies to the populists of Orban and Salvini to the next election.  But in any case, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stand in solidarity with the Greek people in the wake of what happened this summer with the fires. What has happened this year in Greece, and last year in Portugal and Spain, shows us that the European Union has to have leadership in the face of the challenge of climate change. Climate change has a lot to do with what has happened. And, ladies and gentlemen, I am beginning to have the impression — after what I am beginning to hear in France, Germany, etc.— that we do not have on the agenda as a priority to reduce emissions and be more effective in this European leadership in the fight against climate change. We have a chance and it's a great challenge for humanity.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I have listened very carefully to your words. You said, I think very rightly, that you have managed the crisis thanks to the Greek people and the help of the European Union. I understand, then, that you agree that it was the financial assistance and also the pressure for the reforms that you had to make that helped Greece cope with this situation? Am I getting this right? It's a question for you, and I expect an answer. And I mean, I realize you've done a great deal of work.  At the moment, I want to thank, above all, the people who care for refugees in refugee camps, in the hotspots. They're doing a huge job. I personally visited the camp in Athens and. Prime Minister, I would like to call on you to help the people who are organising aid to refugees, especially the island of Lesbos is in crisis. The mayor of Mytilina is doing a tremendous job, you have the opportunity to help them. Do it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, I want from the beginning to declare that I love Greece, I love the Greek people and you have an extraordinary country. But I don't want to talk about Greece, as a colleague said. We are talking about the future of Europe, which is why, after congratulating you on the results, I want to ask you on time: you, as Prime Minister of the country, what do you think of the future of Europe? Do you agree with Mr Macron's proposal, which, also here, has told us that two Europes are needed, a few states more states than the others? What do you think of the fact that the European Parliament should have legislative initiative? What do you think and how do you see the problem in relation to the Republic of Macedonia resolved? Last but not least, I would like to ask you what your position is on the new multiannual financial framework, whether it is appropriate to cut agricultural policy and regional development funds. Here are some points that I am interested in, as a member of the Council, to hear from you here.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to be specific in order to increase interest in Greek public opinion. I would like Mr. Tsipras to answer me if he is going to proceed with the reduction of pensions on New Year's Day 2019, as he has signed with the European institutions and as he has voted in the House, despite the objections of our party, or if he will not ultimately proceed with this reduction in pensions, as many government officials promise the Greek people. This is of huge importance because it helps us to judge whether we have come out of the crisis or, anyway, whether the crisis continues by other methods. I would also like him to answer me about what he will do with the VAT rate on the five islands affected by the refugee crisis. It has postponed its increase; but will it increase it on New Year's Day 2019?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my full solidarity and to thank those who remarked how the neoliberal recipe of unaccountable technocratic bodies such as the Troika and the Eurogroup increased poverty, unemployment and social inequalities in Greece and elsewhere in Europe. What, then, is to be said about the loss of control by Greece and the European Union of critical strategic infrastructures, such as Piraeus Port and the telecommunications and energy networks which Greece had to sell to China as a result of the privatisation frenzy imposed by the neoliberal tracker programmes? How are Greece and the EU to overcome such a strategic loss of control, which places in question our collective security?

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: – Prime Minister, in your face we congratulate the Greek people who, through restructuring but also through deprivation and pain, today can look forward to a better future. In 2015 in this European Parliament, I remember very well that, when some people around you and some in this house were pushing Greece off the cliff outside the euro zone, this Group of Socialists and Democrats reached out, above policies and ideologies, because we believe in Greece, we believe in social policy and we believe in Europe. That is why I am asking you about the future: how do we promote European policies for a pan-European deposit guarantee, how do we promote European energy policies in the Eastern Mediterranean and how, at last, the rule of law will prevail in the northern occupied part of Cyprus?

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr Prime Minister, I welcome you here to the European Parliament. Frankly, I wasn't going to take the floor until I heard the first round of your answer. So I listened carefully to you claiming that in Greece there is nepotism, that there are fans of Pinochet. I was really expecting, since yesterday we had a very interesting debate here about how the European Union would support the Eye and we have gathered all the political groups for the European Union to support the Eye, so I expected you to feel that you are the Prime Minister of Greece and not to transfer here the internal political confrontation; unless you consider that nepotism is to elect the leader of a party with hundreds of thousands of votes and that nepotism is not to serve in government members families of party officials; unless you consider that Pinochet's admirers are some who make unfortunate and wrong approaches and not those who drown in tear gas those who protest because you have handed over the Macedonian nation and the Macedonian language to their neighbours. Really, I want to ask you from the opposition benches what prospect will you offer the Greeks? The one of division?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister Tsipras, we have heard a harsh criticism of austerity, and I would like to tell you that you have never been alone, that there have been many of us who, throughout the crisis, have denounced the failure of austerity. That it is not a mistake or an accident, but an example of political and ideological imposition, of a pernicious adjustment of accounts against the social model, and which has had an impact on the impoverishment of the middle classes and the exasperation of inequalities. , such as fires in Greece or as an increase in migration flow. Greece, Italy, Spain. Therefore, a very clear lesson, Mr Tsipras: alliances must be sought. Seek alliances — Portugal, Spain — not only to change the economic policy that has failed, but to change that negative look at immigration, which is also destined for failure, and to replace it at once with a humanitarian vision, of common responsibility and shared responsibility for migration flows and care for refugees.

name: Αλέξης Τσίπρας
text: Prime Minister of Greece. Mr President, there have been many interesting questions, many interesting positions. Obviously I won't be able to answer everything, but I will try to answer as many as I can.  First of all, I would like to answer the honourable friend and acquaintance of the controversies in the Greek Parliament, Mr Kefaloyannis, to the question he asked me in relation to the presence in the European Parliament, in a few days, of the Prime Minister of our neighbouring country, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, who – if all goes well and I hope it goes well – in a few months will change both its name and its Constitution and it will be called 'Northern Macedonia'. Mr Kefaloyannis, in all the previous years mr Zaev's predecessor, Mr Gruevski, came to the European Parliament or other European institutions, what did he call himself and what did your colleagues, the vast majority of your colleagues, and of course the vast majority of your colleagues in the European People's Party call him? I don't know. A Skopje?  Mr Kefaloyannis, here we are in the European Parliament and therefore we cannot function, as we have often operated in Greece, putting our heads like an ostrich in the sand, with a taboo around us, only us Greeks, while the rest of the world – and of course here in the European Parliament you know this very well – was in another reality. Because 140 countries around the world, including the largest, the United States of America, China, Russia, recognise our neighbouring country by its constitutional name, which it has had for 25 years. And its constitutional name is "Macedonia". Of course, both Mr Gruevski and all the officials have called themselves 'Macedonians' over the years, but I have not seen you bothered by this. Just as I did not see you bothered when, all the previous years, both Mr Zaev and all his fellow citizens entered Greece – and they did well to enter Greece and also holiday en masse on the Greek coast, because this strengthened the Greek economy – so they entered the country with a passport which what it said? It said "Macedonians." From now on, the passport will say "citizens of Northern Macedonia". This phrase will be added.  Nor do I know whether it has any value for you – to me it is of great value – the fact that in all previous years Mr Zaev's predecessor, with whom we have an excellent cooperation, Mr Gruevski, who belongs to the nationalist right, the far right, had filled his country, every city and every square in the neighbouring country. , with statues of Alexander the Great and with all those symbols that are characteristic of ancient Greek Macedonia and are an integral part of Greek history and tradition. From now on, no one will have the right to do this in the neighbouring country. Neither the current Prime Minister of our neighbouring country nor the future Prime Ministers will have the right to invoke Alexander the Great and Greek History as their own piece. Isn't that important to you? And, of course, what is perhaps most important of all is that it will confirm every Prime Minister of the neighbouring country from now on the clearly Slavic origin of his people and his language.  This, Mr Kefaloyannis, has not been the same until now. And I want to address both you and – not to turn the debate into an internal debate – and all MEPs to understand something. In Greece and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, both I and Zoran Zaev are under intense attack. We're accused of being both traitors. Mr Mitsotakis in Greece and Mr Mickoski in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, who belong to the political family of the People's Party, accuse us, with exactly the same argument, which simply changes the sign, of being traitors and of having brought a damaging agreement. I would therefore like to put this to your discretion, ladies and gentlemen, and say that, precisely because both conservative leaders accuse us of being traitors and of having made a traitorous agreement, we have probably done something good for our peoples, and me and Zoran Zaev. We are probably going down a path to the future, towards peace, towards the prospect of cooperation and the coexistence of our peoples, a path that will make history. And I'm proud that we've accomplished that. One Member, I imagine from Hungary, referred to Mr Orbán, saying that he is 'the bad student', as opposed to me being 'the good student', on the occasion of course the fact that my colleague, Mr Orbán, will be in this Chamber in a few hours. Look, I want to answer you on Substance. Because, you know, you can't judge politicians or politicians by tagging, but by seeing and criticizing politically the ideas they represent and the values they stand for. Some in Europe, of course, can make policy with the European Union's money, because solidarity is à la carte for them; some in the European Union can make a safe policy, too, because their countries are enclosed and have land borders, not maritime ones; some in the European Union may remember European values whenever it is in their interest.  You said we brought the immigrants. I don't know. I thought the wars brought this great wave of migration and refugee flow to Europe. I would like to ask you, in reply: do you really think that any country in Europe, even if it is small and enclosed and not with maritime borders, can survive on its own? Without help? No solidarity? Without cooperation? Do you really think that cooperation, aid and solidarity will be à la carte whenever it is in your interest, and that, when the problem is not in your own backyard, you will throw it to the person next door? Europe cannot go ahead like this. I have also heard a colleague of yours talk about the traitoral future of Europe. Well, the logic of 'everyone alone', the logic of 'Greece first', 'France first', 'Italy first' is a logic that will lead Europe to disintegration. That is exactly the point I tried to raise in my speech.  I heard the friend of a Member of the European Parliament from the River, Miltiadis Kyrkos, say that he was confused. Yes, Miltiadis, the reality we live in is confused. And we must all unravel in this tangled reality what the primary threat is. The differences I have with many other colleagues, both from the left and from the Social Democracy area, even from the Liberal Centre or Ecology, are given. But the snake's egg is currently incubated in Europe, just like in the 1930s. And just as, in the 1930s, the primary threat was met with the widest possible coalition of forces that had differences, that is what I believe is our duty today. And to close all this reference to immigration, let me tell you that I am happy with what we have achieved inland, but the situation on the Greek islands is extremely difficult. We don't honor any of us in this situation. But we are obliged to support an agreement without which things would be much worse for all of us. That's why Greece needs support. That is why synergies and cooperation are needed in this direction. And of course it is necessary, when we talk about refugees or immigrants, not only to talk about numbers and brutal numbers and statistics, but to look behind the numbers and faces of those people who have names, names. They may not be European names, they may not be names familiar to us, but these people have a name, a person, feelings, values, "believe" and want to live a better life.  I heard the New Democracy spokesperson and MEP, Mrs Spyrakis, abandon me. I am pleased that, I repeat, dialogue and confrontation are the vitality of the Republic. I would like to tell you the following: you referred to me and the gathering of a few thousand extreme elements the day before, three or four thousand in Thessaloniki. Nothing to do with the big rallies that actually took place in February. You know I'll be the last to deny every citizen the inalienable right to demonstrate in a democratic state. But I would like to remind you, Mrs Spyrakis, that it was you who, for years, as a prominent journalist on a television station, almost every night, when we actually had mass demonstrations with a really great repression, the first five years of your station were going out and you were actually exercising the function of information, as you yourself admitted, in a way that concealed the truth. At the time, you had no particular sensitivity either to presenting the actual numbers of the demonstrations, nor to highlighting the repression and violence suffered by these demonstrations. Today I see that you are very sensitive. I'm glad for that sensitivity. But I want to assure all your colleagues here in the European Parliament that sensitivity must not be à la carte and that in Greece there is neither repression nor violence. On the contrary, in these three years the social, political and democratic rights of citizens have been upgraded by a series of legislative interventions.  I would like to close without distressing your other colleague and compatriot, Mr Kyrchos, because he has raised specific questions. Ladies and gentlemen, you are all aware that Greece, with its exit from the adjustment programmes, is now a country like all the other countries of the euro area, with a peculiarity, as of course all the countries that have been in enhanced monitoring and cooperation programmes with the institutions and in particular with the Commission. Like the other euro area countries, greece, from now on, will be obliged to meet the targets we have set together, our obligations, that is, the fiscal target of 3.5% of GDP surplus by 2022. That's our deal. But it will be the Greek government that chooses the instruments and policies to meet these goals, as is the case in all other eurozone countries and those that have come out of programmes. So these policies and these instruments, with full statistics and forecasts for each subsequent year, we will discuss them by submitting our budget to the Commission every October. So we will do this year in relation to 2019 and together we will take those decisions, which will be the right ones, in order to strengthen the growth momentum of the Greek economy. And growth momentum means no more austerity, no more cuts, a boost in consumption, to the extent, of course, I repeat, that this will allow us to meet the budgetary targets. It's that simple!  I close with a comment on the future of Europe. A question has been asked about how we dream of the democratisation of the euro area and the course of the European Union from now on. We do believe in the need for political deepening. And we do believe in strengthening Parliament's role. You will remember that I was one of those who tried and succeeded in ensure that the debate on the fiscal adjustment programme in Greece over the last three years does not take place behind closed doors and that the European Parliament plays an essential role in this debate; that policies are not decided behind closed doors. I don't know if we've achieved that in its entire right. But we have made an effort in this direction. I also believe that in the crucial next period we must decide on an enhanced Community budget, on a budgetary programme that will enable us to strengthen convergence between the Member States of the euro area and, of course, on the possibility of greater transparency and accountability in the next period. I support the view of a minister of the euro area finances, but I believe at the same time in the need for a minister of social cohesion working in the euro area. This is because I do not believe in one-dimensional fiscal fetishism, but in the need to be able to achieve the budgetary path within objectives at the same time as social protection. We are not and am not in favour of a two-speed Europe. We are in favour of a functioning Europe, the enhanced cooperation provided for in the current European Treaties, especially since it can achieve our objective of a democratic, social and ecological Europe through them.  With these thoughts, I would like to warmly thank you all for your interest, for your questions, for your opposition and to tell you that, despite our disagreements, our strong, despite our tensions, we have managed to go one step further. We have managed to escape the great vortex of crisis. Let us draw our conclusions on the causes that led us to it, so that we can now make the major changes that Europe needs, so that the same mistakes are not repeated, so that we do not find ourselves in the same difficult position we have found ourselves in in previous years.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Greek MEPs wear the jersey of the Greek National. Today you addressed the European Parliament as leader of SYRIZA, not as prime minister of the country. You spoke of widespread corruption, the breakdown of money in health by previous governments, regardless of whether you tarnish the image of our country. Greece is struggling to emerge from the crisis based on the sacrifices of the Greek people, not thanks to the non-existent success story of your government, as you have attempted to present. You have damaged the economy by more than EUR 100 billion, you have pledged public property for 99 years, you have committed the country to unattainable surpluses by 2060, you have idly by EUR 15 billion, you have cut benefits for low-retired, multi-child and disabled people. Your economic populism has taken away the sacrifices of five years, triggered capital controls, deprived the country of its quantitative easing programme and driven thousands of young people abroad. You blamed the previous government, which was generally about to come out of the memorandums at the end of 2014. The Samaras government attracted 34 billion euros in investment in two years, while you in 3.5 years did not bring a single new serious investment. You have described the Prespa Agreement as a model for dispute resolution, and with it you have given our neighbours Macedonian language and identity, retreating from standing Greek positions.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. – Our people expect clear answers, no evasiveness, no unnecessary conflicts without content. At a time when the government is closing its ears to the will of our fellow citizens for the attempted Tsipras-Zaev agreement, at a time when our country needs unity, the Prime Minister once again preferred to blame the ND and previous governments in front of foreign colleagues. In the debate on the future of Europe, Mr Tsipras would be better off focusing on our young people fleeing abroad, on our cultural heritage honoured this year by the EU, on the inequality of opportunities and jobs between northern and southern countries even today, eight years since the beginning of the crisis. The citizens are anxious. These are not the times for slogans, Greeks, Europeans now need solutions, not false promises and contres of impressment.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President, you are welcome in the European Parliament. For us, it is an honour, a great pleasure to have you here in the house of European democracy. It's very important for us to listen to you. The situation in the Mediterranean is difficult, we have a problem of immigration, of refugees. I want to thank the Lebanese Republic for its commitment to refugees; you have welcomed hundreds of thousands of Syrians and thanks to your commitment, the presence of refugees and immigrants in Europe has been reduced. We cannot forget your work and your commitment. We must move forward and continue to strengthen cooperation between you and us. We also know that Lebanon is a country that has made interfaith dialogue its strength, it is a good example to follow everywhere. Your country is also very important for stability in the Mediterranean region. In the face of what is happening in Syria and Libya, we need Mediterranean countries that are committed to peace and dialogue. Mr President, a big thank you once again, not only for your presence here, but above all for what your country is doing for stability, peace and dialogue in the Mediterranean region. A big thank you and I'll give you the floor right away.

name: Michel Aoun
text: President of the Lebanese Republic. Mr President of the European Parliament, Ladies and Gentlemen, I am pleased to be present today at the European Parliament's headquarters in Strasbourg, in front of the elected representatives of 28 states who have chosen to make the European continent an unrivalled model in the world. A model of exchange, integration and unity at all levels, which transforms the countries of the European Union into a single space in which peoples' dreams are based and where principles and ideals are shared, while safeguarding every specificity and civilization and the belonging of peoples to their land, their language, their heritage and their homeland. The strength of this democratic construction and edifice has enabled the consolidation of a genuine peace within the European continent, thus extinguishing the desires of the use of war as the only method of solving problems. These peoples and states believe that their strength, interests and prosperity depend on their unity and the sharing of their democratic values, not on conflict to ensure their success. It is very regrettable to see the emergence of certain separatist and secessionist tendencies that threaten the balance of this pioneering edifice in the meeting of peoples. Ladies and gentlemen, at a time in our history when the voice of humanity is weakening and the interests of the great powers are oversteering all limits at the expense of human justice and solidarity, we believe that only dialogue, mutual respect and the return to implementation of the universal principles of human rights, of communities , and countries will help defuse the violence, wars and extremism that have made the world and our Region of the Near East a place inflamed by hatred, fear and tension. War, although the economy is the real engine, cannot be waged on a solid foundation; it requires a cracked, permeable terrain, ready to ignite. There is nothing like incitement to intolerance, religious, community and ethnic extremism, nothing like the rejection of the other to cause this disintegration, to crack the base and to light the flames of war. What is happening in our region today brings us even more attached to the very foundations on which the State of Lebanon was built and, above all, to the democratic regime that characterizes it, which, despite certain shortcomings, brings together all the components of the Lebanese people and reflects the very essence of lebanon's message of coexistence, diversity, pluralism and cultural richness. As a result of the conflicts in our region, Lebanon has experienced political divisions, but not at the national level. Political rhetoric was certainly inflamed, but it did not set fire to the powder. When some moved away from the normal path of embracing extremism and fundamentalist thinking, they were immediately rejected, both by their community and by the country. Indeed, Lebanese society, by its very nature, is not a breeding ground for extremism and rejection of the other. Respect for freedom of belief, freedom of expression and opinion, and the right to difference are an integral part of Lebanese culture. This Lebanese specificity helps the country to overcome its problems and consolidate its peace and stability. It can also serve as an example to other countries, in order to build a future more in tune with modernity and human rights, especially if we succeed in filling certain gaps and reaching the democratic maturity to which we aspire. In this context, Lebanon greatly appreciates the European Union's awareness of its specificity, its uniqueness. The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe expressed this in the second paragraph of its resolution 2150, in which it stresses the many specificities and the great religious diversity that make Lebanon a unique country. Lebanon is the oldest democracy in the Middle East, political power is shared equitably between Christians and Muslims, making it an example of peaceful coexistence that must be supported in order to continue on this path. Ladies and gentlemen, dear Members of Parliament, last May, Lebanon organised, despite some political tug-of-war which delayed its holding, legislative elections which were held according to a modern electoral law, based on proportional representation. These elections resulted in a more balanced and precise representation of the political forces involved, thus allowing for greater diversity within the parliament and thus strengthening democratic life. In this context, I must therefore commend the work carried out by the Union's election observation mission, led by Mrs Elena Valenciano, who accompanied the various stages of the preparations for the elections and the conduct of the elections. This European Parliament's election observation mission presented a positive report on the electoral process last July. This report contains various new recommendations, made to fill some gaps. These recommendations will certainly be taken into account in the future. In this regard, we wish to strengthen cooperation between our Parliament and the European Parliament by intensifying joint meetings and exchanges of experiences, in order to promote the performance and activity of our legislative power, in line with current requirements. Ladies and gentlemen, my country is currently facing many challenges, including difficult economic conditions. We recently launched an economic plan, outlined in a roadmap to revitalize productive sectors and modernize our country's infrastructure. This plan reinforces the decisions taken at the CEDRE conference. I have placed the fight against corruption and the promotion of transparency among my priorities. We have already made some progress in this area. Ladies and gentlemen, Lebanon has taken its share of the economic, social and security crisis in the region. Terrorist organizations have infiltrated our borders to the east and north to make it a springboard for their bloody operations in the interior of Lebanese territory. However, our army launched a successful military offensive, which resulted in the defeat of the terrorists and the liberation of our territories. Our army continued to work in collaboration with all organs and services of the state, in order to dismantle the dormant terrorist cells until their total elimination. In this way, we have been able to restore the security and stability of the country. Nevertheless, the crisis caused by the displaced Syrians is the one that weighs most on Lebanon. Its consequences are devastating for the economic, security and social sectors. In the name of human solidarity, Lebanon has welcomed more than 1.5 million refugees who have fled the hell of the war in Syria. However, in a small country like ours, with a high population density, limited resources and already suffering from weak infrastructure and rising unemployment, this burden is very difficult to bear. You are aware of the devastating effects of the presence of Syrian refugees. The international community has not taken its share of responsibility in supporting Lebanon in the face of the effects of the presence of migrants. We therefore call on the implementation of financial support decisions, particularly those adopted at the Brussels conference. We also call for consideration of the reservations we have expressed on certain points of the final communiqué of the Brussels conference, in particular those relating to the voluntary return of refugees or displaced persons, in particular the link between this return and the political solution, or the integration of migrants or displaced persons into the labour market in the host countries. It should be remembered in this regard that Lebanon is a country of emigration and not a country of settlement, much less a labour market. The Lebanese scattered throughout the world, and on the European continent in particular, are proof of this. Today, Lebanon aims to ensure the dignified and safe return of displaced Syrians and rejects any delaying manoeuvres in this regard. My country supports any move to find a solution to the mass displacement of Syrians on its territory, like the Russian initiative, and refuses to link the return of the displaced to a political solution that could be delayed. In this regard, I would like to remind you that the Palestinian people have been living in camps since 1948, particularly in Lebanon, awaiting a political solution and the implementation of Resolution 194. After 70 years of waiting, instead of a solution to the Palestinian problem, it is unfortunately a final settlement project that is beginning to loom on the horizon, as if the international community were adopting the policy of the adage "giving what one does not have to the one who does not deserve it". Ladies and gentlemen, on this day of September 11, we commemorate the events of September 11, 2001, a pivotal date that changed the course of world history and pushed the United States to declare war on terrorism, with the promise of freedom, democracy and a term for terrorism. Unfortunately, for the past 17 years and to this day, the war on terror has had the effect of spreading the war around the world rather than ending it. I quote in this regard a passage from an open letter I sent to world leaders in 1995, in which I warned them of the danger of the rise of fundamentalism that was beginning to emerge in some countries. Here is what I wrote: "The latest events in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Algeria and, to a lesser extent, Paris, are only premonitory signs of conflicts that will threaten us tomorrow and that neither nuclear deterrence nor conventional war can stop. Fundamentalism, born of inequality in the application of international law and the frustrations of unbalanced development, risks drowning an entire civilization in obscurantism. No one is immune to the violence of ethnic and fundamentalist passions, and no border can contain them. Aren't these viruses grown in laboratories of political realism likely to contaminate those who, indifferent or complicit, have allowed them to germinate?" Unfortunately, the whole world is now suffering from the repercussions of laboratory experiments of political realism and the neglect of the premonitory signs that could have put us on the path. I would add to this that international policy in the Middle East only exacerbates radicalization and hatred, and paves the way for violence and terrorism. There is no doubt that these justiceless policies are causing trouble in the application of democracy, and this in the pioneering countries, those who had been the first to establish it as a political system. Can preserving human rights at home and sacrifice them outside its borders help serve the interests of the great powers and be synonymous with democracy? This same policy prompted Israel to Judaize Jerusalem and make it its capital, ignoring all international resolutions as well as the votes of the Security Council and the UN General Assembly. Israel did not stop there, it even passed the law of the "Jewish Nation State". Added to this is the recent US decision to end UNRWA funding, which means the beginning of the de facto settlement of Palestinians in the countries that have hosted them, including Lebanon. This is something we reject in the name of justice and equality. Ladies and gentlemen, I come here today on behalf of Lebanon, as The Holy Father John Paul II described it. Its 5,000-year-old civilization, with its many and deep roots, has allowed its children, through its many and varied facets and dimensions, to spread throughout the world and integrate into all cultures, wherever they go. I take the opportunity to be with you today to renew an appeal, already launched especially from the United Nations rostrum, to make Lebanon a permanent centre for dialogue between civilizations, religions and races. This project is being followed by our ambassadors around the world and we hope that it will be proposed at the upcoming session of the UN General Assembly in 2019, just as we hope it will garner the support of European countries. For who better than the countries of Europe to know the importance of dialogue in order to fill the gaps, heal wounds and establish a culture of peace? Thank you for having me here today. Thank you for your attention. Long live Europe, long live Lebanon. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Le Président. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President, for your words. We must continue to move forward with the cooperation between your country Lebanon and the European Union. We must all work together for dialogue, for peace and to solve the refugee problem, at home and at home. This is not easy, but thanks to the will of those who work, statesmen or Members of Parliament, together we can achieve a positive result for our fellow citizens and for all refugees, who have the right to return home. I believe that all Syrians have the right to return to Syria to live in peace in their city or village and to enjoy a good democracy. Syria is a great country with an important history and one of the most important heritage in the Mediterranean; we must prevent this country from being destroyed by civil war. Thanks to Lebanon, hundreds of thousands of Syrian citizens have been able to resist, but now they must be allowed to return home. Once again, Mr President, a big thank you to you and your country for what you are doing. (The meeting is suspended for a few moments while waiting for the time of the votes)

name: Președintele. –
text: I have a communication to make: the Committee on Legal Affairs carried out the verification of the credentials of Mr Romeo Franz and Mr Christophe Hansen and proposed to validate their mandate from 3 July and 2 September 2018 respectively. There are observations?... Not?... Thanks. So these warrants are validated.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, I am asking for the floor on a point of procedure in relation to the previous debate with the Prime Minister of Greece, Mr Tsipras, a debate which was broadcast directly on Greek television, and the speech by Mr Tsipras, Mr Dombrovskis, the representatives of the PRE and the Socialist Party was broadcast and, as soon as I spoke, television stopped broadcasting live. This is the Republic of a la Tsipras so that our views are not heard! I denounce it and point out that, on these terms, we cannot go to the European elections. We cannot go to the European elections without expressing all the views! And I note that in 2015 the speech and the debate in Mr. Tsipras's Parliament were broadcast, that in 2014 the whole debate with Mr. Samaras was broadcast. We denounce the undemocratic process and call on friends from the European Left to take a stand!

name: President. –
text: Mr Marias, your point has been recorded. Personally, I do not know the details and therefore I would abstain from making any further comment.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: I would like to recall an event from 17 years ago in this house. That was the biggest Islamist attack in the Western world: thousands of victims and tens of thousands of relatives. Thank you very much.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to speak to 149, 149a and 165. I welcome the fact that in recent days we have remembered the victims of the forest fires in Greece and the brutal bus attack. However, this Parliament cannot do anything about this. But I miss a minute of remembrance for the many victims of multicultural terror in Europe, and I hope that Daniels from Chemnitz and Markus from Köthen, who have died by migrants, will be remembered here in Parliament, because many in Parliament are partly to blame.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item on the agenda is voting. (For results and other details of votes: see Minutes)

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, on behalf of the EFDD Group, I should like to request that we proceed to the vote on the amendments tabled to the report that we will be voting on in a few minutes' time, as provided for in Rule 59(3) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to use this opportunity to say that I withdrew my name from this report. This is not a surprise for my colleagues in the committee, but I am really disappointed that Parliament again failed to rebalance the research funds under Euratom in favour of challenges, especially around nuclear waste, which we face in many of our Member States. The bill will come back to this House later on. Thank you for your attention.  (Applause)

name: Președintele. –
text: I took note.

name: Președintele. –
text: The vote is over.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the discussions that we have been having about the future status of Northern Ireland and the border within Ireland have an oddly antiquated, almost 19th century feel as though borders were some terrific event involving customs officers with great epaulets and peaked caps who have to rifle through your bags and check every item. Of course, these days the overwhelming majority of customs checks are done online and in advance. Indeed, advances in blockchain will eventually make customs checks between all advanced economies irrelevant. We already have a border on the island of Ireland. There are differential regulations, differential tax rates. There is some cross-border smuggling now, and it is policed away from the border. There is no reason why, provided we have a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union based on mutual recognition, we cannot carry on with the existing arrangements.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was very pleased to support this report, and I thank Derek Vaughan for his good work on it. Investment from the EU’s cohesion policy has had a tremendously important and positive impact on the people, local economy and social reality in Northern Ireland. This is particularly true for disadvantaged urban and rural areas, as well as for cross-community relations. The cohesion policy has been an active contributor to the peace process with investment such as PEACE and INTERREG funding playing an effective role in maintaining peace and reconciliation. The PEACE Programme has been of particular significance, with a special focus on building cross-border relations. The EU Structural Funds should continue to play an effective role in upholding the Good Friday Agreement. The northern Irish economy has benefited substantially from EU cohesion policy, and should continue to do so. For example, the European Regional Development Fund has put EUR 140 million towards SMEs. The European Rural Development Fund has likewise helped agri-food businesses. I welcome this report and I voted in favour.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, due to the effects of the crisis, which have been going on since 2008, as well as the unprecedented influx of refugees and migrants between 2015 and 2016, Greece has had to deal with liquidity problems and a lack of public funds for investments necessary to foster a sustainable economic recovery. This report, which we support, analyses the special measures that have enabled Greece not to lose the resources of 2007-2013 and to improve the absorption rate of the current programming. From this point of view, as we have pointed out in a number of amendments, and as stated in paragraph 12, further information on the social and environmental sustainability value of these funds would nevertheless be useful. A holistic analysis of the situation in Greece, which is not covered by this particular report and the specific regulation dealt with here, should in fact consider indicators other than GDP. Particularly positive for us is paragraph 16, which also comes from our amendment, which shows that some regions have difficulty in cofinancing structural fund projects, and above all calls on the Commission to give urgent consideration, within the framework of the European Semester and the Stability and Growth Pact, to the impact of calculating the deficit in regional investment co-financed with the Structural Funds. , especially in less developed regions. We hope that the Commission will take note again, and a proper note, at least this time, of these comments, and we will therefore work to ensure that the Commission wakes up and removes the cofinancing of the structural funds from the calculation of the deficit.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: –Mr President, Greece, we are now told, has turned the corner. It has returned to normality. Actually, I’m not sure it has even returned to normality in a strict constitutional sense in the sense that it still has external constraints on its budgetary freedom of action. But how can we talk of normality, given the economic and human ruin inflicted on that country over the past decade? How can you begin to weigh up the ongoing cost to Greece of the lost talent from the generation driven into emigration? An irrecoverable generation. We talk of normality, but I would ask all colleagues in this House if they can’t declutter their minds of assumptions and prejudices and ask themselves one question honestly: would it not have been much better, knowing what we now know for Greece, when the crisis emerged in 2009 to have defaulted, decoupled, devalued and returned to growth?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, fortunately here you give us the right to speak and fortunately here what we say is recorded and broadcast because, as I complained to you before, when my speech at the meeting here began, in the presence of Mr Tsipras, the Greek Radio and Television broadcasting programme cut me off from the air to prove that there is no longer pluralism in Greece. This is democracy in Greece, in these terms, with democracy a la Tsipras, we will go to the elections. In any case, I want to say that the measures taken for Greece really supported the Greek economy but we say "burn you Giannis to rub you with oil", that is, after the memoranda imposed by the European Union broke the Greek economy, then the European Union came to change the rules to get liquidity to Greece. That's the reality.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal because, in my opinion, it is a true example of European belonging. We approved the rules that allowed and allowed Greece at that time to fully cover the costs they had with the financing of European projects, and those projects really helped. It was aid to specific businesses, to infrastructure, it was aid that boosted the performance of the Greek economy and increased employment. Therefore, I think that this measure, which was extraordinary, I do not know if it is repeatable, but it was really extraordinary, it really helped the Greek people. I am proud that we also unanimously approved this measure in our REGI committee at the time. For this reason, I supported this report, which assesses the impact of these measures, and I think that this is indeed a measure that we have taken for the benefit of the Greek people, of which we can be proud.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European We Hungarians, with Mrs Sargentini's tour, have taken part in a legal history tour in recent times. It took us to the world of Soviet state theory, when, you know, the point was that we don't need law, we don't need norms, we need revolutionary self-awareness, which shows us the right way as a compass, there is accountability in the judiciary.  But now, in this Greek debate, at least we see the standards that this particular revolutionary consciousness is set for the Member States, and in particular, for the more disadvantaged Southern and Eastern European Member States: the reception of mass migration, the construction of mosques, same-sex marriage and, right, the privatisation of national treasures in the world of the economy, the enrichment of the various international banks. That's not the path we chose. I look forward to this afternoon's debate and the possibility of comparison. Thank you!

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as we meet here, the British Trades Union Congress meets this week for its 150th annual congress. firmly on their agenda is the important need to strengthen and protect employment rights. The report that we have just approved this morning sets out the important need to strengthen the rights of people in the workplace with a terminal illness. That is the subject of the important ‘Dying to Work’ campaign, which has secured the support of Members from across this House, of trade unions and of employers. We must redouble our efforts, and I call again on the Commission today to take legislative action to ensure that people with a terminal illness are supported by their employers and have their full rights in the workplace protected.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, bearing in mind Europe’s ageing population and the fact that almost 30% of Europeans report having a chronic physical or mental health problem, illness or disability, the issue of the reintegration of workers is of the highest importance. I would like to thank all my colleagues who worked on this report. I hope that we will raise awareness about stress and burnout at work, talk more about mental health in the workplace and, most importantly, recognise the psychological and social factors that a return to work entails for individuals, and recommend tailormade measures in different cases, since we don’t have one measure that fits all. Workplaces should ensure a physically and mentally safe and healthy working environment throughout people’s working life, and active and healthy ageing for workers. Member State employers should have the obligation to keep a positive work-oriented approach to people with disabilities, especially because they are very often excluded. Older workers are in favour of upskilling, ensuring their competences are used in the best way possible.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report and the specific reference to the TUC’s Dying to Work Charter. The charter already covers three quarters of a million workers, and has been signed by many leading businesses and organisations such as E.ON, the Royal Mail and the University of Essex, in my region. The campaign is about protecting workers if they get a terminal diagnosis. With the terrible news from the doctor, a person’s world is turned upside down. Some want to stop working, others to carry on, but nobody wants to face the sack. Then there is the question of stressful HR procedures, reduced financial security and loss of death in service payments. The majority of employers want to do the right thing,  not to penalise a worker with incurable cancer, and that is why in the absence of legislation I am urging more companies across the East of England, large and small, to adopt the Dying to Work Charter. If it doesn’t affect you today, it could do tomorrow, so please sign up.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, I want to congratulate my Colleague Žitňanská on the exceptionally high-quality material. This report is not about visions that we should quickly adopt some new European legislation, but it seeks to draw attention to specific possibilities where Member States can make life easier for workers who, after an accident, are trying to get involved in the workflow. I would like to stress here that I believe that the basis is the issue of national law, and we should therefore call on the individual Member States to make their labour law flexible enough to allow a person who wants to work again after illness and is not yet able to work at some stage in the original deployment under the original conditions as he worked before the disease. It is good that this report lists a number of concrete measures, and I think it can be a good guide for individual Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ten years after the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, I believe it is time to take stock of what has been done in terms of the supervision and regulation of the financial system and in the relationship with third countries.  Unfortunately, we have to acknowledge that little or nothing has progressed. It is symptomatic that it was not possible to reach a consensus for the creation of a single resolution fund that is sufficiently endowed and which can, in the end, be credible, match the promises made that taxpayers' money would never be used to recapitalise bankrupt banking and, in relation to supervision, are pseudo rules designed only to make up the balance sheet of banks whose very high leverage ratio remains. There has been no progress on the separation of retail banking from investment banking, shadow banking continues to grow without any kind of regulation.  This proves two things: firstly, that political power remains captured by financial lobbies and the second conclusion is that only public control of banking will allow the financial system to align with the development imperatives of countries.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The cross-border review carried out for the period 2015-2017 has brought some very interesting reflections. First of all, it showed a huge number of active residents who live in so-called border areas. It must also be borne in mind that it is not only a matter of defining these active people, including young people of course, who work in the clean economy sector, but very often it is also a problem of mobility for those who work in creative industries. I am thinking, above all, of the need to take into account the barriers to mobility for artists themselves, especially the youngest generation. They are the ones who have the biggest problems, legal troubles, sometimes financial ones, sometimes concerning these two elements at the same time. I would like to draw attention to this, because this issue has been marginally dealt with in the course of the report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we do not deny the importance of INTERREG and developing cross-border regions, as well as promoting the very permeability of these borders. It is now clear that this debate is somewhat theoretical because anyone looking at these regions of the interior, as they exist in Portugal, will see territories deeply depressed by the restrictive policies of the European Union and, in this sense, we question the Common Agricultural Policy. There were 300,000 farms that disappeared, most of them inside.  What about the austerity policies that have led to the closure of thousands of public services, many of them located inside, and therefore what we will say is that Interreg makes sense but, in order for it to make sense, there must be people in these territories and for people to remain inside, public development policies are needed that break with the fundamental orientations of the European Union and its constraints.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the northern regions of the European Union and the regions really need to be supported, but that means concrete measures. Take, for example, what happened in Greece: together the troika and Mr. Tsipras agreed and we had an increase in value added tax in the Aegean region, and in the North Aegean and the South Aegean, where until recently there was lower VAT, so that it could compete with Turkey, which has 5% VAT. And Mr. Tsipras imposed with the blessings of Mr. Dombrovskis and the rest the increase in value added tax for the islands. What regulation are we talking about and what support for border areas when this happens on the Aegean islands filled with refugees and illegal immigrants? In practice, we need to look at all the measures taken by the European Union to support the regions, so that the border regions can really develop and not be dissolved.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Good report, but I will immediately admit that we have come to it by way of orily. I would like to draw the Commissioner's attention to the unacceptable way in which changes are being prepared for the volunteering of young people. I believe that the lack of a legal basis in the initial phase of the preparation of this report, unfortunately, not only raises doubts, but should mean rejecting it at the initial stage of the process. Fortunately, it happened that the final is good. We have adopted a report with specific new amounts, and I will recall the 20 per cent increase in the fund for volunteering, especially for young people. We have created a new broader program, better addressed. I would remind you, however, that the mode of work on this project meant an annual loss and threatened, in the event of an incorrect decision by the Commission or Parliament itself, that for some time we would not have funded volunteering in any form at all. I remind you of this at the end of the warning.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Solidarity Corps, or now the European Voluntary Solidarity Service, is not only a beautiful idea, but also a programme that is socially, politically, Europeanly important, and practically tested even after the 2017 earthquake in Italy. It is an idea and a program that gives opportunities to volunteer young people, but also professional development. I am therefore pleased that compromises have been found that are involved in the implementation of this programme. It is a pity that there were troubles with it, but all good, which ends well. I hope that this project will continue to work and develop well.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with today's vote in the European Parliament, the European Solidarity Corps is already a fact. I am pleased that we have been able to provide separate funding for the Corps, without prejudice to programmes such as Erasmus+ and to have blending. In this way, we will open up new opportunities for young people across the European Union to join voluntary organisations and feel socially and civicly useful. One of the objectives of the programme is to incentivise countries that do not have legislation regulating the voluntary sector to develop one. Unfortunately, my country Bulgaria during the Bulgarian European Presidency was leading on this dossier and at the same time proposed a bill, but it is not yet a fact. It is high time in Bulgaria to stop just liking Brussels and look at the national interest so that volunteering, which is declining in Bulgaria, can be given a chance so that legislation can be developed and drafted.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last year my delegation opposed, both in committee and in plenary, the establishment of this programme to support structural reforms. However, the text we have voted on today proposes adapting the objective to the increase in the budget. We cannot support it simply because the 80 million increase no longer comes from cohesion policy. Because? Because for structural reforms we have to understand what they are. It is precisely as defined in this regulation that we also mean those relating to the labour market, and therefore to social security, the liberalisation and privatisation of services, not to mention the field of education and training. We are not and will never agree on that. On the other hand, we agree with those reforms, such as the simplification of public procurement legislation or the fight against money laundering, measures that move towards social inclusion and the fight against poverty, such as citizenship income. The European Union must therefore pay attention to the political direction of structural reforms and what it imposes on the Member States. It is true that membership of the programme is optional and voluntary on the part of the Member States. But are you sure that the Member States are all doing as the Italian Government is doing, and are therefore implementing those anti-corruption reforms, for example, such as citizenship income, which go in the direction of the common good, the good of the citizens, and not the lobbies, the strong powers and the private sector?

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr Speaker, today we have given our overwhelming majority of as many as 489 votes to increase the programme to support structural reforms. As a shadow EPP rapporteur, I have worked very this report and I am pleased that it is particularly important that priority should be given to member states outside the eurozone, which we want to help achieve convergence as soon as possible and meet the criteria for joining the eurozone. This makes this structural reform support programme part of our European Solidarity, Cohesion and Convergence Plan across the European Union. Funding increased by 80m euros. It remains a small programme given member states' great need to fund reforms, but it is important to make good priorities.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are against these structural reforms because they are clearly linked to the economic governance of the euro, the European Semester, reform programmes and, of course, recommendations by countries seeking to link these structural reforms to the neoliberal agenda of the European Union and when we talk about structural reforms the Portuguese clearly understand what we are talking about, deregulation of labour laws , privatisation of public services and the social functions of the State and of course we, for the most part, are against this programme to support structural reforms and we also reject an open possibility by this proposal to use the Structural Funds to finance this programme, further weakening cohesion policy.  What Portugal needs are not these structural reforms, what Portugal needs are policies to strengthen and modernize public services and support productive activities. But of course it is necessary to break with the European Union, the euro and its constraints.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Me Too movement has rocked the world of entertainment as well as sport and politics. Indeed, no industry is immune to the perils of sexual harassment. With the 2017 Crime Survey for England finding that 10 000 women are sexually abused each week, it is right that we all challenge the cultures that lead to harassment, abuse and violence, and I am proud that all British Labour MEPs and our staff have received sexual harassment training. Me Too sends a powerful message: no matter your popularity or your power, you will be found out. I also think it is right to tackle everyday sexism. The very first time that I was welcomed into this Chamber by the then President, I was introduced as Herr Mayer, and personally I am sick and tired of the letters and emails I receive that are addressed to Mr Mayer, and of being asked in meetings if I’m saving the seat for my boss. So I welcome this report to promote a culture of equality and respect.

name: President. –
text: We thank you. You should know that there is an ‘F’ here (the chairman points to the list of speakers) which helps me not to fall into the trap.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, no woman in this House will be surprised if I say that I have been harassed and that, like me, 55% of women in the European Union have suffered from it, who have ever been sexually harassed at work, in public spaces or in political life. Sexual violence and harassment have become visible thanks to large feminist mobilizations such as #MeToo or the mass demonstrations of March 8, and we must celebrate that today these feminist demonstrations have been able to reach this House. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is an important milestone in the establishment of measures to prevent and combat sexual and psychological harassment in the workplace, in public spaces and in political life in the European Union. But the most important thing is that the legislation that exists is complied with. I have supported those elements that I consider most relevant in the report, such as considering sexual harassment as a violation of human rights linked to patriarchal power structures; ratification and full implementation of the Istanbul Convention in all Member States; remove obstacles and help women report; tighten sanctions; compulsory training for politicians, etc.  Because we all want to walk without fear on the street, enjoy the same freedom and tranquility as men in the work environment and exercise politics without having to work in a hostile and sexist environment.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Like the rapporteur, I am against sexual harassment and harassment, but I abstained on prevention measures because some of the proposed measures raise serious doubts. I do not agree with the statement that sexual harassment is linked to patriarchy, culture, tradition and religion. Violence is the result of human emotional and developmental immaturity and disrespect for the other person, and the end of all forms of violence depends equally on men and women, who, as parents and educators, are responsible for conveying moral and ethical patterns. In addition, criminal and family codes guarantee the prevention of violence against every citizen. On the other hand, children who are victims of sexualisation in the public sphere should be given special protection and the fight against such sexualisation will be a better investment than many gender equality training. The Commission should also seek a real picture of the problem of sexual harassment, particularly in the context of the great wave of immigration of recent years.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European There is a taboo subject on sexual harassment in a strong context with political correctness, which did not come up in this report. We're always talking about harassment against women, that is, harassment by men against women. I do not want to bring here the harassment of women critically, but the harassment committed by the male perpetrator against a male victim. I find it very interesting that while this is obviously also extremely offensive and painful for the victims – I hear this from art college students, young artists. They have to suffer terrible humiliations from harassing gay men.  It would be great to break this taboo now, to move political correctness a little further, and even if it might hurt certain LGBTI and other interests – to take out this part of the issue of sexual harassment. Thank you!

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 2017 marked the end of the silence of victims of gender-based violence. The most recent scandals have brought the necessary and, more than late, highlight situations in work environments in which people, mostly men, abuse their position of power.
