The European Union's latest effort thus recognises that the 2006 Directive on equal treatment of men and women is not enough to deal with the latest dynamics at stake - namely the evolution of violence in public, virtual spaces, open free, vile and unculpable violence.  This dossier represents a significant step towards improving working conditions for women, but I believe that much remains to be done. Violence against women must be criminalised in all Member States in order to ensure a concerted response mechanism capable of combating one of the major causes of gender inequality.  I believe that zero tolerance has to be given to this kind of behaviour and sanctions have to be applied to the perpetrators. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I finally supported this report because, from my point of view, too, any sexual harassment is unacceptable. At the moment, however, I want to say that I do not think that there is a need to adopt a new directive or a new standard of European law. The report correctly states that we should press the individual Member States to apply the legislation adopted so far. I think that is the main problem that not all Member States are sufficiently applying the existing European legal basis to combat harassment. I agree with that part of the material where soft measures are talked about, about the exchange of information between Member States, about best practices in the fight against sexual violence. These are certainly things where Member States should cooperate much more with each other, communicate much more and thus speak out more effectively against sexual violence.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this report. First of all, the very definition that is contained here shows the extent of the madness to which it proves here. Sexual harassment recognises a situation in which any form of unwanted verbal, non-verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature occurs, the effect of which is to violate the dignity of the person, hostility and so on. Well, the very invaluable, hard-to-capture legal framework of the wording that can be the basis for really human investigation, arguing in the courts about anything, about nonsense. It is not possible to regulate morality by means of laws. This is some kind of thud, this propaganda that is pouring out, such a feminist, radical propaganda about patriarchy, about the fact that this is a form of violence. No, this is not a form of violence. Harassment is not a form of violence, rape is a form of violence – that's the difference. That is why these are two distinct things, what is pouring out of this is really an extremely feminist ideology that is going on in this Parliament, and that is unacceptable.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have noted a great deal of interesting information during the debate. First of all, the number of languages covered by various regulations comes as a surprise to me – 6,000. Yes, in this group we have about 25 percent of languages, which are also written languages. I would like to emphasise two things, firstly, Europe can become a leader in accepting this positive technological linguistic diversity. This is valuable, but on the other hand, by adopting the preservation of languages through the use of technology, it can lead to their actual use. On the other hand, in order to achieve the basic objectives, four more elements are needed, which I have noted – firstly, a decisive improvement in the institutional framework, I stress, is a very important task. Secondly, new research policies need to be developed. Thirdly, the use of education policy to ensure future linguistic equality in the digital age and the latter to increase support for private companies and public authorities in order to improve the use of language technologies.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We all know that people share different boundaries. There are also different barriers between them, but one of the biggest barriers is the language barrier. It hinders people's contacts, relationships, understanding, and eventually cooperation. This therefore has an impact on political, private, public, social and economic relations. Diversity in unity, that is the great strength of the European Union, is worth highlighting this year too. On the one hand, we should protect, treat all languages equally, not only national, but also regional, local or buzzing, but on the other hand, it is in the 21st century that we should use new techniques and technologies to facilitate people's communication and relationships precisely through new technology.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, linguistic equality in the digital age is a very important thing and it should be really spread and strengthened by languages that are not spoken by many of our fellow citizens. But I want to come to the European Union itself. You know that the Eurogroup takes the toughest decisions for all the Peoples of Europe and these decisions, Mr President, are only adopted in English. There is no translation into other languages. Is the Eurogroup's decision imposing a memorandum on Greece until 2060, issued on 21 June 2018, translated into any language? No, it is only in English and Greek citizens are invited to implement this decision. It's unacceptable what's going on. Also, recently in the Committee on Economic Affairs of the European Parliament, I was told that they do not take into account my amendments because I submit them in Greek and they wanted me to deposit them in English and they rejected them! Let the Republic apply the European Parliament here in the Chamber, within its institutions, to give equal access to all languages!

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have given my support to the report on linguistic equality in the digital age because I believe that it finally puts on the agenda the topic of inequalities and in terms of languages. While promoting linguistic diversity is one of the European Union's priorities, there is a great abyss between widely used and less used languages. This abyss is even more visible in the age of digitization. As you can see, here my colleagues from different political groups agree – whether our native language is Bulgarian or English predetermines what information we have access to. It is true that the English language has a dominant role. However, there are Member States such as my home country Bulgaria, where less than 20% of people speak English. These same people do not have equal access, for example, to information on the opportunities provided by European programmes. What equal opportunities are we talking about then? I hope that the European Parliament resolution will be an important step in overcoming this very discrimination.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I abstained in the final vote on this report because I believe that some aspects for transparent and responsible management of the natural resources of developing countries have not been properly taken care of here. However, I voted in favour of the specialty, i.e. article by article, because the problem of deforestation has a global environmental impact and is now responsible for 11 % of greenhouse gas emissions. I therefore believe that the European Union has a fundamental role in establishing trade rules so that it is not conniving with environmental barbarism committed in the name of business. Unfortunately, the unruly commercial exploitation of the forest has had harmful consequences both on biodiversity and in the lack of fire protection in monoculture reforested areas. I worry that poor forest management and poor implementation of global legislation will leave this resource vulnerable to corruption, fraud and organised regime.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Judith Sargentini. on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on a proposal inviting the Council to establish, in accordance with Article 7(1) of the Treaty on European Union, that there is a clear risk of Hungary seriously violating the values on which the Union is founded (2017/2131(INL) (A8-0250/2018).

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I didn’t see this coming. I thought we had company. But, as my report is targeted to the Council as a whole, I’ll just get started. Colleagues, today we are debating the state of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in Hungary. Tomorrow, President Juncker will present his State of the Union. I want to ask you colleagues today: what is the state of our Union? What shape are we in? Mr President, I think I should stop now and start again because I don’t think this is a good start to the debate. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Well, the Hungarian Prime Minister, Mr Orbán, is here. You can continue, Mr President. Sargentini, since he's just getting started.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start again and let me welcome Prime Minister Orbán, who I wanted to shake hands with, but he turned up late for the debate. (Murmurs of disapproval) Today, we are debating the state of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in Hungary. Tomorrow, President Juncker will present his State of the Union, and I asked you before – I ask you now again, colleagues – today, what is the state of our Union? What shape are we in? Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union reads: ‘the Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to a minority’. It continues: ‘these values are common to the Member States in a society in which pluralism, non—discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail’. By signing up to the Treaty on European Union, all the Member States made a commitment – an obligation to defend, respect and promote these values, regardless of political differences.  Are all the Member States fulfilling these commitments? I’m afraid not. The Hungarian Government has effectively silenced independent media. It has put academia on a leash, and future generations will not learn to appreciate critical thinking. It has replaced independent judges with those with a closer tie to the regime. It has rules on which churches are allowed to worship and which churches are not. It makes life miserable for NGOs that provide services to citizens in need, such as homeless people, migrants and refugees and marginalised groups like Roma. These are services that – to add insult to injury – lighten the work of local governments and are often financed through European Union funding. On top of that, individuals in the government have enriched themselves, their family members and their friends by means of public funding from European taxpayers’ money.  The report that is before you today comprehensively lists the actions that, together, represent a clear risk of a serious breach of the values of our Union. Unfortunately, nothing has improved since this report was voted on in June. On the contrary, this summer, one of the last independent news channels changed ownership and, from one day to another, became the mouthpiece of the government. The propaganda tax on NGOs got through Parliament, and whether the Central European University can continue to function in Budapest is still a big question. Since 2010, the European Parliament has been urging the Commission and the Member States to act. They did not do so. And it’s particularly disappointing that the Member States turned a blind eye to the structural erosion of the rule of law in a fellow Member State. It is not the Commission alone that is the so—called ‘guardian of the Treaties’. We are all the guardians of the Treaties. (Applause) We all have the task of protecting the rights of European citizens to live today in a society, as Article 2 reads, ‘in which pluralism, non—discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail’. It is therefore our duty to act, under the very same Treaty that Hungary decided to ratify. The Civil Liberties Committee, after consulting four committees of this House, concluded that an Article 7.1 procedure is inevitable. I do not think lightly about triggering that Article, but if this House fails to use this emergency brake, we fail to deliver to European citizens what was promised to them in the Treaty.  Colleagues, the time has come to make an important choice. Will you let a government violate the values upon which this Union was built without consequences, or will you ensure that the values of this Union are more than just words written on a piece of paper? Colleagues, I count on your support. (Applause)

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Mr President, Prime Minister, Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work. Twice budgetary control has been on the ground in Hungary, and we have seen a tendency towards the worse in the management of EU funds. And since the elections, the situation has worsened. We see problems such as corruption, conflicts of interest and clientele economy, and a lack of investigation and intelligence. In concrete terms, we are dealing with sham legal systems in tenders: in more than one third of the procedures, only one company participates. And it is no consolation that things are even worse in Member States such as Poland. In the case of calls for tenders, your confidants, Prime Minister, are given special consideration, undermining procedures that undermine equal opportunities and prevent the development of a diversified economy. The comparison of the Visegrad states – all big borrowers from the EU budget – shows that Hungary makes the least of the money and also performs poorly when comparing government. We see features of a state-run economy. That is why the Committee on Budgetary Control recommended the Article 7 procedure without voting against. (Applause)

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, I would like to thank the I made it very clear in the opinion of the Committee on Culture that freedom of teaching and research, freedom of the media and the situation of civil society organisations in Hungary are poor. Perhaps the most well-known example to us is the attack on the Central European University: a private war is being waged here on the back of freedom of teaching and research.  Since the adoption of my opinion in committee, the situation has deteriorated further. The Hungarian Government is continuing its efforts to further depact the academic freedom and autonomy of its universities. In a latest attack, the government is once again attacking the most vulnerable in society and those who want to help them. It penalises all organisations that run programmes for the education and integration of migrants, including programmes financed with EU funds. A series of open and hidden measures further eroded media freedom. In doing so, the government is laying the axe to the foundations of our pluralistic society.  That is why the Committee on Culture is also calling for the opening of article 7 proceedings. We can no longer accept that the government in Hungary willfully and permanently tramples on European fundamental rights. That is why we must now send out a clear signal that fundamental rights are non-negotiable for the European Parliament.  (Applause)

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, I was rapporteur for one of the views in the reporting procedure on the situation in Hungary which was adopted with broad consensus, Mr Orbán. Some said we fed their victimism, but closing our eyes fuels the degradation of the values that make the European Union possible. In 2011, the Venice Commission already expressed concern about legislative reforms in Hungary that threaten the rule of law understood as a democracy with separation of powers and independent justice. This year's elections were held in a hostile and intimidating atmosphere, according to the OSCE. The basic values of the European Union protect citizens from the arbitrariness of state power. Hungary has been a member of the European Union since 2004. When he joined it was a collective effort of Hungarians of different beliefs, realities and backgrounds. His government is knowingly turning its back on state neutrality. Freedom of conscience, freedom of worship, the right to disagree is something we learned in Europe painfully last century, Mr Orbán. From respect, from admiration for your country, I believe that the application of Article 7 should be approved.  (Applause)

name: Maria Noichl
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Orban, I would like to thank the commissioner for his We women in Europe are watching very closely, we are looking beyond borders and we are seeing your policy and we are seeing you. Some say you are democratic and strong. No, we don't see that! A democratic and strong prime minister protects women against family violence and in marital marriage. A democratic prime minister does not protect the perpetrators, but women. They don't! A democratic prime minister signs the Istanbul Convention. A democratic prime minister does not allow free teaching to be restricted at universities. A Democratic prime minister is committed to education, from kindergarten to university, without stereotypes, without narrowing. A democratic Prime Minister is fully committed to fundamental European rights and women's rights. Real strength, Mr Orban, real strength is no longer the old male shirt sleeve. Real strength is the inner strength to be able to live with women on an equal footing, to be able to work, to love women on an equal footing. Women's rights are non-negotiable here in Europe! (Applause from the left and cries of disapproval on the right.)

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure you that the Presidency and the Council as a whole attach the greatest importance to upholding democracy, the rule of law and human rights. There can be no compromises on the rule of law, democracy and human rights. These are our common rules, and they have to be protected. At the Council we will have the opportunity to discuss these fundamental issues at the rule of law dialogue on trust in public institutions, to be held at the General Affairs Council in October. According to Article 7, the procedure can be triggered by one third of Member States, by the European Parliament, or by the European Commission. Subsequently the Council examines the proposal and hears the Member States in question. Today, we are at the beginning of the debate in this plenary and a vote in the European Parliament. The Council has not yet considered these matters. Therefore, the Presidency is not in a position to present a position of the Council. We will listen attentively to the debate, and to the Prime Minister of Hungary.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, fortunately, the Commission is in a position to give its position on this issue and I want to start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Sargentini, for her engagement in preparing this report.  The report covers a wide range of measures in different areas taken by the Hungarian authorities over the last few years which give rise to serious concerns from the perspective of our common EU values. In this context, let me stress that democracy in our Member States, in our European Union, cannot exist without the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. They go together. These values characterise a society in which individual freedom, pluralism, non-discrimination and tolerance prevail. Sadly, the Commission shares the concerns expressed in the report, in particular, the concerns regarding fundamental rights, corruption, the treatment of Roma, and the independence of the judiciary. As regards fundamental rights, the report highlights important issues relating to civil society, academic freedom and media pluralism, which are crucial for the good functioning of democracy. Civil society is the very fabric of democratic societies and is threatened by measures taken by the Hungarian authorities that lead to a shrinking space for civil society organisations. As a consequence, the Commission has referred Hungary to the Court of Justice regarding its law on foreign-funded NGOs and has launched an infringement procedure on the Hungarian legislation criminalising assistance for asylum seekers. Moreover, the Commission is analysing the compatibility with EU law of Hungary’s recent law on the special tax on education, training and media campaign activities in the area of migration.  The Commission has also referred Hungary to the Court of Justice regarding the Hungarian higher education law for non-compliance with EU law, including academic freedom.  As regards the treatment of asylum seekers, the Commission has referred Hungary to the Court of Justice for non-compliance with EU law regarding its asylum and return legislation. Let me also stress that EU legislation provides that Member States have to ensure that the basic needs of persons in transit zones are covered and that they are treated in a humane and dignified manner. This includes providing food to asylum seekers staying in border zones. I would say that this is the humane – or, should I say, the Christian – way of doing things. (Applause) The Commission shows zero tolerance towards fraud against the EU budget and carries out regular audits to assess the functioning of the national management and control system, based on regularly updated risk management. If deficiencies are identified, adequate corrective actions are carried out. Through the supervisory role of the Commission, Hungarian operational programmes for EU structural and investment funds have been the subject of the highest amount of financial corrections in 2016 and 2017 of all the EU Member States. Moreover, the European Anti-Fraud Office has opened investigations where there was sufficient suspicion of fraud and other irregularities. On 13 July, following up on a proposal from the Commission, the Council issued Hungary with country—specific recommendations, stating that it should reinforce its anti-corruption framework to strengthen prosecutorial efforts and improve transparency and competition in public procurement. These recommendations are based on the 2018 European Semester country report for Hungary, where the Commission identified challenges related to the effectiveness of its national anti-corruption framework in preventing corruption, curbing favouritism in public administration, transparency and its access to information regime, and the prioritisation of fighting high-level corruption via effective investigations and prosecutions. The Commission will monitor and assess any measures taken by the Hungarian authorities to address these recommendations. The Commission launched infringement proceedings against Hungary in May 2016 for discrimination against Roma children on the grounds of their ethnic origin in the field of education. Hungary entered into a constructive dialogue with the Commission and has subsequently adopted legislative amendments to prevent segregation and to desegregate. Challenges concerning the functioning and independence of the judicial system in Hungary also require close monitoring. In particular, as raised in a 2018 European Semester country report, more could be done to better balance the powers between the President of the National Office for the Judiciary and the National Judicial Council. The Commission is also the guardian of the Treaties, I say to Parliament. When it comes to the application of EU law and the respect of the EU’s fundamental values, the Commission intervenes based on accurate and thorough legal analysis, it focuses on concrete national measures and it engages in a dialogue with the authorities. The Commission is using all the instruments at its disposal to address concerns, in the manner the Commission considers most effective. Let me remind you: it was the Commission which invoked the Article 7 procedure as regards a clear risk of a serious breach of the rule of law by Poland on 20 December 2017. This was an unprecedented step in the history of our European Union.  Unlike the European Parliament, the Commission has a right under the Treaty on European Union to launch infringement procedures and, in the case of Hungary, has launched many value-related infringement proceedings. It is also using other instruments, including audits and investigations relating to the use of EU funds and actions through the European Semester, the EU annual cycle of economic policy coordination.  The Commission remains committed to upholding the fundamental values of the Union and will continue to closely monitor the situation in Hungary in this regard. The Commission will not hesitate to take further action if necessary. My promise to you is that we will be relentless. (Applause)

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Hungary PM. - Mr President, Honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your support. I know that you have already taken your position. I know that the report will be voted on by your majority. I also know that your opinion will not be changed by my post. Yet I have come to you, because you will be condemning not a government, but a country and a people. A Hungary that has been a member of the family of Christian European peoples for a thousand years will be condemned. A Hungary that contributed to the history of our great Europe with its work and, if need be, with its blood. They will condemn a Hungary that rebelled and took up arms against the world's largest army, the Soviets, and made a heavy blood sacrifice for freedom and democracy and opened its borders to its fellow East Germans when it was needed. Hungary fought for his freedom and democracy. I stand here now and see that hungary is being accused by those who inherited democracy, who did not have to take personal risks for freedom. And now they want to condemn the Hungarian freedom fighters of the anti-communist, democratic resistance. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for I stand here and defend my country because, for Hungarians, freedom and democracy, independence and Europe are issues of honour. That is why I say that the report before you is an Hungary, a violation of the honour of the Hungarian people. Hungary decisions are made by the electorate in parliamentary elections. You say nothing less than that the Hungarian people are not reliable enough to judge what is in their interest. You think you know better what the Hungarian people need than the Hungarian people themselves. I must therefore say that the report does not give respect to the Hungarian people. This report applies double standards, abuses power, overskras powers, and the way in which it is adopted violates the Treaty.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for For us in Hungary, democracy and freedom are not political issues, but moral issues. You now want to make a moral judgment based on a numeral majority and stigmatise a country and a people. You take on a heavy responsibility when, for the first time in the history of the European Union, you want to take a people out of European decisions. You would deprive Hungary of the right to represent its own interests in the European family to which it belongs. We have, and we will have, debates. We think differently about the Christian nature of Europe, the role of nations and national cultures, we have different understandings of the essence and vocation of the family, and we have diametrically opposed views on migration.  If we really want unity in diversity, then differences should not give rise to the stigmatisation of any country and the possibility of a joint decision. We would never be att to silence those who disagree with us. Dear Mr President,  They want to exclude a country that has also taken clear decisions in the European elections. We got a 56 percent majority in 2009 and a 52 percent majority in 2014. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, We are the most successful party in the European Parliament. Our socialist and liberal opponents are understandably not happy with our success, but to avenge the Hungarians for not chose them is not fair, and it is not European. Moreover, this report has been written by people who are not even aware of the basic facts. The report admits that you have failed to send a formal delegation to Hungary, so you will decide without proper fact-finding. The report contains 37 serious factual errors. Yesterday, all Members received a 108-page document on this. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Our union is held together to settle disputes within a regulated framework. Hungary, I myself have concluded agreements and compromises with the Commission on the media law, on the judicial system and even on certain passages of our Constitution. This report breakes the agreements that were concluded years ago. But if you can do that and break it, what's the point of getting an agreement with any European institution? What you are doing is a blow to the Union and to constructive dialogue.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Every nation and Member State has the right to decide how to settle their own life in their own country. We will defend our borders, and only we will decide who we live with. We built a fence and stopped hundreds of thousands of illegal migrants. We defended Hungary and we defended Europe. Today's incident is the first in the history of the European Union where a community condemns its own border guards. Dear Mr President, Let's talk straight. They want to condemn Hungary because the Hungarian people have decided that our country will not be an immigrant country. With due respect, but in the strongest possible way, I reject the fact that the pro-immigration and pro-migrant forces of the European Parliament hungary and the Hungarian people on the basis of false accusations. I respectfully inform you, whatever decision you make, Hungary t give in to blackmail. Hungary will protect its borders, stop illegal migration and protect its rights, if necessary, against you. We Hungarians are ready for elections in May next year, where people can finally decide the future of Europe and bring democracy back into European politics. Thank you for your attention.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, this is the first time the European Parliament has discussed an Article 7(1) procedure against a country. An important decision lies ahead of us and, yes, we feel a need for self-assurance, when we have this discussion ahead of us, about the European way of life. Let me share with you some of my concerns and, after the Prime Minister’s intervention, let’s bring it back to what is really of substance on the table: what we are discussing today. We are discussing, for example, something which has a lot to do with freedom. In May this year my Group honoured Lech Wałęsa, a member of the PPE family who is still actively campaigning in Poland in favour of our Civic Platform colleagues, and he spoke about his life. He spoke about the essence of what Europe believes in: about freedom, about freedom of expression, media freedom and freedom of science. With his words in mind, my Group and I cannot understand why the Central European University in Budapest is in a critical situation and can no longer award a US diploma. Freedom of science is a fundamental value for the European Union. (Applause) A second point I want to mention is the fact that, in a democracy, a majority in society governs. That’s clear but, for us, in a properly functioning state a lively civil society is also important. I want transparency about the funding sources for NGOs, I want to know who the internet giants in Russia are who are financing bodies in the European Union. But to have an atmosphere in a society in which government critics and NGOs have a problem in continuing their work is not what we, as the PPE Group, believe in. (Applause) There is a third point I want to mention. We may have different ideas on solving the migration issue, but one thing must be clear: if we say generally that you need to be afraid about Muslims, and we attack a religion generally, then we are doing the job of the jihadists who want to create a clash within our societies. The European ideals of freedom of religion and the separation between states and churches are the principles on which we invented human rights – not Christian rights – on this continent. (Applause) And now about Article 7(1). The PPE Group has always supported the debates here in the House with regard to Hungary. We worked constructively with Roberta Metsola in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the preparation of the document which is on the table. We have consistently supported Viviane Reding in previous times and Frans Timmermans today in relation to infringement procedures. And I have to say that, in the past, Hungary was always ready to compromise. I must tell you that Fidesz was even ready to change the constitution of the country to take account of some of the considerations of Viviane Reding’s Commission and to address them in the constitution of Hungary. My political family will finally decide this evening about our voting list for tomorrow, but I have to tell everybody that without a readiness on the part of the Hungarian Government to resolve the current issues – the legal concerns which are on the table – the start of a dialogue based on Article 7(1) could be necessary. As we are talking about dialogue, I want to underline that it is my wish that the dialogue in Council could start. Council members are publicly attacking each other, they are defining each other as political opponents but, as yet, in the European Council, the Article 7 procedure in respect of Poland has not reached reach the level of our political leaders. So what I would ask for is an end to public accusations among our political leaders. Let them put this on the agenda of the next Council and be honest with each other. I would expect this from the Council. (Applause) And we all must decide: that’s clear. We all must decide between egoism and partnership, between nationalism and Europe, between dogmatism and unity. These are at stake and there is a broader picture ahead of us. For myself, I must say I never had the need to decide because I was always a convinced European and it is also in my DNA that I want to be a bridge-builder. I want to try to achieve a compromise, I want to reach an agreement: that is part of my political DNA. And, with this in mind, I want to add a last point to the current discussion on the table. It’s about the party political dimension. We have been talking about media freedom, and journalists in Bratislava have told me that, since the killing of Ján Kuciak, a lot of colleagues are cautious about their articles. They don’t want to be the next. And, colleagues, demonstrators in Bratislava have showed their concerns on the streets, they have no trust in their Government. So I hope that, among the pro-European democratic parties, we can be united in the upcoming discussion in this House, in fighting for media freedom in all regards and not only when it concerns one country or one discussion. (Applause)  There is a second example I want to share with you. We had mass demonstrations this summer not in Budapest but in Bucharest, with violence on the streets. The President needed to intervene in these demonstrations and had to ask the police to be more careful. There is a Government misusing a majority to protect the already-sentenced Socialist Party leader. We all agreed, including the Socialists, to put this on the agenda in the next plenary, and again I hope that everybody is ready to fight against corruption in all regards and not only in one specific case that is on the table. (Applause) Yes, Europe needs self-assurance and we have to defend our ideas and our common values, in all our political families, and we have to use the platform of the political families to convince each other that we have a future only if we stick together. In this spirit, the founding fathers of Europe created the European Union: always to reach out the hand; to build bridges at critical moments; and to stick to the rule of law in every situation. (Applause)

name: Udo Bullmann
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Defending the freedom of European citizens is the most important duty of this House, regardless of which colour which government belongs to. My group will therefore use this situation today to go into the details and have all the other discussions with you that have to be had. I would simply like to say that I am pleased that the Austrian Presidency of the Council has still managed – because there were rumours in the meantime that they would not be able to attend today. That is always a good thing, because it not only brings us into the conversation, but also gives us the opportunity to approach the facts. That is what we should be doing. There is a massive irritation on my side when I listen to the Prime Minister of Hungary, Mr Orban, because he did not understand what is at stake here. This debate is taking place because this House is defending the freedoms of the citizens of Hungary, because they are in the middle of the European Union, and not because we are attacking the people of Hungary. On the contrary, we need to talk to you about why their rights are constantly being violated. Yes, I would be pleased – you mentioned this example, then just take it away from a German Social Democrat – I would be pleased if we had personalities here of the figure of a Gyula Horn and an Alois Mock, who at that time tore down the Iron Curtain so that the people of East Germany could go to freedom.  (Applause) But that's not the discourse you're going to have. The Austrian Presidency knows nothing, and the Hungarian Prime Minister has never had a problem. That is why this discussion does not continue. I do not want us to simply watch the decline of European values without doing anything about it. You know very well, Mr Orban, that we have been having constant discussions with you since 2010. 2011, 2012, 2013, 2015, 2017 – we have constantly tried to engage in a constructive dialogue with you. It didn't work. Let us be clear: you now stand for the most corrupt system that exists within the European Union. We regret that, but it is. Why is there more... (Interjections) If you are capable of reading, read OLAF's report. That is precisely why there is only one tenderer left in more than 30% of the tenders, that Mr Orban's relatives play a special role in this, that his son-in-law benefits particularly from this system. I would like to repeat it: Mr Orban, you personally stand for the most corrupt system that currently exists in the European Union, and that must stop, ladies and gentlemen. (Applause) We believe that freedom of the press and freedom of expression must not be further suppressed in your country. We want Hungary to return to the path of European values. I can only appeal to the Members of the European People's Party – I hear that there will be a debate this evening on the voting list – that you choose Europe and not the corrupt system of Mr Orban. We have now heard three representatives of the European People's Party, Mr Orban, we have heard the Council representative from the European People's Party, and we have heard Mr Weber, whom I personally accept, to stand up for European values. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, you must decide on the relevant vote on the resolution. That is what I would ask from the heart, and that is how we will handle it. (Applause)

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I have a feeling that there is an overpowering tediousness in a debate like this one. It has been rehearsed so many times. Nothing new. Another instalment of an attack on their democratically elected governments. The Fidesz government has had massive support for the last decade. You said it is not an attack on Hungarian society, but on the Hungarian Government. Well, somebody elected this government. It was not Snow White and the seven dwarves. If you do not like it, just abolish the election and appoint somebody from outside to be the viceroy of Hungary. I think Mr Timmermans will be more than willing to take the job. And after that you do that, do the same with Poland. That will solve all the problems. The resolution that you have read – at least some of you must have read it – is so biased. To say it is biased is an understatement. It is exclusively based on the information from anti-Fidesz groups, and the argument of the majority of the Hungarians on the government has been simply ignored, and this is a regular practice here. This has been done in the case of Poland too. The replies of the government had been thrown into the wastebasket. They are just not taken into account. Take the case of the Central European University. This school was established as a foreign institution with certain privileges, and the government wants to restrict these privileges. What’s wrong with that? It has nothing to do with teaching, research, academic freedom or freedom of thought. In many EU countries the function of foreign academic institutions is very restricted, far more restricted than the current Hungarian law provides. Why is it that you tolerate certain arrangements and certain practices in your own countries and you demand that the Hungarians change their law? This is absolutely unacceptable. The good side of this is that all this entire spectacle is counter-productive. In my country after each spectacle – I cannot say ‘debate’ – of Poland-bashing in the European Parliament, the support for my government conspicuously increases. So I suspect the same will happen in Hungary. So, Prime Minister Orbán, it may very well be that the authors of this resolution are your unwitting or perhaps clandestine supporters.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, you and Mr Orbán can be reassured that I will not go so far as the late John McCain, who on the floor of the American Senate called Mr Orbán ‘a neo—fascist in bed with Putin’. Those are not my words; they have been said before. Also, I will not come back to all the violations that have been put in this report. Let’s be honest between each other, the inconvenient truth is that, under these circumstances, it would be impossible today, Mr Orbán, for Hungary to join the European Union. That is the reality of today. (Applause) What I would really ask you to do – because I like Hungary and I certainly like Hungarian literature and culture – is anyway to stop saying ‘Oh, that’s an action against Hungary, an action against the Hungarian people’. You are not Hungary, you’re the government of Hungary and the leader of a political party and Hungary is far more and far more eternal than you are. (Applause) My intervention is not to you, it is especially to our EPP colleagues, and I have one plea, which is that hopefully this evening they will follow their conscience when they decide on this. I know that’s not always easy to do. We are talking about somebody of the family, and I can tell you that I had the same problem at a certain moment. That was the moment when we had the dilemma to push out of our family Jörg Haider of the FPÖ. We did it in the end, also based on counsel, because we thought that more important than size and power are in fact principles and values.  The second reason is for European reasons, Manfred. What we are living today is the survival and existential battle over the survival of the European project. If Mr Orbán is publicly siding with Salvini, openly discussing the disruption of this European project, well, we need that not to happen in the coming years. My last argument and reason is mainly because, and I will recognise it – that doesn’t happen often – that the European Union has been based on Christian democratic principles, beliefs and energy for decades. We all know them: Adenauer, Schuman, Monnet, De Gasperi. I want to use the words of one of these giants, of Robert Schuman, and I will quote him: ‘Christianity teaches us equality of all men without distinction between race, colour, class or profession [...] the dignity of each human person in protection of his individual liberty and with respect for his individual rights by practicing brotherly love to all’.  So I want to plead to you, my Christian Democratic colleagues, to recognise that the way Schuman looked at Christianity is in many ways exactly the opposite to the divisive, narrow and destructive actions and opinions of Mr Orbán. Dear colleagues, please for once see that he is the seed of discord that will ultimately destroy our beautiful European project and please, together with us, stop this nightmare this evening in your Group.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and respect for human rights, including the rights of people belonging to minorities. These values are common to Member States in a society characterized by pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men. This, ladies and gentlemen, is what Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union says, which, before being a major market, is a union of values. Values which, on the basis of our Parliament's factual report, are called into question by the action of the Hungarian government. No, Prime Minister, this is not about Hungary, it is not about the Hungarian people, it is about the actions of the Hungarian government, and I know many Hungarians who do not find themselves in your action. In a democracy, holding a majority does not automatically legitimize any action. No, Mr Orbon, neither the nepotism and the abuse of European funds, nor the violations of academic and religious freedoms, nor the asphyxiation of the media and NGOs, nor the implementation of the judiciary are compatible with European values. I would add, addressing the defender of the Christian values you claim to be, that refusing to feed failed asylum seekers seems to me to be totally contradictory to the gospel message. It is not enough to say that the Sargentini report is a web of lies to erase its reality. The reality is that if your country were now a candidate for EU membership, as Guy Verhofstadt said, it could not be admitted without fundamental changes in its structures and legislation. Like others before you, Prime Minister, you have repeatedly compared the European Union to the defunct Soviet Union. Such an analogy is scandalous, because it is free that Hungary has decided to join the European Union and, as far as I know, the tanks of the European Union have never invaded the capital of a country to ensure that it remains in the European Union. But make no mistake: for us, Hungary's place is at the heart of Europe, and in Europe there is no second-tier Member State. But if belonging to the Union creates rights and benefits, they come with responsibilities and obligations. The launch of the Article 7 procedure is aimed at one thing: to ensure compliance with these obligations. To our epp colleagues I want to solemnly say this: you count in your ranks The Fidesz, the party of Mr Orbon. For a long time, he was considered a bit like the black sheep of the family. Today, he claims to set the course! By adopting a language, posture and policies that make it the whooping cough - and we check it here at every moment - of the European and even American extreme right-wingers. How can you say that no red line has yet been crossed? But where are your limits? Are you going to abandon your humanist values to campaign on the themes of the extreme right, to make a common list with it, to govern with it or simply to implement its agenda? In a document adopted in 2015 by the EPP Congress, I read a resolution entitled 'Protecting the Union and Promoting Our Values'. You were defending, and I quote, "liberal democracy, based on the rule of law and a multi-party system, a strong civil society, freedom of expression and association" and I conclude, ladies and gentlemen, the vote on Judith Sargentini's report gives you a unique opportunity, my colleagues in the EPP, to join the words with a strong gesture. Having heard Manfred Weber, I would like to think that many of you will make this gesture.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, according to the Hungarian press, those who vote for Mrs Sargentini's report would be sold to Mr Soros. So, Prime Minister, I will make an admission: here, on these benches, the billionaire Soros is really not our cup of tea. I invite those who want to avoid caricature and who believe that the rule of law still makes sense in a democracy to read Mrs Sargentini's report, just to read it. It is based on the views of the Council of Europe, including the Venice Commission, and the United Nations.  No, it is not a question of condemning the Hungarian people, nor Hungary, just to respect the european Union's accession criteria in this area, accepted at the time by the Hungarian government and prepared by your government, Mr Orbon, when you were Prime Minister, from 1998 to 2002. But at the time, you were a liberal. For you today, freedom is no longer a central element of the organization of the state and democracy is reduced to a political majority that applies its choices, the strong against the weak. So yes, in Hungary, there is a regression of rights for justice, for the press, for education, for asylum, for NGOs. But for the economy, there is unlimited liberalism, and even European funds are diverted to the profits of your loved ones. You're an authoritarian neoliberal. It is the freedoms and democracy that you are bringing down, and it is not surprising that you are trying to ally yourself with Mr. Salvini. Your illiberalism makes the bed of the worst nationalism, xenophobia and therefore of the extreme right, and just look here who, today, is applauding you. Yes, thank you, whistle me, it suits me. So everyone will take responsibility tomorrow and we'll see who's who.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Orbán: thank God, there is at least one European leader prepared to stand up for his principles, his nation, his culture and his people. In the face of such extreme bullying, ‘thank God you’re there’ is all I can say. I am sure that for Hungarians of a certain age today will have brought back many dark memories. You’re here with a show trial where a bunch of political non-entities get up and point the finger and scream, enjoying themselves with their afternoon hate, and the chief prosecutor, the commissar that comes from the unelected government, has the audacity to lecture you on democracy. You don’t know what you’re talking about. The fact that you’ve got 50% of the vote in your country and that no one has ever voted for Timmermans or can’t remove him seems to have passed him by. He’s also telling you ‘you’re not getting your judicial appointments right, you’ve got to change things’. This is the man who is one of the bosses of the European Commission that appoints Martin Selmayr, driving a coach and horses through all the rules that exist here. What is really happening here, Mr Orbán, is that they are just updating the Brezhnev doctrine of limited sovereignty. There’s no point pretending in this union that you’re independent, there’s no point pretending you run your own country. And Article 7 is the new method of adopting that. They want to strip you of your voting rights, they want to stop giving you European funding, and all of it because you have the audacity to stand up to George Soros, the man who has poured USD 15 billion all over the world in trying to break down the nation states and to get rid of our traditional forms of democracy. In Hungary he spent money to promote illegal immigration into your country and you, quite rightly, have stood up to him and closed him down. I wish we all did the same. Mr Orbán, you keep saying you want to stay a member of this European Union, but it is not just your country that has been insulted today. You’ve been insulted today. It is time to be more logical. Come and join the Brexit club. You’ll love it.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Prime Minister, Mrs Sargentini claims that your government is refusing dialogue. Yet, in addition to your permanent representative, you have twice sent your Minister of Foreign Affairs for public hearings before the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Ms Sargentini claims that you despise this Parliament, but this is already the third time that you have come to respond to the constant attacks on your government. In reality, it is not a report, but an indictment, that of a witchcraft trial heard exclusively on the charge. In particular, he accuses you of not respecting the independence of the judiciary, but at the same time he allows himself to criticize decisions made by Hungarian judges and gives his opinion on instructions that are being carried out. The Sargentini report also criticises your electoral system. However, the latter allows all opinions to be proportionally represented, while in France, for example, a party that has won between 15 and 25% of the vote over the past 20 years has the right to only a few crumbs: seven out of 577 MPs. Whereas unelected bureaucrats - isn't it, Mr. Timmermans? - confiscate democracy and impose on peoples the migratory submersion, your government is the only one to have consulted its citizens on how to solve this existential crisis of a magnitude - it must be said - unprecedented. We are being re-referred to with the so-called 'values of the European Union'. Those of a so-called open society where we advocate multiculturalism against our traditions, against our identities, against the Christian roots of our civilization. In the face of these deadly ideologies, you, Prime Minister, are a true defender of our values of civilization, against communism yesterday, against globalism today. One wonders if today your worst opponents are not in the ranks of the EPP. Yesterday, Mr Weber declared in the newspaper Le Monde that he supported Commissioner Timmermans against Hungary, before adding that he felt very close to his Social Democrat and Liberal friends. Prime Minister, just a few months before the European elections against Merkel and Macron who want more immigration and ever more federalism, you embody, with Matteo Salvini, the spearheads of another Europe, the Europe we want, the Europe we love, the Europe of nations, that of cooperation, that of protections, and, of course, that of freedoms.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Dear Mr President, Thank you very much. Today is a special day because we have heard two European Union prime ministers and two sharply different values are straining each other. These will have to be chosen, practically between these two values, for European citizens in May 2019. It was the Greek Prime Minister Cipras, who once saw better days, was here this morning, who, of course, was brought to his knees by the European Union and the majority of those present, who, to the great delight of the Union, wanted to hear what had happened in his country: the reception of mass migration, the construction of mosques, the licensing of same-sex marriage, and, last but not least, the privatisation of national treasures, the enrichment of foreign banks.  We Hungarians sent the International Monetary Fund home, prevented migration, said no to mass migration, defended our own borders, defended Europe's borders, protected and defended Christian European roots and values. Once again, in May 2019, there will be a choice as to which values Europe wants. Thank you very much!

name: József Szájer (PPE).
text: – Dear Mr President, Dear Prime Minister and Mrs Vergiat, We have just heard your speech, in which you mentioned who applauds whom. You're a communist. Your comrades have ruined my country. Do you have the skin on your face to lecture us on democracy and the rule of law? According to the report, Hungary a threat to the rule of law. That's a lie. This is true of those who criticise Hungary, Judith Sargentini, the left and the LIBE Committee. Because what is the rule of law, honourable Members? The rule of law is when it is not the self-love of individual people, not of individual groups, but of the law.  Firstly, Parliament is empowered by the Treaty of the Union to act on the basis of Community legislation. In point C, the report acknowledges that it has not found enough cases under Community law against Hungary and therefore examines issues which are not covered by the Treaty. For the most part, the report lists such matters with exclusive national competence. Spreading beyond the law of the Union is arbitrary, contrary to the Treaty, contrary to the rule of law. Secondly, since Roman law, the rule of law also means that the accused is given a fair opportunity to defend. In this hours-long debate, Hungary can only speak for five minutes. It's not a rule of law, it's a thousand-year-old rule of law. Shame! Are you afraid of words? Thirdly, in a rule of law, it would not be possible to roll out the treaty's special guarantee voting rules at their convenience, so as not to count abstentions as votes cast in order to achieve a better result for them. Those who do not even follow their own rules are the ones who are constantly talking about the wrongs of the rule of law and democracy, who teach Hungary.  They are doing this to avenge the Hungarian people who oppose mass immigration, Viktor Orban, who has fenced off illegal migrants. Owl tells sparrow he's a big head. This saying is used in our place by those who accuse the innocent of what they are guilty of.

name: Presidente. –
text: Given the importance and delicacy of the debate and also given the very high number of participants, since then there will also be the "catch the eye", I will not accept "blue card" questions.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Our debate today will be reflected in the history books. For the first time, we are faced with the decision to make it clear to a Member State, by initiating article 7 procedure, that it is not a cavalier offence to disregard the union values laid down in Article 2 in a significant and systematic manner.  We must take a stand when it comes to the union's existence, when its foundations are undermined. There can be no consideration. It is therefore not against a Member State, but we are fighting for our common interests. Above all, it is not appropriate to say that the resolution is a way of punishing a Member State, as the Hungarian Foreign Minister has repeatedly said. Yes, he constantly insults Members of this House by denying the report as a collection of proven lies. No diplomat speaks, certainly not someone who should be interested in an objective and serious exchange of views. And I would have expected a Prime Minister to make that clear to his Foreign Minister.  Above all, it is an unjustifiable accusation. We have made a sincere effort to draw up our judgment on the basis of verifiable facts and the rapporteur has gone to work carefully, sine ira et studio. The outcome of the report is clear and the overwhelming majority of the LIBE Committee has therefore recommended the application of Article 7. Four other committees have joined this request. The decision now rests with the plenary and a clear decision is needed. There is no longer any point in putting this on the back burner. The problems are not self-sufficient, and certainly they do not allow themselves to be sat out.  To be clear, ladies and gentlemen, there is no illiberal democracy. The East of Europe has had this bitter experience before. At that time, it was called euphemist ist people's democracy. Democracy will not function without the liberal principles of tolerance towards dissidents, respect for the political minority, the existence of freedom of expression, the separation of powers, the independence of the courts and a vibrant civil society. Tomorrow, we have a historic signal in our hands.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. The author of this report, starting our debate, asked the question of the state of the Union. The Union is in a state of decomposition, of crisis, of demands such as today's one, namely the demand to exclude Hungary from codecision on European Union matters. Look at le Monde two or three days ago, there were two Europes: Macron's Europe and Orban's Europe. This is the image of today's Europe that you want to share rather than unite. You are trying to stop the wind of history, because the wind of change is blowing through Europe today, and this wind is blowing not only through the Hungarian forest, but blowing from Sweden to Italy, and remember one thing – maybe Stalin was able to turn back the rivers, but the wind will not stop. These changes are coming, and either by respecting democracy, we will accept them and discuss them with peoples who want to decide for themselves, or we will really turn deposition into a complete destruction of the European Union. In article two of the Treaty on European Union, we have enrold the values that unite us. You want to make these values a tool for the police to think in order to divide Europe, but Europe still exists, because Europe is the union of our countries, not your ideology.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I’m delighted to hear Mr Jurek’s ardent plea to uphold Article 2 of the Treaty, because – I say to Mr Orbán – the funny thing here is that you claim that the European Union wants to impose things on your country, but your country was the first country to ratify the Lisbon Treaty. And I’m sure that you read Article 2 before you put your signature to it. So all we are doing is keeping you to your word. And you know what? The Hungarian people want you to keep your word, because they want to remain at the heart of the European Union. But then you have to play by the rules and respect the rules. Debates like this one today are about a very difficult situation, and some people are getting rather desperate about how to get out of that situation, but I think this is just a difficult phase in a bigger process of the European Union coming of age as a community of values and a community of law. And we will get out of this situation. Maybe we should do that by de-dramatising and de-politicising. You put a lot of drama in your speeches, Mr Orbán, but I actually prefer the approach of Ms Sargentini, which is very factual, fact-based and accurate. Her report is a very accurate picture of the state of play of democracy and the rule of law in your country, and it is not a pretty sight. You talk about the Hungarian people but – you know what, Mr Orbán – all of us here have voters, and my voters ask me why we have to respect the rules when the Hungarian Government doesn’t have to. Why are we giving Mr Orbán EUR 87 million a week in order to destroy the European Union? Why are they getting away with it? Well I have difficulty answering my voters. It is not just your voters we’re talking about, Mr Orbán, it is all the citizens of Europe. So we have a duty to hold you to the same rules and standards as everybody else. And then, finally, the real message of today’s debate is not about pointing the finger at Hungary or criticising Hungary. The strong message of the European Parliament is that we are not willing to let Hungary go. We didn’t walk the road to here, and bring Hungary on board as a member of this family, in order to let go. Hungary is a member of this family, and we will fight to get Hungary back on track and give Hungarian citizens the European values that they are entitled to, like anybody else. That is what we will be voting on tomorrow. (Applause)

name: Romeo Franz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Orban, I would like to thank the commissioner for his Dealing with minorities recognises a government's attitude to democracy, the rule of law and human dignity. These three pillars are crucial to the existence of a peaceful Europe. True peace arises only through acceptance of differences. It is not for nothing that the motto of the European Union is: United in diversity. But the Roma in particular, Hungarian nationals, are exposed in your country, Mr Orban, to institutional anti-Gypsyism, segregation in the education system and discrimination on the part of the state and non-state. Mr Orban, finally assume your historic responsibility towards your national minorities, so that Hungary can perhaps even become a model for the rule of law, democracy and for the protection of the dignity of all people! Hungarian citizens! You are strong! That is why oppose right-wing extremism! Create with us a Europe of justice in which racism has no place!

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Democracy is not something you taste sometimes like a dessert – today I take dessert, sometimes I don't take it. It is something that is fundamental for all this work to work, how we are going to have it together. You are turning away, Mr Orbán, and the right here does not really know how to vote tomorrow. I believe and hope that you will land right in the end. What I am also concerned about is the idea of the nation that you have, and it is shared by some here on the right flank of the house. It is patriarchal, it is authoritarian, it is anti-democracy, it is racist, and it is dangerous for us women, for us LGBTQ people, for all our racialised sisters and brothers. The nationalism that you represent, it destroys and it destroys. Europe cannot be built on racism and oppression and anti-democracy. Civil society is fighting that oppression. Now we in the European Parliament are doing our work carefully in Mr Sargentini's report, and I would ask the right to do its part and vote in favour of that report tomorrow. Anything else would be a disgrace. Then I would ask the Council to do its part. Sitting down at a table and not having the basic rules ready for itself, it does not bode well for the political content that it is to be decided on.

name: James Carver (NI).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, for hearing my point of order. I rise as one of the four Members of the European Parliament who are from the Roma minority, and could I honourably remind Members that Lívia Járóka, one of the Fidesz MEPs, is one of the other four Roma MEPs. She sits on the right of politics and not all Roma are necessarily on the left of politics, just like all people within society, and all this talk of anti-Roma ... Mr Orbán has a Roma MEP who sits as a vice-president of the European Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Carver, I can confirm that there is a Vice-President of the European Parliament who is a Roma MEMBER of Parliament, who belongs to the Group of the European People's Party and comes from the Fidesz party. That is the truth. Mr Járóka, who is Vice-President of the European Parliament. It is well known throughout parliament that it has fought in defence of the Roma, and so I can confirm that what Mr Mc8/80 has said is true. Carver, beyond political judgments, just for information.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is about the incredible request by this Parliament to have Hungary strip of its voting rights in the Council. Ladies and gentlemen! I believe that today will go down in history. We have already seen the decline of social democracy throughout Europe. This happens when an elitist official caste makes policy against their own clientele. Today marks the beginning of the end of European Christian democracy. Ladies and gentlemen of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the treatment of Prime Minister Orban as one of you, your contempt for the nation state and its sovereignty, for the principle of subsidiarity – all of which shows how deeply socialist thinking has penetrated your ranks. But I would ask you to carry on, this is only for the benefit of the citizens of Europe. Christian democracy will follow social democracy into the abyss. From 2019, this will also be reflected in this House and in its coalitions. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Orban, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his work Rest assured: many millions of people in my country, Germany, stand behind you and your policy of defending conservative and liberal European values. Do not let the pseudo-moral scorn of this House distract you from the right path, no matter how it is decided here tomorrow.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: Mr President, this resolution is a direct attack on Hungary as a sovereign country and is fundamentally anti-democratic. The aim is to subjugate a democratically elected government of a country that applies the principles of democracy, freedom and European and Christian values. It is fundamentally wrong for the European Parliament to function as chief justice and to decide whether or not a national parliament should implement legislation. Apart from the fact that the justification for condemning Hungary in Mrs Sargentini's report is also not enough.  Viktor Orbán is the only one who respected the Schengen Convention and stopped illegal migration. Orbán defends European values better than the European Commission itself, and my party fully supports Hungary's sovereignty. And as my party leader Geert Wilders has said before: Orbán has more backbone and character than all the cowards of the European Union put together! You understand, we're going to vote against it.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: " Mr. President, thank you for the floor. As early as 2015, the European Parliament Hungary illegal migration by border fence as a charge against the european union. We should therefore have received recognition, but instead the accusations are included in the current report, expecting the quota migrant reception to be honoured and an otherwise failed decision to be taken.  The report also talks about racism and anti-Semitism in the form of acts of violence. I reject this sgalent.  The report includes serious findings on the rise of corruption, restrictions on the rule of law and an unprecedented level of government predominance in the media. These criticisms are real, based on facts, and the question can be asked: to what extent is a free country Hungary?  The proposal requires a two-thirds majority of the yes and yes votes. I will abstain in the final vote, which means that I do not support this pro-migration report and I do not accept the launch of the Article 7 procedure, the final sanctions of which would otherwise hit an entire country rather than a government. Thank you very much!

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we are here today to show that politics must be about principle and values. That means taking tough but necessary decisions. Of course we can choose to close our eyes, but too much of Europe’s history is marked by terrible decisions taken in the name of expediency. We know that appeasement never works, we know that our values are worth more than just the paper they are written on, and we know that from some things, we cannot look away. Europe is a hope, it is a promise, it is an ideal, and I see Europe as the pillar of light sandwiched between Trumpian clouds and Putinesque shadows. Our European way – of freedom, compassion, fierce personal liberty, passionate equality, the rule of law, free thought, free movement and a free press, and the protection of minorities is a global symbol of enduring courage. We should be proud of that. The litmus test of a European nation is how well these values are nurtured and protected. If, despite everything, despite all the calls to change direction, despite all the extended hands of friendship, our values remain under serious threat, as they are in Hungary, then we must act. We must choose the politics of hope over the politics of fear and cheap populism. We must protect the European way, always. And so, in the name of all those who sat in this Chamber before us, in the name of all those who believed and believe still, tomorrow I shall stand up for Europe.  (Applause)

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable Prime Minister Orban, this debate is not against Hungary! Slovenia, my country, loves Hungary. This debate is against your politics of intolerance, lies and intimidation, which is spreading dangerously beyond Europe's borders, including to my country, Slovenia, where your sister party has used your methods of intimidation very openly in the recent political election campaign.  This is one example that I would like to show by asking where we Europeans are safer, whether in Paris with the mend and armed forces or in sunny Budapest with tourists.  You say this report is the one that offends the Hungarians. It is this campaign that insults, unfortunately, all Europeans, and we must fight this, not Hungary. And I am sorry that we are forced to debate again in the European Parliament today about the state of democracy and the rule of law in one of the Member States.  And we reject that very very clearly. I therefore express my support for tolerance, dialogue, for democratic values, for dignity, for man. Indeed, hungarians do not deserve to be significantly undermined by the countries, the situation in the country, their fundamental social order and democracy.  I will therefore strongly support my colleague Sargentini tomorrow and vote in favour of the report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, this debate here is about much more than the fate of one nation. We are shaping the future of the European Union here and there are complaints about the Hungarian institutions, Hungarian rule of law and so on. So yes, let us settle those questions then. But some would like to see Hungary and other central European countries under control, obediently following the wrong directives of Brussels given from above according to the explanation of the common rules, but with different biases. It was mentioned here that we are united in diversity, so how has it come about that you want to kick out someone for being so different? We have some different opinions, yes. After 40 years of Communist oppression, we are entitled to shape the EU project as well. We experienced totalitarianism already; we experienced the dictating of opinions. There are so many wrong things with Europe today: unrealistic federalisation, disrespect of the natural family of one man and one woman and of human dignity, more opposition to the freedom of speech. There are examples in EU Member States. Prime Minister Orbán is no threat in comparison to the deformed version of democracy that the left-wing liberals are preaching to the EU states. It is a false gospel, and I ask you: let us deal with that, please.

name: Nadja Hirsch (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The report shows very clearly what is going on in Hungary: away from fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law, freedom of the press and freedom of expression towards an illiberal democracy, as you yourself call it, Mr Orban. But this idea divides, it sows discord. At the beginning, the state distrusts its own citizens, initially only minorities, but later also always all people. You personally stand for this development towards totalitarian autocracy, Mr Orban. And that is precisely what I, as a Free Democrat, do not want, and that is why it is my duty to speak out here too. But it is also my duty to speak out against those who seek to join forces with you, such as the CSU, like Seehofer, like Söder. In Bavaria, for example, I do not want a government that is toying with an illiberal democracy. I therefore call very clearly on the PPE and, in particular, from the CSU tomorrow, for a very clear commitment to the liberal values in Europe and a clear statement against illiberal democracy.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, in a minute I will not have time to list all your attacks on democracy and the rule of law, on freedom of expression, on human dignity. Triggering Article 7 is an absolute necessity, as you are flouting European values every day. Values that aim precisely to protect all citizens, to protect Hungarians and Hungarians. No, contrary to what you say, this is not a country that our report denounces, it is the actions of your government. We do not insult Hungary's honour; on the contrary, we want to defend it and protect it from your autocratic excesses, because, Viktor Orban, you are not defending the freedom of Hungarians, you are consolidating your personal power. You don't protect them, you turn them against each other. You are not serving your country, you are locking it into an authoritarian regime, even worse than the one you claimed to save it 30 years ago. This must stop, and the vote on the Sargentini report is a first step in this direction.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (EFDD).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, Mrs Sargentini, I am a Frenchman who lives in Vienna, Austria, a stone's throw from Budapest. I am an observer of the central-European reality, a Western observer—European and, strangely, we do not see the same thing. It seems that you are reading the story with your ideological glasses and you are not looking at reality. The European Union is destroying its legitimacy on its own, and its legitimacy is the adherence of the peoples to its great project of unity. Because the people want a Europe of power, they do not want a Europe that welcomes its enemies, a Europe that lets them proliferate and silences those who revolt against this collective madness. So the trial that is being heard, on false legal grounds, against Budapest, is a political trial obviously, which aims to silence the courageous voices in Poland, Austria, the Czech Republic and of course Hungary, who refuse to make the same mistakes as the West in terms of immigration.
