Those who hear this trial will bear a heavy responsibility before history, because in the only history that counts, the History of Long Time, that of civilizations, well it is Mr. Orbon who is right.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, welcome Mr Orbán. You, dearest Orbán, are a hero in this Parliament, a hero who is fighting for the freedom and sovereignty of his people, against the European Soviet Union. The Hungarian people are under attack from this Europe, a slave to soros lobbies, banks and financiers. That is why Brussels is attacking Orbán in Hungary today, and tomorrow it will attack Italy and our leader Matteo Salvini, who is courageously stopping illegal immigration. Mr Orbán, we have the same values, the values of those who want to defend their identity and popular sovereignty, the values of those who want to defend borders and say no to the invasion of illegal immigrants. This Europe must be changed, and we will change it from top to bottom in order to give security, justice and true democracy to our citizens. Courage, Mr Orbán, we stand by you and together, after the European elections in 2019, we will build a new Europe: a Europe of peoples, homelands and freedom.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for the work she has The EU is a community of laws and values. It must therefore be completely out of the question that the rule of law and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights are the basis of any political action. Values and law do not know party political or tactical mash-up. I would therefore also like to say to you that the era of liberal democracy is not over, as you said in May. Liberal democracy is fundamentally different from authoritarian democracy. European democracy respects EU fundamental rights, European law, goes towards each other, respects one another, respects all people and protects minorities, protects freedom and independence.  We have a great many questions relating to politics in Hungary – because of the statements against liberal democracy, because of the incitement of anti-Semitism by the poster campaign against Mr Soros, because of the EU bashing through the text in the referendum, because of the NGO law, because of nepotism and corruption, because of the threat to the private university, because of the restriction of media freedom.  It is in your and our common interests, Mr Orban, that the orderly, structured, rule-of-law dialogue should be initiated in accordance with Article 7. It is a question of the union's credibility. It is about your credibility. It is a question of the credibility of the quality of our cooperation. Populism, nationalism and the idea of Europe are mutually uneven.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. Dear Prime Minister, One thing I'm sure we both know equally: that you're lying. You lie in this community, in our family, here in parliament, and you lie at home, in our society, in Hungary, to your compatriots. He says he wants to protect Hungary from Brussels. You do not have to protect Hungary from Brussels, because this is our family, and believe me, you do not have to protect Europe from some kind of danger that only you outline to the sky. What are you really trying to protect? That regime, that sinful, stinking regime he built with his oligarchs. That is why he is doing this policy, because he wants to protect this regime from law and European rules, from the European community. You have taken away European resources and are using them to build an empire at home.  Dear Prime Minister, His greatest sin at home, however, is that he took away the belief that we are all Hungarians because he divided Hungarian society in two. He teased neighbors and introduced what only Goebbels knew at home, that he divided all members of Hungarian society into good and bad. This began with you taking the cookard from every member of the nation and ethicing the national cookárd. This, this cookard, Prime Minister, which I am now symbolically taking back, because the home belongs to all of us, not to your sinful regime. Home, love, Europe! You poisoned, you threw poison into our common drinking fountain, and it was a huge sin, for decades, long to define Hungary life. That is why tomorrow we must vote in favour of this article – the Article 7 Sargentini report, so that you learn, and for posterity, that no one can do this to their own country. Thank you very much!

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Mr President, there are problems in Hungary when it comes to questions like corruption, the situation of national minorities, and so on. Many of those problems are inherited from the past, and they are in no way unique to Hungary. These shortcomings are not the reason why Hungary has become the prime target of the Commission and this Parliament.  The real sin of the Hungarian Government is that it wants to protect the country from damaging mass immigration from the Third World. The Hungarian Government and the majority of Hungarian voters do not wish to repeat the catastrophic mistakes we have made in Western Europe. I very much sympathise and support that position. Unfortunately, liberal immigration policies and multiculturalism have become the European value in this House. Almost anything else can be forgiven, but not questioning that value. This is why we are having this debate.

name: Bernard Monot (EFDD).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Orbon, thank you and congratulations. Thank you for offering new hope in the resistance to federalism of the European Union, thank you for restoring to Hungarians and Europeans their dignity as free citizens. Your courage is admirable in the fight against the Euro-globalist caste in Davos and Brussels, embodied in Hungary by Mr Soros. The Hungarian people, attached to their national identity, are deeply grateful to you for re-electing you triumphantly. It is normal, you protect Hungarians from the deadly danger of migratory submersion, against Islamist terrorism and against the steamroller of globalism, which brings only economic, social and cultural regression. He is a patriotic and deeply pro-European leader who, together with the Italian leadership, offers a credible alternative for Europe. Federalist Europeans like Juncker, Merkel and Macron want to punish and demonise them. In the name of democracy, Mrs Sargentini's report and article 7, of totalitarian inspiration, must be rejected. That is why we will vote tomorrow against this scoundrel report. Mr Orbon, don't change anything, long live the Hungarian Fidesz!

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to apologise in advance – I apologise for the fact that an ominous alliance of leftists, communists, socialists, greens and, unfortunately, the European People's Party portrays you, Prime Minister Orban, as a treaty breaker, treating you as if you were a political criminal. This is by no means the case! Prime Minister Orban is one of the heroes of Europe, who, when the migration wave began in 2015, was the only one to observe the European rules. Please respect this and stop your unflattering attacks! And, Prime Minister Orban, how dishonest this side of Parliament is, is shown by the example of Romania, when a month ago some 100 000 people took to the streets for corruption against the ruling Social Democrats and Socialists, 500 were beaten down and you all put your head in the sand as if nothing were! This is not about human rights, liberal democracy and European values applying somewhere. No! The Socialists are governing, and we are burying our heads in the sand. Indecent is what you do here. You have friends in Europe, in Italy, in parts of Austria, you have friends in Poland, in many other areas of Europe: please continue on your way! They are a hope for many people.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Hungarian citizens, dear colleagues, including women and mothers, are outraged at the way they want to protect them from themselves here, against their will, because they are supposed to not be able to practice their religion freely, there is no freedom of expression, they restrict their assembly and social rights at home.  While everything has nothing to do with reality! Therefore, dozens of Hungarian NGOs are openly opposed to voting for the Sargentini report in an open letter, many of them factually denying the mistakes. Thousands protest in petitions as individual citizens. They are outraged that the text is not based on the activities of tens of thousands of well-functioning NGOs, mr Timmermans is based only on the slip-up and untruthfulness of a few NGOs funded from abroad. Yet these NGOs in Hungary have already lost their credibility when they have listened deeply to the police excesses of the Socialist government.  Let us note that this is a political instrument with two objectives: firstly, to punish Hungary for its strong and consistent opposition to illegal migration, and, secondly, to divide the People's Party as much as possible before the EP elections, colleagues.  We all know that the opening of article 7 proceedings does not stand up to our country. Therefore, this report does not classify us, but those who made it solely for ideological reason. Please, if you still believe in a common Europe, vote against this report tomorrow.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this resolution is not directed at the Hungarian people, to whom we give all our support and friendship, but at the work of Viktor Orbán's government, which systematically violates the values on which the European Union is founded. A government that for years has been jeopardising the functioning of the constitutional and judicial system, which promotes corruption, which violates freedom of expression, which denies the rights of refugees, migrants and all minorities. There are no intermediate positions: either you are with Orbán, endorsing his repeated attacks on the rule of law, aware that what is happening in Hungary today could recur tomorrow in any other Member State, or you are against it, censoring the serious violations for which your government has been responsible. The Delegation of the Democratic Party in the European Parliament and the entire Group of Socialists and Democrats will vote in favour of this resolution. We will not be complicit in the break-up of the rule of law either in Hungary or in any other Member State. We want a strong Europe that guarantees the rights and democracy of all its citizens.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Hungarian Prime Minister tried in his speech to manipulate the Hungarian nation. We are not taking action against the Hungarian nation. We are taking action against politicians who violate European values, as is the Prime Minister of Hungary. Moreover, Budapest, and I am referring again to political leadership, is copying Moscow's practices. Prime Minister Orban explicitly supports an illiberal system in which civil society, free media, academic freedom, diversity, independent justice no longer take place. At the same time, European money is disappearing. OLAF investigated 35 cases in which EUR 40 million from the Cohesion Fund disappeared. Where did they go? I don't know-- said a colleague before me. It calls for the recovery of this EUR 40 million from Hungary, from the political factor. Michael Ignatieff, the rector of the Central European Liberal University, has said the essence publicly - there have always been people who liked what Orban said about migration, but the question for all is whether they like and what Orban says about democracy, freedom of the press, economic freedom and, above all, what Orban is doing against democracy, freedom of the press, economic freedom, European values. That's what we vote for, that's what we vote for.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we should probably be glad that the Prime Minister found his way here because I hear, Prime Minister, that you posted a video message on Facebook that you were going to Brussels to protect Hungary.  This is not, of course, Brussels, but since Brussels is all that embodies the nefarious influences upon Hungary for you, I suppose that between here and Brussels there is no difference. Europe has to be Brussels, and Brussels is not good for the country. Because it would impose migration, because it would impose certain functioning measures and certain democratic standards, probably because it would also be looking after its money.  And honestly, I am sick and tired of seeing EUR five billion go every year essentially to make a few people close to you richer, every year, and having for the rest, the Hungarian economy – which is probably glad that 700 000 people have left over the last 10 years because otherwise they would be in the country and unemployed. The only reason why unemployment is where it is, is not the prowess of the government; it is the fact that people have voted with their feet.  Now otherwise, what happens with the money? Enormous billboard campaigns against Brussels, against the Commission, against Parliament, against the Commission President, against Soros on the sidelines – but that is not really relevant in the Brussels context, apart from the fact that we are all apparently doing the bidding of Mr Soros. The only thing I know is that I never had a study grant from him. Other people apparently did. I never even shook the man’s hand. Others have accepted favours.  I noticed one thing and that is that today you are even more behaving like the leader of a sect than ever before. It’s only about religion, the right form of family, the nation, and shutting the other out.  Among the many mails that we got, Prime Minister, there was one from Pastor Ivanyi, who I believe once officiated at your wedding. I do not think he is less good at religion and less good at Christianity than you are, and he is not feeling comfortable any longer. And I am not comfortable with this discourse because the Christian democracy that I want to belong to is a Christian democracy that accepts the secular state. I don’t want to become part of a sect and I don’t want to be treated like I was facing a sect. What you are doing in Hungary is dangerous, but the Hungarians seem to vote for you. Let  them go on doing that; we will vote for something else tomorrow, at least as far as I am concerned.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Article 2 of the Treaty on Union establishes equality between men and women as one of the fundamental values. His government not only attacks freedom of chair, but is now considering eliminating the university's gender studies. We all know here that education is one of the fundamental tools for creating fairer, freer and more egalitarian societies. Gender equality must therefore be a guarantee throughout the European Union. Mr Orbán, you intend to ask that your majority be legitimized when you are not accepting the legitimacy of the majority of this European Parliament. And he's come here defending himself, using the Hungarian people as a shield. The European Parliament has nothing against Hungary. What is against it is for governments like yours to drag their people apart from the fundamental principles and values of the European Union. Let us therefore work together together to achieve a fairer and freer European and Hungarian society on equality.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: Mr President! It is clear when you hear this debate that it is approaching the tragikomic. This house, which enthusiastically welcomed the new Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, made it quite clear that they were probably welcomed into the club but did not welcome the positions coming from the countries. I do not understand how a Commission that has not been elected and a Parliament which, in every direct election, has lost the proportion of people who bother to go down and vote for us at all will lecture on national democracy in the Member States. It's beyond my comprehension! But we can therefore say here today that if this Parliament and the Commission continue their attacks against Hungary, against Poland, and probably soon against Italy, Austria and whoever else is coming for, then all that can be achieved is to push the Europeans away from us and destroy the cooperation that should actually be well-functioning in the European Union. It is certainly not to bring Europe together in diversity. And if you really believe in diversity, then you also gave the Hungarian people, as you give all the other peoples of Europe, the opportunity to go down and vote, elect their government and be governed accordingly.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, allow me to begin by thanking Prime Minister Orbán for being here. Prime Minister, this is not the first time we have discussed in Parliament such problems in one of our Member States; and the fact that you are here to face the critics deserves some respect. You certainly have courage. That said, I cannot deny that I am concerned, and have been for some time, about what I am hearing and reading in reports from your country. We have unfortunately been forced to discuss the situation in Hungary a few times here in Parliament; and we are all, at this stage, extremely familiar with the issues: the ‘stop Brussels’ campaign and general anti—EU rhetoric that was used in the election campaign earlier this year; the use of an anti-immigrant poster, borrowed from UKIP, in the same election campaign; the accusations of limiting the freedom of the press in Hungary; and the moves to introduce legislation that could close the Central European University in Budapest. These are not actions we would associate with a European People’s Party Head of Government and it is disappointing that we are having to discuss these issues with you here today. To me, many of your actions are not in line with the principles and values of our political Group. Frankly, Mr Orbán, what I want today are straight answers and responses from you on all of these issues, not generalities like you gave us in your opening speech. My constituents and grassroot members are rightfully bringing these concerns to me about your party’s place alongside mine within the PPE. Your answers are keenly awaited.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, the democratic values and principles of the European Union remained the same before and after Hungary's accession on 1 May 2004. This accession was a voluntary process, reflecting a broad consensus of the Hungarian political class, and the European Union is no more forgiving than before. We have always had a responsibility to safeguard our common values, all the more so today, as we witness the emergence of those who advocate exclusion and hatred throughout Europe. Despite all that the Hungarian Prime Minister has said today, the actions of his government represent a systemic threat to the rule of law and, logically, the European Union cannot tolerate it. As we do now, our strongest response is the article 7 process of the Treaty and I would like to get it up and down as soon as possible. In advocating Article 7, I am not going against Hungarian citizens, quite the contrary, because it seems to me that it is the Hungarian citizens who are suffering from the reform of the Hungarian Constitutional Court to limit its powers. The absence of counter-power is a threat to each of them, and it is always they who no longer enjoy a free and independent press, thus seeing their freedom of opinion restricted. In this Chamber, it is the MePs who are fighting for the Hungarian people, the first victim of this authoritarian drift.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The behaviour from the front row reminds me very much of school time, when the bullies stood in a row in front of their bullying victim, gaping and screaming. When they were finished, they went off to coffee, patted each other on the shoulder, paid tribute to each other for how good they had been. That's the behavior we see at the very bottom. First row, you think you're good. It is frightening to see how you behave towards democratically elected representatives visiting the house. The Sargentini report consists of the cut-and-paste model, which does not give an objective picture of the situation. Hungary has responded to the report's claims. The question must also then be asked why the report, which is based on the observations of other organisations, would be more important than what Hungary is suggesting in substance. The EU is trying to punish Hungary, and its actions are restricting Hungary's sovereignty in a totally unacceptable way.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: Thank you very much, Mr. President. I am convinced that this report must be stopped now. I'm asking you to vote against it tomorrow. As we have reassuringly heard from the Commission, there is no specific threat to the rule of law, so there is nothing to justify voting for this report.  In eighty-nine, ladies and gentlemen, I was a 15-year-old teenager, and even then, with a poster for Fidesz, we were hoping for a better Europe, a healthier Europe. Looks like it's the same thing now. Then I spent 20 years defending rights in Roma matters, studying at CEU, studying at Western universities, and investing a great deal of work in making good use of the position that Fidesz then gave to a Gypsy woman, a young Gypsy woman from Central and Eastern Europe, in 2004, in order to protect the 16 million Roma in Europe. It was therefore particularly important that fidesz also delegated me to the People's Party as Vice-President of the European Parliament.  And it is therefore particularly painful to see you, led by my fellow German Members of the People's Party, who are really familiar with the very strong Hungarian attitude in the European Roma strategy – because we have made this strategy for Europe, we want to protect the poorest – they know that today it Hungary also the one who is really doing everything he can against the segregation of Gypsy children in schools.  We were the first country in 2004 to bring up this issue. You are talking about violating the rights of Roma children. In our country, children go to school from the age of three, integrated kindergartens, by the age of six they no longer need to be developed. We have dual vocational school programs compatible with sports programs that really bring the best workforce to your multi-large companies. By 2050, we have realised that if we do not train the Roma, all the states of Central and Eastern Europe and Western Europe will be at an economic disadvantage.  So I think that we should thank the Hungarian Government for what it has done for the Roma and not condemn it. Moreover, such baseless accusations seriously undermine the credibility of the European Parliament and the European Commission. On the basis of these arguments, the initiation of such an Article 7 could be envisaged for any Member State in the future. So please stop this by voting no tomorrow. Thank you!

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your I think that you and I have no kind of the same thinking, no understanding. Which, by the way, would be perfectly natural in a normal democracy: you have a kind of political concept, I have another. The problem is that in Hungary you call the political opposition a traitor in a short word. My fellow Member Szájer's earlier taunt illustrated this situation precisely.  I must say that I find it disappointing that you are coming to the European Parliament, and instead of having a factual debate, you are still talking about being persecuted, stigmatised, punished. I must say, Prime Minister, many of my fellow Members from other political families have said so here, and that is not the case.  The aim of this report is to bring Hungary back into the European family. We do not want Hungary belong to a different kind of Europe. But in that, Prime Minister, you are right that this is really about the future of Europe, and we really do not want you to take Hungary to the Europe of Salvini, Farage or even Steve Bannon. Hungary my country, not just yours, Prime Minister, and I would like to see my country in this democratic Europe today, and not in the other country that you are about to build. Thank you very much!

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, today I am proud to stand up for democracy. This debate is not about condemning, sanctioning and accusing. It is to reach out to the Hungarian people, to engage in an open dialogue and to uphold our shared values and their rights as Europeans, based on facts and rules. Democracy is more than winning elections. Our union is founded on human rights, civil liberties and freedoms. Prime Minister Orbán, high—flying rhetoric and a denial of reality does not help us to move forward together. You and I shared an inspiring moment of history at the funeral of Helmut Kohl, the great statesman who united Europe and shaped a Union based on liberal democracy and Christian values. Instead, splitting East and West and pursuing hard nationalism undermines our Union. You do not represent Helmut Kohl’s heritage, nor the salvation of Christian democracy. Christianity is about respecting human dignity and helping the most vulnerable in need, not sabotaging any European solution on migration. There is no illiberal democracy. Everything else is regimes. Now you want to export your model, spreading the acute Salvinitis virus that is affecting Italy, lining up with populists in France, Poland, the Swedish Democrats and even Putin. Bad company! Rest assured, we in the PPE Group are not going to give up our identity, nor lose our compass. Please, Mr Orbán, I truly hope you will find yours again. Citizens are watching. Either we stand up for our values or we are dragged down in the populist meltdown. (Applause)

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister Orbán: 'democracy' and 'liberal'. We have long learned that when a democracy needs adjectives it is that it has ceased to be.  Report against Hungary: The Council of Europe, the Commissioner for Human Rights, the Venice Commission, the OSCE and this European Parliament express nothing against Hungary, but a red alert to the setbacks of the rule of law and democratic quality imposed by the roller of its absolute majority in a succession of constitutional reforms against all others. Restrictions on pluralism, women's rights, minorities and systematic and derogatory non-compliance with European law on migration and refugees demand a response.  And neither our voters, nor the European citizens, which include Hungarian citizens, nor can this European Parliament look the other way. You must vote yes to Article 7 because democracy has never been, without more, the rule of the majority. Democracy is the guarantee of respect for minorities and fundamental rights against the tyrannical temptation of any majority.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Hungary decided in April 2010. Voters in the economically and morally devastated country gave the Fidesz-KDNP party alliance a two-thirds majority. The Orban government immediately started the Hungary and economic renewal of the government. Straight talk and action were already catching the eye of those who had benefited from Hungary situation.  As early as January 2011, in the debate on the Hungarian Presidency, I mentioned a witch hunt as a Fidesz MEMBER, seeing the unfounded and unsustainable style of contributions. We Hungarians have a clear vision. We stand by our Christian Democratic roots and say that the Hungarian people do not ask for illegal immigration, nor do we ask for lectures on issues that belong only to us.  Fidesz is the only party in the European Parliament that has sent one member with disabilities and one Roma member at the same time, and you want to lecture us on democracy? I wonder why no one in the report cares about the situation of people with disabilities. One in 10 Hungarian citizens has a disability. Don't they matter? It is against the fact that a number of European Parliament documents attempt to provide extra resources to organisations helping migrants or illegal migrants, more than once at the expense of people with disabilities, taken away from them.  It is clear from this indictment, this inconsistent and biased indictment, Hungary who is now eyeing. We must say that this Hungary not in the interests of the European Union.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address the ordinary European citizen Viktor Orbán, not the President, to tell him that liberal democracy is not dead. It will be slow, flawed, imperfect, but democracy is strong, and this European democracy is so strong that it is also ready to defend its rights as a common European citizen. That is why I want to reassure him that there will always be room in this House for opinions, including his own. I would like to reassure him that the European Union will always be founded on the solidarity that guarantees Hungary EUR 5 billion in funds. I would like to reassure him that, if he is one day in court, it will be this democracy that will ensure that he has independent judges who are not influenced by the political power in hand. I would like to tell him that he will defend his personal rights, including that of studying at a Hungarian or foreign university, if he wants to, because it will be his right, and also tell him that he will not be discriminated against, and that if one day he finds himself looking for work outside his country, it will be the European Union that will guarantee him freedom of movement. That is why I invite you to reflect on what this democracy is and what value it has. I say to my colleagues in the 5-Star Movement, who I see as particularly absent and silent, how they will vote, whether they will be in Italy and Hungary and in Europe for the rule of law, or not.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have no problem criticising the Hungarian Government as long as it relates to the exercise of my mandate. I find it particularly worrying the allegations of corruption to which both Mrs Grässle and Commissioner Timmermans have referred. Unfortunately, even after considering these facts, I must say that triggering Article 7 of the Treaty of Lisbon will not solve these problems. Corruption is a problem in all the new Member States. At the heart of this report is an ideological, not substantive, dispute. I have witnessed this when I adopted the opinion in the Committee on Women's Rights, which I consider to be misleading. It is based on criticism in areas that are also the subject of controversy between the conservative and liberal parts of this House. This is, for example, the right of a Member State to refuse the so-called 'green card'. Istanbul Convention or define family and marriage. This right does not fall within the competence of the European Union; Mrs Sargentini's motion for a resolution deepens the polarisation in the European public space. In doing so, the Union has more effective instruments to ensure redress in specific areas of concern. Article 7 is intended for a qualitatively different situation and I cannot support the proposal to abuse it.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Europe is a family of shared opportunities and values. We create it voluntarily in our part of Europe, looking for better opportunities after years of the Iron Curtain. I am concerned that respect for the freedom of civil organisations has disappeared in Hungary, because it imposes rigour on them, such as during the gloomy times of communism, that laws are being introduced that break good habits in helping others, because what is the criminalisation of those seeking refugee status, that academic freedoms are being undermined and conspiracy theories about institutions supporting education are being dissuaded, that the language of simplification and hatred has dissuaded the language of conversation and solidarity. All in the name of the fact that the majority won the elections, and yet in liberal democracy the winning majorities care about minorities, but for today's leaders of Hungary, liberal democracy is the incarnation of the devil.  The report in question is based on facts and objective analyses, and it is not necessary to challenge its authors from the worst liars. Maybe you need to accept criticism and change your attitude? I remember the experience of working with Fidesz in the late 1980s. I would like to return to cooperation. Is it possible? Is there only cold water left for hot populist heads by triggering Article 7 of the Treaty? Go back to Europe, Hungarian friends.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Mr Tajani, Honourable President Orban, dear colleagues.  Mrs Sargentini's report seeks to potentiation or convert political issues into problems that are supposed to have systemic origins in Hungary. At the same time, it touches on issues in areas for which the Union does not have competence, such as social and education policy, which, of course, must remain in the domain of the Members.  Subsidiarity is one of the fundamental principles of our union, and the creation of a demarcation between the competences of the Union and the Member States must be respected. Otherwise, we're taking a lot of risk.  But the most concerned are the double standards that the European left often implements. As a rule, there are centre-right governments in pranger. When it came to an eclatant violation of the rule of law in Slovenia, she did not react because the left was in power there.  I have mentioned several times here that, just before the elections, the leader of the opposition, Janez Janša, was illegally imprisoned, and then his term was withdrawn. Where were you then, guardians of the rule of law? Where are you today when you need clear answers from the Maltese and Slovak governments about investigating the murders of journalists? Not to mention Romania.  Let me remind you, and this was confirmed today by the Vice-President of the European Commission, that the European Commission did not consider it necessary to initiate the procedure laid down in Article 7 of the Treaty. In doing so, the Commission has been closely monitoring and analysing, as we have heard before, the Hungarian situation for many years. Mrs Sargentini, however, has only survived one day in Hungary. Who do we believe now? Of course, I will vote against the report.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to thank you for the opportunity that, since Mr Carver addressed me, you will give me the opportunity to react very, very briefly. Yes, I think it is very important that the European Parliament has a Representative of Roma origin, and that is why I am appalled that two texts could remain in this report suggesting that the far-right Hungarian Guard may have been operating under Fidesz, or that the Roma killings took place during our period. The perpetrators of the Roma killings were convicted when the Orban government came to power, and Viktor Orban's first action after the 2010 elections was to ban the operation of the Hungarian Guard in Hungary. Under the Socialist governments, the Hungarian Guard was able to gras in gypsy settlements. Thank you!

name: Le Président. –
text: If we are talking about the Roma minority and the Vice-President is trying to defend the Roma minority, she has the right to do so. As she was talking about something else, she asked to speak on the Roma issue. As there are... Ma'am, it's my responsibility, yes, I gave her the floor a second time, do whatever you want. I gave the floor to Mrs Jurka on the Roma minority because she had started talking about something else. So, if... You cannot defend the rights of the Roma if only a few people defend them here and there. The Roma minority must be defended by everyone. That's enough, thank you very much. Now we're moving on to Catch the eye. Say what you want, that's enough, thank you Madam, thank you very much. We're moving on to Catch the eye. Several Members have asked to speak and I can give the floor to up to six or seven members. On-demand interventions

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Dear President, Mr. Prime Minister of Hungary, dear representatives and members, Hungary is a democratic country of legitimately elected representatives in democratic elections. It is also a country whose people know very well the cost of their freedom, independence and sovereignty. We cannot help but notice that the Hungarian Government has stabilised national finances, significantly reduced the unemployment rate and recorded economic growth. Hungary's orientation to assist directly persecuted Christians in the Middle East, for which it has allocated EUR 16.5 million in the last year and a half, is an indication that Hungary is ready to help those most in need. As a full member of the European Union, Hungary warns of the weaknesses of some European policies and seeks their change. The European Union, on the other hand, expresses concern about the situation in Hungary. Solutions should be sought in the dialogue, respecting the fundamental values of the Union, the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality and internal political processes in the Member State. I understand the concerns of individual colleagues, but triggering Article 7 is not the right answer. We must jointly seek solutions to preserve a united Europe, not contribute to its disunion through our actions.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Orbán that I have been in Hungary many times, both before I entered politics and in the past four years during my term of office. Coming from a civil society background, I can feel the pulse on the streets, and I was on the streets of Budapest in July for Pride, a civil society action. I did not see you joining the march, Mr Orbán. I did not see you standing shoulder to shoulder with the Hungarian people of all ages, the families with their children, who came out in force to stand up for gender equality and non-discrimination. On that day we had to march with police protection because there was a fascist counter-march. You have created this state of xenophobia and creeping fascism. Fear of the other stalks your land. The racists, the misogynists and the homophobes are emboldened by your illiberal, anti-European, regressive values. I love Hungary, Mr Orbán, I love its people and its culture, and it’s not Hungary which is the problem – it’s you, who have forgotten what it means to be both European and a Christian.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I have to say to Mr Orbán: I am no fan of the European Union, but you completely and utterly disgust me. You talk in pejorative terms about how you don’t want your country to turn into a country of migrants. Well, you’ll really hate me then, and my children, because both my children’s parents – myself and my wife – were migrants. Their four grandparents, nine out of the 10 of their uncles and six out of the six of their aunts. If they, in the countries that they went to, had to face what you’re doing to immigrants, well, it wouldn’t be a good thing: signs put on the doors of people that helped them; punishing educational institutes who support them. Yet, still, my wife is a Kelly, one of the most common immigrant names. Yet, still, we have a Kelly in here who describes you as having courage and says how he respects you. I don’t think the Flanagans and the Kellys and the immigrants of this world would respect you. I’ll say it again: I don’t like the European Union but, as far as I’m concerned, you are dirt.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Orbán, I will not repeat the arguments of those who opposed Article 7, because I believe that the two speeches by our fellow Members – a nice and gracious colleague of Roma origin and a valiant colleague with handicap problems – have, I would say, uncovered the hypocrisy of those who point to your government and your country as an enemy of minorities. I just want to tell you this: I was nine years old when in 1956 all the newspapers and the news, still black and white at the time, showed us these guys from your country fighting with their bare hands against tanks. May I tell you that today your courage, your example and the struggle you are courageously making are worthy of that memory, that courage, that anxiety of freedom that should unite us and respect those who speak on behalf of a people who, unlike others who only speak, fought with blood for freedom.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, unfortunately we are witnessing an extremely dangerous attempt by some european Union officials and leaders to break the independence of a Member State in order to impose their own ideologies on it, contrary to the will of the Hungarian people. The interventions attempted and the attempt to restore Hungary to the policies proposed by Brussels are a bomb in the foundations of the Union. Firstly, the areas in which objections are raised are not areas which the Union has competence in, but fall instead within the competence of the States, which must be respected. Even more important, however, is the fact that the Hungarian people approve and support the changes that the Hungarian Government is trying to implement, as demonstrated in the recent elections. Contrary to the practice of most governments, these reforms were included in Prime Minister Orbán's election programme. In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that there is a huge risk for all Member States if the pursuit of certain sanctions goes ahead and I call on you all to immediately abandon all such thinking, as well as to stop interference in the internal policy of an independent and sovereign Member State.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on behalf of my fellow Members who, for Forza Italia and the UDC, then Lorenzo Cesa, are here in the European People's Party, to say that we absolutely do not believe that there are any requirements for activating the procedure provided for in Article 7. On the contrary, I have to say that, listening to this debate, I have convinced myself that we have something to worry about, because we are a little deaf to each other. If we had listened carefully to what our Hungarian colleagues were saying, we would have understood that perhaps many of the things written in Mr De Clercq's report would have been a good one. Sargentini should perhaps be reviewed. In any case, it must not be an ideological issue, as some speakers have said. Look at the fact that we are in danger of opening Pandora's box. I do not believe that it is the activation of Article 4, but we must ask for dialogue, we must ask for intelligent support. So, if not Malta, why not do the same thing about Malta? Why not do the same about Slovakia, where journalists were killed not so many years ago but a few months ago? And why not romania? Really look at what we're doing is risky! I believe that if we vote for this, we, as a Parliament, really act like an elephant in the glassware and get the opposite effect. Let us listen to our Hungarian colleagues.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, I was waiting for your point of view because last week I gave an interview to a journalist in Hungary who was asking me how I would vote. As a member of the LIBE committee, I spoke to journalists from Hungary who came and complained and showed that their rights were being restricted. I am appalled by your position. For four years and something, all the leaders of the member countries have been watching here. None of them behaved like you – arrogant, defiant. You told us you didn't care in your speech. You haven't followed any colleagues, you haven't come back to see who's talking. Stay and defy us. Prime Minister, we are not attacking Hungary. I have friends, I live in Timisoara, I took holidays in Hungary. I want to understand - do you want to do something that is not enshrined in the treaty? You say you are defending your country, but you understand that you are in a club, you have signed some agreements and you have to respect them? Or you only want to do what you want, but to meddle in other states, as you mix in Romania. That's what I want you to understand, it's not the Hungarian people we're punishing here, it's your way of governing.

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Hungary PM. – For those who miss the specifics: in a 108-page report, we have sent it to all of them, please read it.  I've deciphered, I think, Mr Verhofstadt's feelings for us, too bad he's not here. I see that the fact is, Mr Verhofstadt, that you hate us conservative Christians more than you love Europe. And I can only say to Hungarians who vote against their own country: the problem with you is that they hate me more than they love their country.  As far as corruption is concerned, I say to my fellow Member Bullmann that all applications in Hungary are open to the public. Any European company can start. The proportion of applications running alone in Hungary is 26 percent and the EU average is 24. There's still work to be done. The proportion of investigations launched on the basis of the Commission signal is 47 percent in Hungary and the EU is 42, so we are better off with this.  By the way, the Commission proposal presented by Mr Timmermans was adopted by us with zero tolerance, which we received in June.  As far as CEU is concerned, Mr Wéber is wrong. If you look at the Bavarian rules, you will find that they are stricter than the Hungarian rules. You're a double standard, even though we belong to a party family. In addition, I ask you to go to ceu university's website. Today, before I came here, I went to the website and read the following sentences. I quote from them now, from that website, you can read: "1. CEU will continue to operate in the future", writes the university itself. "All students now enrolled in Budapest will finish their studies," the university writes of itself. "All the accreditations of the university are intact," the university writes of itself, and also says, "Budapest a hoathing city." We're waiting for you to come and take a look around.  As far as extremist parties are concerned, the fight against migration is not a partisan issue. I'm willing to work with any government that wants to protect the borders and raise my hat to the brave Italians. As far as anti-Semitism is concerned, I would like to make it clear that it is declining in Central Europe and growing in Western Europe. Moreover, the centre of modern anti-Semitism is in Brussels because of its support for anti-Israel organisations. Please pay attention to this in the future, and it was not us, but you who wreathed Marx, the father of modern anti-market anti-Semitism, his statue.  And finally, ladies and gentlemen, I belong to the European People's Party, and I can see that we are in trouble. Looks like we're weak.  We European people's parties are not strong enough to go our own way. I see that we are weak, and we dance like socialists and liberals whistle. I want us to be able to change that in the future.  Anyone who claims that the report does not condemn Hungary should read its title. They do not want to condemn the Hungarian government here, they want to condemn Hungary. Thank you so much for your attention.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, having listened to the debate, I think there are a few things we have to clarify. First of all, the Commission operates on the basis of the Treaty on European Union. The Treaty was signed by sovereign nations and was adopted in sovereign nations. If you’re a member of a club and you sign a treaty and want to be a member of the club, you apply the rules. You cannot use the argument of democracy to ignore the rules. If you have a democratic majority, you can change the rules, you can negotiate a change of the treaty, but you can’t violate the rules, nor can you ignore the rules.  Everything I put in my report at the beginning of this debate, and all the concrete issues I have put before you are based in fact. They are issues we have with the Hungarian Government on the basis of, in our view, rules that are not being respected. We will pursue this in a dialogue with the Hungarian Government and we will take the Hungarian Government to court if we believe that they violate the rules that were agreed at European level. That is a task of the Commission. Whether I was elected to this position or not is neither here nor there. What we do is we respect the Treaties and this role was given to the Commission in the Treaties. The Treaties are the fundament upon which we operate. I just want to add one issue to that: when we criticise the Hungarian Government and its legislative measures, we do this very precisely. I have to say – to then say that criticising laws and criticising the Government would amount to criticising a nation or a people, frankly speaking, Mr Orbán, that’s the coward’s way out. If you make these laws and if you stand for these laws, stand for them, and we will have a debate and dialogue and hopefully we will resolve them, but don’t try to deflect attention from criticism about the actions of your Government by saying that those who criticise the Government attack your nation or your people. That’s the coward’s way out.  One final remark: the emptiness of the arguments on this side need to be compensated by screaming and shouting. Volume will not compensate for the emptiness of your arguments, sir. Finally, I want to reiterate that the Commission believes that the only European way is through dialogue. If the dialogue doesn’t deliver the results, we will go to court, and I hope that Hungary will stick to its line to execute court rulings. That is the rule of law in Europe. Europe was created on the basis of rights of individuals. We’ve had a past – sometimes – of dictatorship through democracy. That is why we can never ignore the rule of law, nor fundamental rights, and using the argument of democracy against the law and fundamental rights is going back to a European history none of us want to see again. (Applause)

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, having followed the debate attentively, I would like to reiterate that the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights are cornerstones of the Union. Therefore, these values are at the heart of our concerns. As the Presidency, we will act as an honest broker, and I can assure you that the Presidency will closely follow the vote and will pay particular attention to all views expressed today. As I stated at the beginning, there will be no compromises regarding democracy, the rule of law and human rights.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, some of the speakers asked why this report is based on sources from outside of the Union; some called it ‘cut and paste’. I will explain why. It’s because within the Union there are no reports being written that are benchmarks on fundamental rights and democracy per Member State. For instance, the Fundamental Rights Agency in Vienna, one of our agencies, is not allowed to do that. And why is that? Because Member States in the Union have been shying away from looking at the state of their country when it comes to democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. Some speakers asked why Hungary? Why not Romania, Slovakia, Malta? Well, I’ve been here since 2009. If you look at my track record I have been supporting every debate that deals with rule of law in a Member State, and I can tell you that Romania is going to be on the agenda next time if you all agree with a proposal that the Greens have made. And I know that the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs is going to visit Malta and Slovakia next week to look into the issues around the murder of journalists and corruption. I think that is important. But two wrongs do not make a right, and that’s the mistake a lot of people here are making. If you point to a mistake by somebody else, it doesn’t compensate for the mistakes you make yourself. I think we should keep that in mind. Now, if you, as a representative of a minority grouping, manage to break through a glass ceiling, good for you. It doesn’t mean that everybody else in your society is able to follow you through the glass you’ve broken, and it is that possibility that society needs to create because, in the end, what is a government? A government is a service provider to its people – all its people – and a government that is elected with such an enormous majority has extra responsibility to bring along all its people. That is what Article 2 is about: people. Article 2 is about respect for human rights, including everybody, and Article 2 is not about nepotism. Nepotism is not a European value. I ask the House to vote in favour of this report. Tomorrow Commissioner Juncker will talk about the State of the Union. Well, this is a decisive moment for the state of our Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, September 12, 2018. As we are very late, I would like to announce that the 'blue card' questions will not be allowed in the forthcoming debates and there will be no catch the eye. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is grounded on values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, and the rule of law, and on respect for human rights, to which all Member States have freely subscribed. As a convinced defender of our common values, I am profoundly concerned about the recent threats to what binds together, represented by the cruel murderers of journalists in Malta and Slovakia, the questionable judicial reforms in Poland, the threat to the rule of law in Romania, by a ruling party led by a politician who has been sentenced to prison, and the current state of democracy in Hungary. With regard to the latter, Ms Sargentini’s report sets out in detail the multiple actions taken by the Hungarian Government in recent years that have a negative impact on the Union’s image as a whole and could jeopardise our international relationships in the future. Activating Article 7 TEU would highlight the fact that European Union belongs not to its leaders but to its citizens. Regardless of our political affiliation, as Members of this Chamber we have to stand united in defending our electors’ explicit attachment to our values, which are appreciated worldwide, and in seeking further solutions for those of us who are, unfortunately, straying from those values.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We strongly denounce and condemn attacks on democracy, social rights, fundamental freedoms and guarantees of citizens in Hungary. We express our solidarity with all those in Hungary who resist and fight against these attacks. It is important to understand the causes of the rise of the far right and fascism in Hungary, as in other European countries. Understand to fight. This is an inseparable reality of the path trodden by the EU. Inseparable from its policies and its consequences, in particular at the social side. Inseparable from the anti-democratic deepening of capitalist integration. Inseparable from the attacks on the democratic sovereignty of peoples, national sovereignties, and the authentic processes of national oppression and class oppression associated with them. We do not recognise the EU's authority or the legitimacy to become a judge or even reference to democracy and human rights. We do not forget the consequences of the troika's intervention in Portugal, trampling on the constitutional order and the collection of rights, freedoms and guarantees contained therein. We do not forget the xenophobic, racist and exploitative nature of the EU's migration policies. We do not forget the promotion and support given to fascist forces in Ukraine. We do not forget military aggressionagainst sovereign states in violation of international law. None of this can be ignored.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – (PT) We would not be here if the Commission had already acted in line with the Tavares report of 2013 and then activated Article 7, thus sending a deterrent signal to other governments with the right to call into question European values and principles and the solidarity that should be the cement of this Union. Orbán's government does not protect Hungary, it disgraces it, as the Sargentini report details: in addition to corruption, discrimination against Roma, assaults on media pluralism, the independence of justice and academia, it has exceeded a threshold of inhumanity in the campaign of hatred against refugees and migrants, refusing them food.  Orbán's government holds Hungary hostage and serves Putin's strategy and the Nazi far right, racist, anti-Semitic and xenophobic, to challenge and destroy the European Union. The European Parliament must unite. This is a moment of truth for the EPP: its members must assume their responsibilities, vote in conscience, no more supporting Orbán and Fidesz.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The idea of applying the Article 7 procedure against Hungary is wrong and unfair. EU action is motivated by political motives and not by a will to protect democracy and the rule of law. The initiation of this procedure is an aggressive response to Hungarian policies and reforms that are not in line with the official political line of Brussels. The European Union therefore does not respect the sovereignty of a Member State and the principles of subsidiarity. Parliament's report contains dozens of errors, and the vote on Article 7 is revenge for Hungary's non-accepting of refugees. It is a kind of blackmail that leads to the support of migration against the opinion and will of a nation. This is a simple political struggle, the use of the EC institutions and other European institutions to brutally combat those who think differently, to combat political opponents. The launch of the article is a punishment for Budapest's attitude towards the problem of migration. I therefore strongly oppose the content of Mrs Sargentini's special report. This report is extremely extensive and contains many allegations without any real evidence of a serious violation of democratic principles and the rule of law. I believe that its adoption may undermine the unity of the European Union, which is why I am voting against it.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. – Mr Orban, in April last year when you were in the European Parliament, you stated that you wanted to correct the Union and to reform it because that was the only way to regain people’s confidence. Why don’t you start with yourself first? A year after that discussion in Parliament, we see that the situation in Hungary is getting worse. The report lists 12 serious issues which threaten the rule of law, including the functioning of the constitutional and electoral system, the suppression of freedom of expression, freedom of religion and academic freedom, and conflicts of interest, to name just a few of them. It seems that the only actual ‘EU value’ which you accept and follow is EU funding. You want to get the money but you don’t want to play by the rules. What kind of business deal is that? We, the EU MEPs, have to stand up together for EU values: we have to protect them because the protection of EU values means the protection of EU citizens, including, in this regard, Hungarian citizens. Mr Orban, when will you have had enough of ruling Hungary using communist-type practices?

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – In fact, this debate has long been not about Hungary, but about Europe. It's about what kind of Europe we want to live in. One where the decisive word belongs to the people, or where the will of the people can be taken into account.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Two years ago, the Hungarian government called for people's views on immigration in a referendum. Voters overwhelmingly said no. An election was held in Hungary this year, with immigration as the main theme. Fidesz won a two-thirds majority. Yet many of you are now preparing to adopt a report condemning Hungary, among other things, for not taking in immigrants. If they do, they'll abuse their power. But it is good for you to know that this is not primarily bad for Hungary, but for the European Union. You can't build a community for violence.  I therefore ask you, if the future of Europe is important to you, to respect the democratic decision of the Hungarians and to vote 'no' to the report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. "There is nothing more shameful than a dictator not taking responsibility for the system he built, but rather covering up with his own people. It is a special and historic moment that MEPs can see a man like this live here in the European Parliament today.  Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your It was not the Hungarians who forcibly prevented a referendum with bald beaters, but you. It was not the Hungarians who silenced or bought up a significant part of the independent press, but you. It was not the Hungarians who unilaterally rewritten the rules of the election tailored to Fidesz, but you. It was not the Hungarians who made party media out of the public media, but you. It was not the Hungarians who stole the EU money that was given to Hungary, but you. I only know of one son-in-law being investigated by the EU Anti-Fraud Office for corruption, your son-in-law, Prime Minister. It is not Hungary that is being criticised here, but the Hungarian government, not the Hungarian families, who are considered thieves, but the Orban family. Do not hide behind the Hungarian people, do not hide behind the nation, but act like a man and for once in your life take responsibility for your actions. All 12 points in the Sargentini report classify your system, your government, your decisions. And yes, Hungary must be protected, not from Europe or Soros, but from you!

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Hungary is a sovereign Member State that has voluntarily chosen to join the Union, with all the advantages – there are quite a few for Hungary – and all the obligations that go with it. The maintenance of the fundamental rights of the Union, democracy and the rule of law is part of that. Mr. Orbán wraps these violations of fundamental values into a dark brown discourse on migration, a feint that gives him applause in this chamber from all those European parties – including nationalists and populists in my country – who want to score electorally on the suffering of people fleeing war and oppression. If we fail, ladies and gentlemen, to stop the advancing authoritarianism in one Member State, it will ensure that extremists elsewhere in the Union feel embointed in order to systematically destroy the fundamental rights of their people. When we talk about a Europe that protects, it means not only that we have to protect our external borders better, but also that we protect the Hungarians. After all, today we are in an era where threats are not only beyond our borders, but unfortunately also within our borders.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Axel Voss, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on copyright in the Digital Single Market (COM(2016)0593 – C8—0383/2016 – 2016/0280(COD)) (A8-0245/2018).

name: Axel Voss
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner and Vice-President of the European Commission, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. We have all had intensive discussions, but what is the point of this reform that we intend to vote on tomorrow? On the one hand, it is, of course, a question of preventing the exploitation of our European artists, which continues on the Internet. We are talking about big tech companies that have been making huge profits with the works of our European artists and our European creatives for years. And that is something where I would say: we should not continue to accept this.  Now that the mandate was rejected before the summer recess, we have the opportunity to stand alongside the European creatives once again, and we should not constantly look for any way out and excuses for actually getting the big tech companies back there. I think we should start to stand by our artists and protect our values here as well. It is not just a question of how to make a profit. In fact, this is also a question of Europe's self-assertion. It is also a question of how we actually transfer the property that we consider to be normal in our online or offline world to a digital world, and the fact that these parameters are not shifting accordingly here. It's about taking responsibility for content on a platform. This is new. So far, we have not asked the platforms to do so. However, following the e-commerce directive, which was formulated at the beginning of the millennium, when platforms played a very different role, there has now been a development where we have to find massive copyright infringements and where we should now simply act to achieve a better balance between the artists and their works and the platforms.  Ultimately, it is always a question of cultural theft. We Europeans can be very proud that we can create so much content that we are creative, and we in the European Parliament should support that accordingly. It is not a question of destroying the Internet, as it has somehow always been collated in the summer by this great campaign. It is not a question of obstructing someone, of uploading their works, nor of preventing any dimensions of the future. Nobody in this house wants to destroy anything. Nobody in this House wants to prevent anything. But we should start thinking now about the other side that is in question here.  What is the point of avoiding copyright infringement? What is the point of wanting fair remuneration for journalists, publishers and artists? And what is the argument against large platforms taking more responsibility, including the rights that apply? In the future, we will have to regulate the responsibility of the platforms anyway. Let's start with copyright here! I believe that this would be a wonderful signal to all our European creatives. I would therefore ask you to participate constructively in this.

name: Catherine Stihler
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, as rapporteur for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), with joint responsibility on Article 13, I must say that this article remains problematic. The proposals to protect copyright owners are so restrictive that they could have a detrimental effect on the freedom of expression.  There’s a broad consensus across this House that we should protect the work of artists, but I agree with consumer organisations, user groups, academics, developers – and the list goes on – that Article 13, as proposed, goes too far and could dramatically restrict the internet freedoms of our citizens. To fundamentally change platform liability through copyright and not the e—Commerce Directive is dangerous and deceitful.  What will this lead to? Filtering, where error—prone and hypersensitive algorithms will remove anything that could pose a risk. This includes legal content. If this is not censorship then I don’t know what is. On Article 13 I ask colleagues to support IMCO’s balanced text protecting our citizens’ fundamental rights.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Voss and all the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts to modernise the European copyright framework. This is a priority for the Digital Single Market, it is a priority for this Commission. Since the Commission put the proposal on the table exactly two years ago, as we all know, the discussions have been complex, difficult at times, but also subject to intensive lobbying from all sides. We are now at a decisive stage. Stakeholders and citizens all agree that copyright changes are necessary.  Today's rules belong to a bygone world, a world that did not know the high-speed internet, smartphones or social networks. With these new rules, Europe aims to provide benefits to our citizens, researchers, teachers, creators, cultural heritage institutions, and all in a balanced way. The new rules include a new exception for the search of texts and data, an essential exception for European research and innovation. They also contain exceptions for education. They will ensure the preservation of cultural heritage and access to it by our citizens. Finally, they improve the transparency of artists' remuneration. All these benefits for the cultural sectors and for our society are at hand. However, they will not happen any time soon if the European Parliament does not adopt a mandate tomorrow. I am aware of the intense debates on two provisions of our proposal, namely Article 11 and Article 13. In both cases, the objectives pursued are essential. Article 11 aims to support quality journalism, which today faces significant challenges, while continuing to be indispensable in a pluralistic democracy. Article 13 is intended to ensure the online consumption of creative content and to ensure that creative content is guaranteed fair remuneration. I would like to clarify the debate. The right of press publishers is not a tax on links, nor is it an obstacle to access to information. This right clearly excludes hyperlinks from the new protection afforded to press publishers, just as it does not change the scope of what is already protected by copyright. Similarly, Article 13 is not intended to create private censorship or an obstacle to freedom of expression. It aims to ensure that those who create content have a say in the possibility and how their content is made available by platforms, and that they can have a fair share of the revenue generated by the use of that content. Section 13 does not concern users and their ability to upload content; it does not in any way limit the use of parodies; it does not prohibit memes or limit freedom of expression. Finally, it contains strong mechanisms and safeguards to protect the rights of individual users. The Commission's proposals are balanced, and among the many amendments received, I see many amendments which aim to improve the Commission's proposal without altering its spirit. None of the provisions currently under discussion will destroy the internet, none will sign the Wikipedia shutdown, none will destroy Europe's cultural heritage. Tomorrow's vote will focus on European creative capacity. A vote to start the trilogue will demonstrate that Europe is capable of reforming copyright, and therefore modernising our society and ultimately safeguarding our values and democracy. Thank you for your attention and I remain attentive to the discussion that will come.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We are trying to face a problem resembling a squaring circle. How to preserve internet freedom and ensure that creators, on the other hand, exercise their rights? I agree with Mr Voss that value gap is a real, serious problem. We need to create the right conditions for creators to create outstanding works of art in the digital age too, in order to preserve and develop our cultural heritage. It is therefore necessary to ensure that cultural creators and journalists have the right to a decent remuneration for their work and the tools for enforcing this right, including online. On the other hand, we must not forget the rights of users who are not only passive recipients of content, but actively create and publish it themselves – they are, above all, the creators of the internet. We need balanced solutions that protect copyright content in a way that does not violate the freedom of users' rights. As we know, however, our proposals have caused great concern and protests.  It seems to me that we have not yet found a suitable solution, and the proposed provisions seem in many cases too restrictive, this applies to both Article 3, Article 11 and Article 13, which is why we have also tabled numerous amendments.

name: Marc Joulaud
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. As we have seen, copyright is a subject that stirs passions. It also unleashes impulses, and sometimes even lies. We hear that journalists, many of whom risk their lives to write articles, would like to prevent citizens from informing themselves. We hear that artists, who are often the first defenders of freedom of expression, would like to prohibit citizens from exercising this freedom. We hear that Europe, the most protective continent of freedoms in the world, would like to censor its citizens and ban memes. In truth, every person in good faith will see the absurdity of all these accusations. There are, of course, legitimate concerns. We answered that. The new proposals guarantee, black and white, the fundamental rights of everyone. The truth is that some people use citizens as an excuse to kill this directive. In reality, what citizens want is for artists to be simply compensated and platforms to act responsibly. If this directive is reduced to an empty shell, our artists will continue to be paid by tips and platforms will continue to be accountable to no one. Tomorrow, the choice will be very simple: either Parliament will defend the interests of the American giants, or it will defend European interests.

name: Michał Boni
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Europe needs to adapt copyright to the digital world and new conditions for rewarding creators for their work. But authors' rights must be balanced with user rights, not put at their expense. The key is the provisions of Article 13 – without the prevalence of content filtering, with users' procedures to appeal when their rights are violated by the excessive zeal of platform administrators removing content just in case under pressure from ambiguity of the rules, even if they were to be restored in a moment. The damage will then be to users in sharing their content. For platforms, because they will become rulers of the decision to break the law or not. And there will be no benefit to authors. The unnecessary rigours of Article 13 will limit innovation, open the internet, and not develop good quality journalism. We have made progress since July. There are proposals to change Article 13, which reconciles the needs of users and creators, protecting the small digital business. Let's take them and move forward!

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, I think this is the appropriate moment to announce that, due to the fact that the previous debate lasted significantly longer, we are 25 minutes to half an hour behind schedule. For that reason, first of all, neither I nor my successor in the Chair, Mr Wieland, will allow any blue cards or any catch—the-eye. Secondly, I will have to ask you to respect the time slots and I will have to be very strict, as will Mr Wieland.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the Spanish delegation of the EPP unequivocally supports this text and both the rapporteur's amendments and his mandate. We consider that they offer a pragmatic solution to value transfer and through their articulation minimize the possibility of uninsused consequences. The text as a whole is fully consistent with existing copyright law and provides sufficient protections to rightholders, users and platforms alike. Article 13 and all the recitals clarifying this meet a need for the sector. In this way we will achieve a shared responsibility for all those who make protected content available to the public and which must therefore be governed by intellectual property rules. The disclaimer that platforms have enjoyed so far cannot be allowed anymore, is unacceptable and abusive. As regards the alternative amendments proposed by the rest , said with all due respect – in any case, they simply serve to reinforce injustice. Due to the nature of such services, rightholders need a clear framework to determine that they are carrying out an act of communication to the public and are not protected by the limitations of the defence offered to them so far by the E-Commerce Directive. This doesn't benefit anyone. It is disturbing that economic survival capacity is increasingly dependent on a great seeker. That is why we must create a framework of conditions that allows publishers to also deal with that power. Introducing at least one right of protection in favour of publishers becomes inevitable... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Tomorrow's vote on the draft directive on so-called copyright reform will be crucial for the functioning and development of the digital economy, but above all for internet users. I hope that, after the summer reflection, MEPs will eliminate from the draft the provisions which are unfavourable to internet users, which are included in the final text voted in the JURI Committee.  With regard to the controversial Article 11, I support the concept of presumption of copyright by publishers, not the introduction of a new related law without a due impact analysis, which has not worked either in Germany or in Spain, where it has been attempted. The presumption of law will make it easier for publishers to pursue claims while respecting the principle of fair use of the public domain without blocking access to information.  The proposed new related law will not, as its proponents argue, contribute to a better quality of transmission or the elimination of so-called facs, but will strengthen the position of large publishers by eliminating weaker, independents, who will not be able to afford a fee for the so-called snippet. As a result, these great ones will become monopolists, which I think I have been in Parliament for almost 15 years, and we have always tried to avoid them in this House.  Many experts warn that this means that the public is clearly at risk of neutral content search by limiting their choice, reducing media pluralism, jeopardising freedom of expression on the internet.
