In the case of Article 13, which is even more exciting, I do not agree with the automatic filtering of content posted by users of platforms, as this means, in practice, internet censorship. Both the citizens and this Parliament have already once rejected the attempt to introduce such censorship in the infamous ACTA proposal.  I therefore call for support for the compromise adopted by the IMCO Committee, which has reached a sensible, balanced solution and clarified the compatibility of the rules with the E-Commerce Directive, ensuring a balance of interests for both publishers and consumers.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, may I first of all start off by recognising the tremendous work that the author of the report, my good friend Mr Voss, has carried out, and indeed the shadow rapporteurs as well.  If anybody was in any doubt about the power of platforms, the exercise that those platforms carried out in terms of targeting this Parliament, Members of Parliament, and indeed, policy advisors and staff that were working on our behalf, should leave them in no doubt at all as to the tremendous power that they wield. That was not an exercise in democracy. That was an exercise in manipulation, and we must ensure that there is a greater balance that comes out of this process that we are undertaking at this moment in time.  Much of the campaigning focused on Articles 11 and 13. Whilst there are a lot of improvements there – and indeed we will be voting on that and much of that will receive support from my Group – our position on Article 11, the publisher’s right, is to support it, whilst narrowing the remit so that it would not apply to insubstantial parts of articles or short extracts. I think this is a balanced solution.  On Article 13, I support the rapporteur’s approach, which I consider to be the only text on the table which addresses the liability of large platforms such as YouTube, and makes sure that artists and authors are fairly remunerated. And very finally, I am pleased to have introduced proportionality into the text so that small and micro-enterprise platforms ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, because the press is necessary for the vitality of democracy - and we have seen this again today in the debate with the Hungarian Prime Minister: let this warn us all - because culture is also an economy - 536 billion euros each year, which employ seven million two hundred thousand people in culture - and above all, , because we do not have a digital industry, we must help, in this Parliament, the enhancement of content, which is one of the elements of balance in our culture. European public opinion, as the polls have just shown, requires that users, i.e. aggregators, i.e. platforms, pay fair remuneration to those who create: artists on one side, journalists on the other. My group has tabled amendments to help the rapporteur to be even more effective.  On Article 11, for example, it is quite necessary to be a little more precise, but above all to remove the obstacle that we received in full appearing on 5 July, in order to bring together more political groups and ensure that protection is unanimous, or at least the majority in this House. On section 13, we also want to be much more specific. We have disseminated our intentions, those of my ALDE group, and I will not enter into the debates. I will simply say that we must trust the authors and ask them to report to the platforms, the texts, the works, the creations that are free of rights, and those that are not, because I do not trust the platforms, whose capacity of nuisance was seen in this chamber on 5 July, in order, I would say, to go to the rightful people and pay them fair remuneration. That is why we want to try to be a little more precise in helping the rapporteur. I would like to point out, Mr President, that there is not a letter to be taken out in what Commissioner Gabriel has said. It was not propaganda, it was the strict reality.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, copyright law is complex and, when it comes to tomorrow’s vote, all of you have been getting mixed messages, and there is a reason for that. The problems that the rapporteur, Mr Voss, wants to solve are serious, but they are not, in large part, problems caused by copyright law. Copyright law cannot bring back lost newspaper subscriptions and it cannot bring back lost advertising revenues. If that’s the problem we want to solve, we need the Commission to bring in online advertising regulation, because this is how tech companies are threatening to destroy the news business. The truth is that news articles are already protected by copyright, and if platforms use them without paying they are already breaking the law. Our alternative proposal will allow publishers to enforce that law without limiting the freedom to link. The neighbouring right, on the other hand, has been tried and has failed before. Simply wishing it will work this time around is not a solution. It is time that we turned the discussion away from what we would like the proposals to do, towards what they will actually do. If we make platforms directly liable for everything, they won’t get a licence from every rightholder in the world. Even if they could find all the rightholders, if just one of them refused a licence, the platforms would have to filter. Mr Cavada may deny that, or say that these filters will only block legal content, but simply wishing that automatic filters can do that is not going to make it true. Until algorithms are smart enough to have a sense of humour, then they won’t know the difference between a parody and a copyright infringement. They would simply block both. If we want YouTube or Facebook to pay creators, let’s write that into the law, as many of the alternative amendments from the left side of the House actually do. Upload filters will just give YouTube and Facebook an excuse not to pay. Instead, they will sell their filters to small European platforms, a danger that even the United Nations Special Rapporteur for freedom of expression had called by its name: censorship. The proposals may be well intended, but they suffer from a reality gap. We have to stick to what copyright law can do to support creators without trying to bend it to solve other problems and without threatening fundamental rights. That is what the amendments I have tabled do. They are not what big tech wants and they are certainly not the Pirate Party position. They are the proposals by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and by the previous PPE rapporteur, and they are 100% supported by Europe’s leading copyright academics. Please vote for them so that we can preserve the positive parts of this directive that will actually help creators.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, colleagues, I consider the work on the proposal for a directive on copyright to be one of the most difficult and challenging in my entire time in the European Parliament. There are too many interests and positions of different groups, and finding an acceptable compromise is not easy. We all seem to agree that modernising copyright to match the current digital era is needed. Of course, in what form, it's a different song. The controversy of the subject is also evidenced by the fact that 166 amendments have been tabled, not to mention the hundreds of emails we receive every day. However, unlike the rapporteur, I do not think that this is merely an angry campaign. We are interested in quality legislation, but it will not be a step backwards. I would like to thank all my colleagues who have been involved in this difficult work in this way. I think we have done a good job in the JURI committee in certain parts. However, for our faction, several provisions remain in the proposal for a directive that we cannot support. I hope to support our amendments to Article 4, where we want to ensure that, even today, educational institutions can use digitised materials to teaching, sample songs without the need to conclude contracts. For me personally, the current wording of Article 13 is completely unacceptable. I know that all political factions are divided on this point, but I believe that we are able to agree a compromise.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the world has had to be artificially divided in two: those who want to defend authors and creators, on the one hand, and those who want to defend the great giants of the web, on the other. I have no doubt which side to stand on: I have always defended and will defend the authors and creators. This directive, however, seems to have become a punitive measure against platforms and the network.  The Internet is a medium that has revolutionized our lives and also that of artists and creatives, offering them a global stage. But what happened? That the rights of authors and creators are used instrumentally to justify maintaining pension positions on the market. The problem of remuneration for creative content that is put online exists and is serious, but it is not with automated control by an algorithm that we solve the problem. By introducing, with Article 13, absolute responsibility for intermediaries, we believe that we are solving the problem, but instead we are creating an even more serious one, putting fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression, at risk and giving enormous power to private multinationals. It is also ridiculous to think of combating the phenomenon of fake news through Article 11, which in fact introduces a link tax on the publication of article previews. This directive, which should protect authors and creators, is already obsolete and punitive towards the freedom of the internet. We in the 5-Star Movement believe that in order to protect citizens' rights we must look to the future and not continue to apply the old categories of the past.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the vote on the Copyright Directive is decisive for the future of European nations for three reasons. First, politically. According to a recent poll, a vast majority of Europeans believe that the American internet giants now hold more power than the European Union. They see GAFA (Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon) as a potential risk to the functioning of democracies. Will this Parliament give way under the millions of spam and tweets controlled by Silicon Valley? Second, socially. At a time when GAFA has an unprecedented market capitalization, are we going to refuse fair remuneration for our authors and creators, who are workers and whose works make the wealth of these foreign companies?  It is time to tell these internet behemoths that Europe is not a big market where they can use themselves freely, for free, with impunity. Finally, without authors and creators, no culture. Will we take the risk tomorrow... so I abbreviated... Tomorrow I will vote for the rapporteur's amendments and all... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We should ask ourselves at the outset, before the vote, whether we have too few videos in the world, whether there is not enough music, whether people are flocking to or running away from the entertainment industry, or whether artists sometimes do not set up profiles on YouTube and other portals that, they say, mercilessly loot them. Deeds speak louder than words. If we ask any professional group whether or not they earn too little, we will of course get the answer that so that they should earn more, that the bad world benefits from their hard work and does not pay them well. But apparently the benefits for artists of posting on YouTube are greater than their losses. They gain popularity, which they can then discount in other ways. So deeds speak louder than words, we have enough videos. Let's not fix something that is not broken, if it is not broken, do not fix it.  Furthermore, I believe that Mr Tajani should resign.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Why are we revising copyright law? Because digitalization has changed the framework conditions. Our goal must be to strengthen our creatives – the musicians, the journalists, the artists, the authors, the filmmakers and many more – against the Internet platform operators, who usually use the works of our creatives free of charge. We want to prevent the sell-out of our creatives, the sell-off of our European culture. And how do we do that? We need a right to protect the services of our publishers so that they can negotiate on an equal footing with the American platform operators. And we also need to take responsibility for platform operators who build their business models on the backs of our creatives. That is the only point. No one wants to censor the Internet, as is repeatedly claimed. Nobody wants to prevent linking, no one wants to introduce taxes on links. There has been very, very much untruth in this debate. It is important for us that it is about our European culture and our European creative industries. I would really ask all Members to support the balanced proposals that our rapporteur, Axel Voss, has drawn up over many, many months. We need this new set of rules so that we can simply put our creatives in an appropriate position in the digital age in order to stand up to others.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It was the right decision that we decided in July to debate the Copyright Directive again in plenary. Many amendments have been tabled over the summer, and this shows the huge need for discussion in this legislative proposal, which is essential for the completion of the Digital Single Market.  My group has been trying to reach a compromise until the very end. We welcome important progress for employees in Articles 14 to 16. Unfortunately, in the area of the controversial Articles 11 and 13, it was not possible to formulate an acceptable compromise. We would have liked to have been prepared to do so.  The S&D Group's main aim is to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of artists and consumers, while strengthening the development potential of the European creative industries. Safeguarding fundamental rights is essential for us. Our voting behaviour will be guided by these objectives.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Intellectual property and copyright undoubtedly deserve protection at European level. Unfortunately, our debate has been focused for weeks solely on the profits of the two sides in the dispute. Both the European Commission and Mr Voss have lost sight of what should be the most important thing, namely the needs and rights of internet users. It is difficult today to imagine the functioning of freedom of expression and public debate without the internet. The freedom to publish and comment on content is a very important element of modern democracy. We cannot agree that large press corporations should be given tools that, under the pretext of copyright protection, can lead to censorship and the licensing of freedom of expression. Internet users can't be treated like live shields by publishers, but they can't be thrown at google and Facebook by such regulations. We need a real compromise. Mr Voss's report is definitely not.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, our copyright needs updating. But the protection of copyright, and ever more of it, is not the direction that Europe needs. This has been a depressing debate with claims of fake news flying back and forth, rock star experts and aggressive lobbying from big companies, on both sides of the argument.  But this should not distract us from the substance of what is at stake. So with 50 colleagues we seek a compromise that puts the public interest first and is proportionate between the need to enforce copyright but also to respect fundamental rights. So that means no upload filters, but proportionate remuneration for creators. It means no publishers’ rights, but presumption rights. It means new and clear text and data mining exemptions, which has not been discussed much but which is crucial for the development of Europe’s artificial intelligence industry, which is something of great concern as well. We also speak of a freedom of panorama and an exemption for user-generated content.  So I hope for your support, so that we can move on together and show compromise can work.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The proposal to change copyright is unacceptable. It will force upload filters over large parts of the internet. These filters are stupid! They will prevent people from making perfectly legal sharing severments of images, music, videos and political comments, and it risks hitting scores of platforms whose business model has nothing to do with copyright infringement. Pages like TripAdvisor, which is busy giving us tips on nice restaurants and great places to travel to. Many of these pages will not be able to afford upload filters. We need to resist the pressure of the copyright lobby and put the public interest first. I urge you to vote against upload filters and instead support the IMCO's proposal for a balanced copyright that both supports the artists' right to be better paid and the public's right to a well-functioning internet.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this report has caused MEPs to receive thousands of emails from their constituents. The vast majority I have received have asked me to vote against it or at least to vote for those amendments which would mitigate its worst effects. The only reason that we are having this vote at all tomorrow is because, in July, UKIP MEPs and some others invoked Rule 69c of the Rules of Procedure to make that vote happen. Otherwise this report would have gone unopposed for negotiations to the Commission and we would have been stuck with whatever came out of the legislative sausage machine.  This report is another example of the one—size—fits—all legislation to supersede national legislation and laws and it will cause bigger problems than those they are supposed to fix. Of course authors should have their works protected under fair and appropriate copyright laws, but this legislation is not the answer. The proposals have been widely criticised as a means of introducing censorship to the internet and social media, and it has been criticised by no less a person than Sir Tim Berners-Lee, the creator of the World Wide Web.  Many people now rely on the alternative media, like Twitter, to learn things which are not reported in the mainstream media and which they would otherwise not see. These proposals will also create a barrier for entry to entrepreneurs, due to the difficult requirements for social media start—ups to comply with and it will inhibit competition. We should not make it harder for people to publish material of interest to the public or restrict the ability of small voices to be heard. I urge MEPs to vote for the EFDD amendment 87 to reject the proposal completely and, if that fails, at least to vote for those amendments that mitigate the worst effects of the proposed legislation.

name: Stanisław Żółtek (ENF).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Internet has given people freedom – they don't have to listen and watch just what tv and newspapers are squeezing into their heads. They themselves can gain knowledge about the world and share their knowledge, but in this way the internet takes profits from powerful owners of newspapers and TELEVISION stations, and reduces the power of officials. This is the only main reason for this directive. Contrary to the deceitful title, it is not about copyright, but about defending the profits and power of those who have it so far. Thousands of beautiful words, as well as many of the black-out amendments in this directive, have one objective – to obscure the meaning of Article 11 and Article 13, which introduce censorship and surveillance that was not even the case in communist countries. If we adopt this directive, if you adopt this directive (because I will not vote for it), then you and your children will live in this Orwellian world too.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Union's motto is 'United in diversity', and it is today that the protection of this cultural diversity should be at the heart of our debate. Music and art are at the heart of European identity and culture, they reflect and emphasise our fundamental values, and that is why we must do everything we can to protect these values.  Around this directive, as many have said, a lot of myths and fake news have ariset. It is not true that the European Parliament wants to restrict citizens' access to creativity or to censor content online. It's not true that we forbid memes or taking selfies with your favorite player in the stadium. You will still be able to comment, share content that you like and that is very important to you. We just want the efforts and efforts of artists to create this content to be properly rewarded by those who use it illegally. Here in this House, 'fair pay for work' is often repeated. Does this also not apply to European musicians, composers, journalists, actors, press publishers or filmmakers?  I come from a sports environment where fair play is the main motto and principle, but when we are flooded with tens of thousands of emails, often automatically generated, with various false information, including threats, it has nothing to do with fair play rules.  I must admit that this is the first time I have faced such a cynical campaign against the introduction of a directive. We protect European culture and identity, let us reach out to those who, against the big platforms, currently have no chance.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, the essence of the vote tomorrow is to ensure creative workers get fairly paid for their work and are not exploited by large online platforms. We have to close the value gap, have money to reinvest in content and create new work. This is not about censorship. This is not about making individuals liable for their everyday use of the internet, despite the myths. Would we dream of turning to other European workers and asking them to give their work for free? So why are we not ensuring creators – our musicians, writers and filmmakers – such basic guarantees? We must vote tomorrow on our European values, pay creators properly for their work, protect them against exploitation and end the unfair monopoly of a few big platforms. (Applause)

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, well I don’t support Articles 11 and 13 and I never have. I don’t believe either of them will do what you want it to do. I don’t believe publishers or creators will make any more money. I don’t think it will hurt Google, but it will hurt consumers because big flat platforms and big publishers will face less competition.  Now we need to recognise that the internet has changed everything, and we need a balanced debate on how we are going to regulate it. But we need to do it carefully and not threaten the entire ecosystem of the internet. Article 11 as proposed does threaten news aggregators which drive traffic to publishers’ websites, especially small publishers. It does threaten the ability to post links to social media. It is not proportionate. Article 13 threatens to force platforms to check and filter all content, and it will take down legal content.  Now I accept that there are genuine problems, particularly for the music industry, but we must address them without undermining how people use the internet. Think about vlogs, twitch feeds, memes. So I hope constructive compromises will pass tomorrow, but I can’t support the report that came out of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Parliament has become the battleground for giants: the giants of the music and publishing industry against the giants of tech industry, and the creators are used as pawns in the game. But what is the actual problem? Not enough money finds its way to the creators while someone else is cashing in on their work.  Creators need fair remuneration for their work, but making platforms liable will not solve this problem. Neither will the creation of the publishers’ right, but it will have an impact on the users. What we need is a balanced approach between the creator’s right and the right of users. We have introduced compromises because the rapporteur failed to do so. There are reasonable amendments on the table, supported by academics from the field of intellectual property law and information law. They strengthen the position of creators and introduce exceptions for users. We have to strike a balance and not to fight on the side of one giant against the others.

name: Helga Trüpel (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Voss amendments represent a balanced approach. I would like to remind you that the artists who talked to us want us to vote in favour because they are pleased. So now the question is: are the consumers pleased? What do the consumers get? Legal certainty. What we are doing is to make digital platforms – involving the most powerful and richest monopolies we have ever had on the globe – take care of the payment of artists by concluding contracts with collective management organisations. We have it in the analogue world, we want to have it in digital. Consumers are not being placed under threat. Filters are out in the Voss amendments, so there is no censorship, there is no filtering, and political censorship is really a very different thing. Have a look at China and Saudi Arabia, they filter content according to political ideas. What this proposal is about is to make very rich companies socially respectful. And, on the question of freedom, if we have an unlimited concept of freedom that’s very neoliberal, then only the bigger ones win. What I want to do with this copyright reform is to combine responsibility and freedom, and that is the balanced approach. It’s not against consumers, it’s in favour of consumers’ legal certainty and in favour of fair payment. As in seeking to regulate Uber, when the Socialists wanted, for good reasons, to ensure that workers were paid, we want cultural workers to be paid as well.

name: Jiří Payne (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Article 11 will mean that the services we have been used to with search engines, such as Google and some others, will be limited. The people of the European Union will be harmed. Article 13 will cause our files, what our children create, and what we create and put on the Internet to be censored by robots. Robots will decide on our freedom, on our ownership, on things that can normally only be decided by the court. You can see here that the European Union is not about people at all, it is not about what the citizens of European states need. The European Union wants to concentrate more and more power in Brussels, and that is why we need to replace the European Union with an alternative.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Copyright is a right of ownership, and that must, of course, be protected. But, ladies and gentlemen, when we discuss the fact that Google, YouTube, Facebook and all of them have too much power, that they exploit the artists, exploit the creatives, then at the moment when we give them the political mandate to censor that just because Google, YouTube and Facebook censor, it is still censorship.  If algorithms determine freedom of expression, if it ultimately eliminates the rule of law through private corporations – which even gain power as a result – then neither the users win, then not even the creatives win, then at best large publishers or large music labels win in relation to the big Internet corporations. But it is the little ones who are falling through the cracks again, and this is unfortunately the old disease of the European Union. You always only take care of the big ones, you only take care of the medium-sized ones at most, but the little ones, who always fall through the grid. Unfortunately, that is exactly what is happening in this case.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, tomorrow will not be judged only if artists and creators survive in our digital age. Perhaps something more serious will be judged: if the European Union has the courage to draw up the appropriate legal framework for the operation of the technological giants, because we have typical examples already of their power and their deception. The result of the Committee on Legal Affairs was already a balanced compromise, but much improved by Mr Voss's new proposals. Although we, as the Culture Committee, where I was shadowy, have several objections, I call on colleagues to support Mr Voss's amendments exclusively. Tomorrow's vote will judge not only the future of artists but something more serious than that, the quality of democracy in Europe.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Mr President, tomorrow the European Parliament will decide how it intends to reform copyright. And for N-VA, it's already clear which way to go. We are going for a copyright that is adapted to the 21st century, a copyright that understands how the Internet works today and that digitisation and innovation does not stand in the way.  Above all, a text that speaks plain language and does not lead to confusion, as is the case now. And let me be very clear, it is essential that artists and authors receive fair and correct compensation for their work. But that must never come at the expense of free speech or innovation.  We therefore say no to mandatory upload filters and to link taxes. For us, such disproportionate measures do not fit into this picture.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission's proposal with the amendments adopted in the JURI Committee is positive because it strikes a healthy balance between the rights of intellectual creators and the rights of users, in particular the right of expression.  We cannot accept that highly profitable businesses based on the free offer of intellectual creations of others have been set up, without respect for the rights of their authors. Press publishers investing in the production of quality, free and independent information cannot be reduced to the role of free content providers to the large platforms that have emerged on the Internet.  In essence, what it is about is extending to the Internet the protection that the right gives to intellectual property in general, outside the digital space. What it comes to, in short, is to choose between the defense of European culture or the gigantic profits .... (the President withdraws the floor to the speaker).

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the economy behind the copyright system is becoming increasingly complex and we are trying to reconcile different interests. Important messages are sent out by all parties. Copyright law should focus on protecting authors and performers, and legislation should ensure that those with less bargaining power can effectively rely and have confidence in their rights. Legislation should never further strengthen the stronger party to the agreement. For example, in Article 12, we found a sensitive but satisfactory solution from this point of view in the Committee on Legal Affairs. But in Article 13, the power relationship between rightholders and technology companies should be better balanced and negotiations should be fair and transparent. The rules and means must not violate the privacy and other fundamental rights of internet users. Article 13 is not just a two-way deal, but users also have their rights. That is why I think the formulations of the IMCO and LIBE committees are the best.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, honourable members of the European Commission, a functioning copyright is an essential condition for ensuring the competitiveness of European creators on a global scale, for the viability of European culture. However, only copyright that reflects a well-defined public interest works. And that public interest cannot be reduced to the interest of one particular group of future users of these regulations. The public interest must be the result of careful consideration of the requirements of all those who combine their legitimate expectations, authors and consumers, with the existence of copyright. For my decision-making, the primary thing is that the resulting text really reflects the public interest and that it cannot be challenged for non-compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms, where intellectual property is mentioned as part of protected property. At the same time, I would like the word censorship not to be used in this debate to ensure the copyright purity of the use of copyrighted works. For us who have lived under real censorship regimes for decades, when content has been discarded because of content and not because of technical imperfections in existing instruments, this is a hard-to-digest bite.

name: Dietmar Köster (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The reform of copyright must be based on a fair balance of different interests. For me, the interests of the artists and users have a special meaning. We should not allow ourselves to be instrumentalised in a dispute which is only a dispute – old recycling industry against a new recycling industry. The most controversial are Articles 11 and 13. Both do nothing to improve the living conditions of the artists. However, I see significant risks to freedom of expression and information. Article 11 serves only to provide new sources of revenue for the old recycling industry. That cannot be our job as parliamentarians. Article 13 still means that private platforms end up using upload filters. Private actors thus decide by means of pre-filtering which content can be uploaded. I think that is disproportionate. The risk of censorship by algorithms is therefore very high.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would not want the debate to be the wrong way at the time of the discussion on business secrecy. We were told that we wanted to defend the small SME, but in reality it was the interests of large industrialists that were preserved. There, the debate is a bit similar. We are being told that we want to defend creation, the little creator who would be looted, robbed, etc., when in reality it is a struggle between platforms - and large platforms - and some publishers - and major publishers. So let's try to keep reason, let's try to understand that through this text, it is all the freedom of digital, it is all the freedom of the internet that we risk questioning. So no, let's not put in place automatic filters, let's not give robots and artificial intelligence - which only the largest groups can develop - the power to control and censor. The internet is not a lawless zone, and if we really want creators and journalists to be paid for their works and creations, then we have the opportunity to charge GAFA, especially through taxes.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Rapporteur, Commissioner, today we met here in Strasbourg Sammy Ketz, the war reporter who sent us Members of the European Parliament a letter from Baghdad, signed by 116 correspondents from all over Europe, imploring us to protect the copyright of all those journalists who are physically on the war front in order to guarantee us Europeans the right to truthful information. , to a free, diverse, quality print. The same appeal comes from all European associations of authors, publishers and producers to protect Europe's cultural diversity. The copyright directive, conceived twenty years ago in a totally different scenario, not dominated by the few over-the-tops, is a battle today for freedom and the European social model. It does not censor, because we do not want to restrict citizens' access to information and culture, but to regulate relations between copyright holders and only those platforms that classify, organise and present content protected by copyright, on which they collect increasing and huge advertising revenues without recognising and remunerating producers, publishers and authors, and therefore we want to provide for specific responsibilities and obligations. We want a sustainable publishing and cultural industry ecosystem, where powers are matched by responsibility. We want to protect the quality of information against fake news and protect Europe's cultural diversity, overcoming the current situation of an oligopolistic market dominated by US web giants with parasitic behaviour. Just one fact: it is not network freedom that still allows Spotify, with 150 million users, to recognize 1.2 billion royalties to the music industry, while YouTube, with 900 million subscribers, pays only 450 million dollars. We have a duty, as legislators, to fill this regulatory vacuum by encouraging innovative online legal business models, including to protect users. That is why, after the 'no' vote last July, we appreciated the efforts of the rapporteur, Mr Voss, to find a balanced compromise and therefore the vast majority of my PD delegation will vote...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, let us clear the way for fake news: copyright reform does not restrict the freedom of web users, nor does it authorise a generalised system of control over citizens. We have to choose whether to protect content creators or large online platforms. We must choose which cultural model undersoes our society, whether it should be shaped by the major global networks or should be based on creativity, diversity, ingenuity, everything that has always characterized us. Ladies and gentlemen, the decision we have to make is whether to try to give some rules to the digital world or whether to let the online dimension remain a Far West where a handful of large platforms orient markets and public opinion in an almost private way. That is what the future of politics is about, the future of democracy and the role of parliaments as an expression of popular sovereignty are at stake here.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Mr President, we have heard many things, many things that are wrong about the text we are debating today. However, the challenge is simple: we can no longer continue to accept that platforms do not obey any rules and pay no one. For example, YouTube now accounts for 94% of online music consumption in Europe, but contributes less than 3% to the sector's revenues. In this regard, I urge my colleagues to vote against the amendment of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), which will have no other effect than to fossilise this unacceptable status quo. So, ladies and gentlemen, rather than submitting to the propaganda financed and sent from the United States, which has been hitting us for several weeks now, listen to the voice of the Europeans. According to a recent study, 87% want rules to pay and protect creators. Please don't disappoint them.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, the rapporteur's proposals in their present form would mean that there is a general filtering requirement. We cannot want that. Today, this infrastructure may only be about an illegal piece of music, perhaps an unwelcome opinion soon. We must prevent this. I want there to be a fair balance between the interests of creative people and the interests of users, and we must get that balance right. I want active platforms to pay creative people. But I don't want algorithms to decide what to see online and what's not. That is why I have made suggestions myself. Mr Rapporteur, there are proposals on the table that you would only have to combine in order to reach a compromise that almost everyone could support here. Take advantage of this opportunity, which you have until tomorrow, so that tomorrow there will be a majority in favour of this important directive.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is high time that copyright arrived in the 21st century. Online platforms have to pay when they use the works of Europe's artists for their advertising revenue. However, we must not further strengthen their power by letting them have the uploads of Internet users. I am concerned about the fair participation of artists, creatives and legal certainty for all users. And we Social Democrats, across the vegetable garden, have already introduced and achieved a great deal in the Committee on Legal Affairs.  Artists must be paid fairly and appropriately for online use of their works across the EU, and they must be duly informed by the online platforms where, how and, above all, how much their art is marketed. Fair payment for creatives, artists and an open internet without letting users be liable for the uploads is possible.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for this interesting debate. It is very evident that there is a clear consensus about the need to modernise the European copyright framework. Reform of copyright is extremely difficult to do, we all know this. There are so many interests to reconcile and the rules have a direct impact on the everyday lives of our citizens.  It is good to remind ourselves that this directive is important for the many reasons that were mentioned before. European citizens care about this directive in a very direct way. We saw this when the Commission worked on its proposal and we have seen it leading up to this debate and votes. Clearly we need to give Europeans the right kind of copyright laws for the digital age. They deserve nothing less and it is achievable. This is very clear to us after this debate.  As mentioned before, none of the proposals now on the table will destroy the internet nor the freedom of speech. None of the proposals will restrain our citizens from expressing themselves or sharing their ideas with others. More specifically, rest assured that Article 11 will not limit access to information. On the contrary, it will ensure the survival of a quality press in the digital age. As for Article 13, I think we are only aiming at a targeted and balanced intervention, to make sure that the European creative industry can get a fair share of the value generated by its content, which is nowadays mainly used online. After today’s debate I’m encouraged that all EU institutions share the common objective of ensuring a fair and thriving copyright environment in Europe. This directive is a one—of—a—kind opportunity to adopt copyright rules to the digital age. If we fail to start trilogue negotiations, the directive may be pushed back several years. In this case, in the short term, there will be only one winner – large platforms – no one else, not the creators and artists, not the citizens, not the researchers, not the teachers, not even start—ups or smaller platforms will win, and in the end not even bigger platforms win from fragmentation. This will be a real lose—lose situation. We are committed to assisting the co—legislators in the trilogue negotiations to ensure that a balanced proposal is adopted. Thank you President, thank you Mr Voss and the shadow rapporteurs, and thank you honourable Members.

name: Axel Voss
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Why not the text of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection? I would like to make a brief point of this: because we have a legal situation here that deals with passive platforms, which cannot simply be extended to active platforms, and the case law is already much wider. There is a UGC exception there that undermines all the law there, and in the current legal situation we are simply one step further.  Why not the ALDE proposal? With the ALDE proposal, we cement the copyright infringement in the first upload and would then proceed to remove it with filters. This, too, falls short of the current legal situation.  These two options are therefore not really worthy of discussion, because we cannot carry out a reform for our authors, which will allow us to fall back behind the existing law. That is why my proposals – as Mr Wölken said – no longer contain any filters at all. I have proposed a procedure in which the parties are put together to find a gentle way of making progress here, without violating fundamental rights, without omitting the exceptions, in order to seek workable solutions, because I do not believe that we in this House will be able to do anything sensible there. And this proposal again provides for filters.  So it would be most sensible to bring everyone together here and then just say: let us develop something there so that it does not become so difficult. We have strong rights for individuals, we assume their liability, even though they are actually committing copyright infringement. And we have a clear participation of journalists, including in Article 11. That is why I believe that everyone can agree with this Voss proposal. Please go down this road with me so that we can make progress in Europe.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, 12 September 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – MEPs have received thousands of emails expressing concern about the Digital Copyright Directive. Discussions about this proposal have been both complex and controversial, while seeking a workable compromise between the most contentious elements of the directive, in particular Articles 11 and 13, and the right of copyright-holders to receive fair remuneration for their work when it is published online. That is why, in July, we voted to allow for this full plenary debate and amendment process. Throughout the negotiation process, the Greens/EFA Group has fought to get the right legislative balance, for creators to get their fair share of remuneration, and for public digital users. However, the current text of the directive includes some provisions that have far-reaching consequences for digital users, for example due to the potential imposition of content filters. There is an undeniable right for creators to be properly compensated for their work. SNP MEPs have always supported that right. On the other hand, we must also seek to protect the public who have the right to freedom of expression. To date, we do not have the necessary legal framework that balances these two principles. I think that the position of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is reasonable and I will vote accordingly tomorrow.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – The Internet and digital technologies are changing the world. Therefore, we have a responsibility to our citizens in creating better legislation. It is important to protect creative work, artists, performers, professional and quality journalism and provide authors with compensation for their work. It is also important to provide citizens with free access to online content and give them the opportunity to share these content through social media.  Cultural and creative industries in Europe employ more than 12 million people, representing 7.5% of the Union's workforce and generating around EUR 509 billion in added value for GDP, and copyright protection is the cornerstone of their revenues. The exploitation of copyrighted copyrighted works, without paying compensation, cannot be an acceptable basis for any business model. It is unacceptable for internet giants to publish other people's work and thereby make huge profits without paying creators fees. Therefore, quality legal solutions can contribute to fairness in today's digital age and ensure the well-being of our citizens.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – () We advocate that the law should be made unambiguously and accurately obliged for authors, creators, artists, interpreters, journalists, all of them, to receive a fair remuneration for the use of their works, of their work. Mandatory that the large companies that own the means of disclosure, those responsible and owners of vehicles or media or communication must be held accountable. It is in the face of these large companies that authors should be protected and not in the face of the public, users. This fair remuneration is not and should not be incompatible with the wide-ranging dissemination of the works as possible. Contrary. Nor should it justify perverse solutions involving hypervigilant practices or digital censorship. We advocate the democratization of culture, freedom of cultural creation and enjoyment, multilingualism and cultural diversity. We refuse the submission of culture to the strict logic of the market. These are principles that guide our position in this debate, including in the amendments we have tabled. In view of the complexity of the issues at hand, this will hardly be an issue closed in tomorrow's vote.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The digital environment offers new opportunities, new actors and business models, and the evolution of digital technologies has changed the way works and other protected objects are created, produced, distributed and exploited. As such, consumers have new opportunities to access copyrighted content, and the EU legal framework on copyright, while continuing to be valid, needs to be adapted to these new realities. This is because rightholders encounter difficulties when trying to license their rights and be remunerated for the online distribution of their works. That is why we agree that this Directive must ensure that authors and rightholders receive a fair share of the value generated by the use of works and other protected objects. Furthermore, in view of the fact that existing transparency in relation to the revenue generated by the use of works or their interpretations and performances is limited, affecting the remuneration of authors and performers, this proposal contains measures aimed at increasing transparency and ensuring greater balance in contractual relations between authors and performers and the persons to whom they transfer their rights.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Legislation in the field of copyright law also needs to be updated at digital level, as it must follow time and space. It is true that the initial procedure was not transparent and that the report contained quite a few critical points. However, the changes we have on the table are good and ready to coordinate with the Council. The report now regulates this area so that users' rights and the rights of creators and publishers are proportionally protected. All creators deserve fair pay for their work and protection from the big platforms that use their work for their own gain. As a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I simply cannot overlook this. The European Parliament is working to ensure that competition in the Digital Single Market is as fully competitive as possible and to provide an environment in which authors have the opportunity to exercise all the rights to which they belong, in proportion, of course, to the impact that this directive will have on businesses. Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises are exempt from the directive, and the filters at issue are no longer mandatory.  I therefore support the recast text. Thank you to the rapporteur for his hard and hard work!

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – The EU Parliament is now voting on its position on the long-prepared Copyright Directive. The aim is to ensure that authors are fairly compensated for their work even in the digital age. For months, a huge international online campaign and rumour mill have been running around the directive. EU MEPs have received tens of thousands of emails in mass mail in which the directive is suspected of leading to censorship, restrictions on freedom of expression and the destruction of the Internet. Of course, this will not happen as a result of this directive.  For me, promoting digitalisation has always been one of the most important themes. Our GROUP of the European People's Party (E-President) and European Democrats has put to the vote in plenary the compromises that specify the directive, and now the directive is clearly limited to those large commercial online platforms whose main business is to significantly distribute copyrighted material in the hope of profit. In the future, a permit or licence will be required to distribute it. Small businesses and non-commercial operators are not subject to this Directive.  Although the directive is not perfect at all, that is the sum of a number of compromises and votes, I do not think it should be overturned now. Otherwise, even the necessary reforms could be postponed for years to come. Once Parliament has decided on its position, the Copyright Directive will proceed to further negotiations, i.e. the so-called 'copyright directive'. trilogy with the Commission and the Member States. The aim is to have the directive finally adopted during the spring.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on "Autonomous Weapons Systems" (2018/2752(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for putting artificial intelligence on the agenda. I know that this might look like a debate about some distant future or about science fiction: it’s not. Artificial intelligence is already part of our daily life – when we use our smartphone or when we watch a TV series, we understand that very well – and it is now starting to be weaponised and to impact on our collective security. So it makes a lot of sense to have this debate here today. We are entering a world where drones could fire and could kill with no need for a man to pull the trigger. Artificial intelligence could take decisions on life and death, with no direct control from a human being. The reason why we are here today is not that we are afraid of technology, let me start by saying that. Human ingenuity and technological progress have made our lives easier and more comfortable. The point is that scientists and researchers should and must be free to do their job, knowing that their discoveries will not be used to harm innocent people. After World War II, a large number of nuclear scientists started to oppose nuclear weapons so that research could focus on the peaceful applications of nuclear energy, and I think that today we are witnessing something very similar: scientists and artificial intelligence pioneers are warning us of the dangers ahead. Some of them are refusing to work for the military. I believe the best way ahead is to agree on some common principles regarding the military use of artificial intelligence, and to define the boundaries of its applications so that, within those limits, scientists are free to explore the immense positive potential of artificial intelligence. This is a core objective in the Commission’s communication on artificial intelligence and in the follow-up work that will also cover security matters. At the beginning of this month, the United Nations Group of Governmental Experts on Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems agreed on an initial set of possible guiding principles. This is the first step, after a number of failures, towards a shared approach. It is a good starting point, and the new guiding principles are very much in line with the positions we have developed inside the European Union under European External Action Service coordination. Let me say that this is one of the points on the agenda where I could easily sit on both sides of the Chamber, because there is work being done on the Commission side and work being done on the Council side, as well as under the EEAS leadership.  The group of experts stresses that international humanitarian law applies to all weapon systems, both old and new, and that all weapons must always remain under human control. The experts have agreed that the UN Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons is the appropriate framework to regulate weapons of this kind and that any policy measure must not interfere with the civilian uses of artificial intelligence. This is only the first stage of the discussion and there is no agreement yet on any regulation, so work will continue within the Group of Governmental Experts during the course of next year. I believe that we Europeans have an important contribution to bring to this table. Our Member States, it’s true, hold different views on some issues, but we all agree that the use of force must always abide by international law, including international humanitarian law and human rights law, and this fully applies to autonomous weapons systems. States and human beings remain responsible and accountable for their behaviour in an armed conflict, even if it involves the use of autonomous weapons, and this is why our position at the UN has been that humans should always make the decisions on the use of lethal force and always exert sufficient control over lethal weapon systems. Of course, we do not have all the answers or all the solutions, and, partly for that reason, I decided a few months ago to set up a panel with tech leaders from different backgrounds and fields of expertise. We had the first meeting in Brussels in June, together with me and all of them. We’ve started to carry on a conversation between the tech world and the foreign and security policy community, and my intention as High Representative is to put this issue on the table for the defence ministers, too, at one of our next Council meetings: the question of how we can harness the opportunities of the digital era while also addressing the rising threats. Among the members of this global tech panel are some of the experts on artificial intelligence who have been most vocal on the issue of lethal autonomous weapons. Together with the experts’ community, we can find a solution that is both prudent and innovative. We can continue exploring the immense possibilities of artificial intelligence and, at the same time, guarantee full respect for human rights. This is a collective responsibility and I’m particularly glad that the European Parliament is leading the way and driving the conversation on this issue, so I am looking forward very much to listening to your views on this extremely important part of our common work. (Applause)

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Technology is always a difficult subject, especially when we need to regulate technologies. It seems to me that, with this problem, we have three basic thesis, which should be expressed unequivocally. Firstly, there can be no regulation or wish to block work on autonomous weapons systems in the final. This would be detrimental to, in short, the security of Europe, or mainly europeans. Secondly, autonomous weapons systems must be subject to human control, and this is what Parliament will consistently ask for. Thirdly, it is necessary to build such a legal framework so that there is no doubt as to not only the use but also the responsibility for the use of autonomous systems. In order for these conditions to be met, three objectives must be achieved: firstly, a good definition of autonomous weapons systems, we have this. Secondly, human responsibility and thirdly... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, we support and appreciate your position, Mrs Mogherini, and your initiatives, namely the call for this panel of experts to start a conversation at a level that is not only technical but also political.  We want even more in this resolution which is supported by various political parties in this Parliament: we want to move towards a binding common position that clearly prohibits the development of weapons, autonomous lethal weapons systems, so without human intervention, so on the basis of so-called artificial intelligence.  This is as a priority as we want there to be a single, clear position at the next meeting of the High Contracting Parties to the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons which will take place in November in Geneva, where of course you, your services must speak throughout the Union. And it is very important, in fact, that this message is clear for all sectors, for industry, for science, for technology, for civil, military, security and political establishments.  It is that, in fact, this type of weapon without human intervention is not acceptable, they can jeopardise the future of humanity and this conversation has to reach, inter alia, those Member States that have been reluctant to embark on a concerted process at European level, namely the United Kingdom and France, which have the project, respectively the TIRANIS project and the NEURON project which , of course, should be controlled politically at European level by the European External Action Service.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At a recent SEDE meeting, its recognised independent experts, NATO representatives, informed us that none of the Western democracies had lethal weapons that were fully autonomous, without even remote control. When calling for a ban, we must realise that such legislation can also be a tool of some international manipulation, namely the threat that we anticipate, in theory it is primarily about authoritarian regimes, which by their very nature are unlikely to submit to the precepts of international law.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Mr President, Commissioner, we welcome your initiatives in an area that we consider to be future and particularly important for the future of humanity. Artificial intelligence is an increasingly present, increasingly developed reality, but without a regulated framework, it risks constituting an attack on international security and stability and on individuals. In the use of these types of autonomous lethal weapons, we must respect the principles of international law, the principles of humanitarian law and including our values, which we protect at European level. It cannot be accepted to allow space for these artificial intelligences to decide a person's right to life or death. In this context, the absence of any moral, ethical and even legal liability could lead to chaos, abuse and a situation of global insecurity. That is why this resolution calls on you to continue the work you have started, until we have a common position in this area, a position that is crucial and, I stress, Madam Vice-President of the European Commission, in full agreement with our European law and the values we protect.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as the EU is being called upon to shoulder more responsibility as an actor in the security field, it is also very important that on all the issues that we are confronted with we clearly make visible to our citizens and everybody else that we will do that according to our own principles, and that is why we need a ban on killer robots.  We believe that the use of these kinds of weapons, which select and attack a target without meaningful human control, would dramatically change the world we live in, and it is quite obvious that the use of such weapons, if they existed, could most probably not be limited just to state actors. Therefore, we want the EU to come up with a common position in November in favour of a legally binding ban on killer robots.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the As long as 2014, this Parliament adopted a joint motion for a resolution calling for a ban on the development, production and use of fully autonomous weapons. How could it be that the negotiator of the same House, the same Parliament, disregarded this majority will and the negotiations between the Council, the EP and the Commission have now resulted in autonomous weapons systems being supported with European taxpayers' money in the EU armament programme? In fact, the legal text adopted by the EP on the EDDP, which excludes the financing and development of autonomous weapons systems, was disregarded. This is a scandal and must be reversed.  All the more important is the resolution to be voted on, which unequivocally calls for an international ban on the development and production of lethal autonomous weapons systems. There is no moral or international legitimacy for weapons – weapons that kill people without a court order, targeted and insidious. A weapon machine makes decisions about the life or death of people? The barriers to violent intervention will continue to fall. A new arms race will be launched and a bomb shop for the arms industry.  Anyone who defends human rights and humanism can only call for a complete ban on these weapons systems.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the enormous and rapid advances made by military technology, robotics and artificial intelligence, autonomous lethal weapons are destined to dominate the next military scenario. I wonder, however, whether the supposed military and strategic advantages of these new autonomous devices will really outwe exceed the risks and dangers associated with their use. I am thinking in particular of the difficulty in identifying a true and sole perpetrator of crimes that could be committed against innocent people, their uncontrolled proliferation, not forgetting the risk of mistakes or even worse of hacking, not to mention the inability to deal with all the unforeseen events in the case, without human intervention, in full compliance with the rules of engagement and international law. For these and other reasons, I believe it is necessary to start negotiations on a legal instrument that prohibits or almost completely restricts the use of these weapons. We have a duty and a responsibility to protect our citizens, avoiding apocalyptic scenarios where robot killers decide for themselves who to unload their fireload. It cannot be an algorithm or a robot that decides the life and death of humans.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The development of artificial intelligence is covering more and more areas of life. What can perhaps still be seen as useful in the civil sphere, in private life, is, of course, frightening when you think that further in the direction of these killer robots, as they have been described. As a result, it must be prevented from becoming self-sufficient and thus becoming a threat to humanity. That is why I agree with the approach proposed by the High Representative. She has, of course, put experts on this. Our demand here is also for them to work towards the Member States and the Council to draw up and adopt a common position. I believe that this is the way in which we ensure legal certainty, but also a common political course in this challenge and how we can find a good position for this together – including with this resolution.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The failure of the Geneva negotiations on autonomous weapons systems at the beginning of September has once again demonstrated the importance of the EU speaking with one voice here. I, too, call for an international ban on fully autonomous weapons that decide life and death on their own. The already existing international ban on chemical weapons should be both a warning and an incentive for us. We must not produce, export and use autonomous weapons, which can kill without human choice and also spiral out of control. This is also what the SPD in the European Parliament calls for in its recently adopted core thesis paper on European security and defence policy. The development of autonomous weapons systems, which has already begun, must therefore be stopped as a matter of urgency. We must prevent technologies from coming into the markets to which the current human rights law does not apply and which raise previously unanswered moral and ethical problems. I therefore welcome the fact that the European Parliament is already opposed to the promotion of such weapons systems through the European Defence Fund.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What are we talking about today? Artificial intelligence is so advanced that there is a risk that it could slip away from us. This will lead to job losses in the industrial sector – which is bad enough – but in the area of autonomous weapons it is literally a matter of life or death. Systems are already on the market that can target, track and destroy incoming missiles without human action. But these weapons have at least been programmed by man. But now we are still working. The next step is algorithms, where humans no longer play a role at all. Now the autonomous drone alone decides whether or not to destroy a target it recognizes. We therefore urgently need to put in place appropriate regulations to prevent these systems from being used unchecked. In addition, the European Union must press internationally for moral and ethical responsibility to always remain with people when any weapons are used.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, recognising that fully autonomous lethal weapons are not fully operational yet, however the use of artificial intelligence is already playing an important role for military around the world. That is why I welcome that we are debating how we can shape international law and policies in this field, because far too often we are behind the curve. Given the EU’s ambition to be a global actor for international peace and security, my questions to the High Representative are: how does the Commission and the EEAS define ‘meaningful human control’ over autonomous weapons systems, and what type and what degree of human control? How do they propose we strengthen the precedent in international and disarmament law for banning weapons without human control; and with the intrinsic dual-use nature of emerging technologies, how do we achieve not hampering progress in civilian research and development while having lethal autonomous weapons internationally?

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all let me thank you, as I said at the beginning, for putting this issue on the agenda, but also for the clear indication of all of you to the need to continue this work and to engage in this dialogue we have started already, in particular with industry and researchers, but also civil society organisations, to first and foremost better understand what we’re talking about, because I think we all have more questions than answers in discussing issues that can have very complicated technical implications, that can themselves have very complicated impacts on the political decisions that need to be taken. So I think that here the core issue is to keep at the centre of the debate human control and human responsibility for whatever affects the lives and deaths of human beings. The very definition of lethal autonomous weapons is not fully clear yet, and this is why we should define the key element of human control. Sound technical work here is key to getting the political decisions right, also because we are discussing a new frontier, so at the time we are discussing the norms and the regulations and the legal framework for all of this, we need to be sure that we are discussing the right things that will come. This discussion is I believe crucial, even if at the moment there is no agreement at this stage on regulatory measures, which could include a legally—binding instrument or a political declaration. I think that the right approach here is to first of all focus on the content of what we need to achieve and then, I believe, the forum and the consensus on the instrument, I hope, will come. If the discussion on the forum takes the lead, we might end up with an empty instrument that is not supported by the most relevant actors, and that in itself would be a problem.  So when we talk about non—proliferation and arms control – as I said this is the new frontier – you can count on my full commitment to make sure the European Union, together with the Member States, all of them, works on this in a united, meaningful and substantial manner and, obviously, in doing that we will take into full consideration the positions expressed by this Parliament.  Thank you again for having this conversation going among policymakers and the expert community. I’m sure this will not be the last time we discuss this issue and I am fully committed to continuing this work together. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, 12 September 2018.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on elmar Brok's report on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the state of EU-US relations (2017/2271(INI)) (A8-0251/2018).

name: Elmar Brok
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Parliament. Today is 11 September, the anniversary of 11 September 2001, which killed 3 000 people by the terrorist attack. But this is also the day that led to Europe showing solidarity with the United States of America. Only once has Article 5 of the NATO Treaty been drawn, namely on this issue. That is why Europe's soldiers are still in Afghanistan today. In other words, when President Trump says that the European Union was created to harm America, we prove the opposite every day. And historically, it's wrong anyway. We should make it clear that we are continuing this solidarity, but we expect that, at the same time, there will be solidarity from the United States and that it will not be built in such a way that it is no longer a partnership, but rather degenerates into vassalism. Those who do not parry are subject to sanctions or indirectly with extraterritorial measures. It is the ally, even on trade issues, that follows American policy, and not that something can be done in partnership. This is a major threat in the face of world political developments. The West is moving farewell to a unified, global security architecture that includes not only security policy, but also trade policy and much more. As a result, China is the big winner of this game. As a result, the values of the West in this world will become weaker if we do not make conflicts of interest and cooperation here. I am glad that President Juncker has now managed to see negotiations conducted to avoid further action against Europe. But that's not all. I believe that this means that we continue to need NATO for Europe's territorial collective security, that we want cooperation, but that this also means that we need to get more on our own feet because of the uncertainties in the field of foreign, security and economic policy. I do not know whether the term 'autonomous sovereignty' is correct. But that we are less vulnerable, that we are growing more in strength to achieve partnership and to be recognised in it, and that, for this reason, when it comes to 'America First' policy, we need to be clearer in the area of security policy, not just discuss 2%, 2% more money for the military without the European measures. , creating synergy effects that have to do with PESCO and these issues makes little sense. Then it will only become a purchase programme for American weapons in Europe, for which this money is used. I do not believe that this will lead to the strength we must have. I believe that the pressure measures that are constantly coming to Europe, the measures that mean that we want to do less with Europe than with Member States, because we can do more deals with individuals in their own interests, that we need to see that we need a common policy towards Africa, that we have to see that the European Union has a security strategy. , which is more comprehensive. We are spending far more money from the EU budget alone on civilian external aid rather than on the gain of stability than the United States. If you add the money from the Member States, it is huge: 60% of the world's development aid is provided by the European Union. What we have done with the enlargement of the European Union, what we are doing towards Ukraine and other countries, is all that security policy we are pursuing, and we must take that into account accordingly in order to achieve a fair burden-sharing in this way. When we talk about trade surpluses, we have to say that if we take the current account and take the primary gains that come from other areas, then that is roughly in a tie. In other words, we need more common ground, more European strength, in order to get the European Union and the United States closer again ..... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bernd Lange
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Yes, in fact, I believe that the European Union must very clearly reject what President Trump is saying. Just last week, that the European Union was just as bad as China, only smaller, really does not correspond to the facts.  We, as the European Union, are a fair trading partner. This fair trading partner does indeed have a trade surplus on goods.
