text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the escalation of tension that we experienced last week, and which will probably continue around Tripoli, is a sign of the great instability in the country between the various militias present in Tripoli and outside the capital and the real difficulties in which al-Sarraj finds himself. I think I can say that the Skhirat agreement is now becoming more and more distant. Now, there is no question of the European Union's commitment in recent years, but I think that the main task we have today is to help define a new roadmap for Libya, involving all the internal and external actors, including the militias that were not called into the Skhirat Agreement. The European Union's action in this respect is also decisive for the Member States. A clear message must be given to the Italian Government: get out of this migratory obsession and focus much more on the need to play a political role in libya's geopolitical framework, starting with the November conference. And it is French good to remind the Government that it will not get a stabilisation process under way if it wants to play the Libyan game alone. In conclusion, I think that the European Parliament – the President has now left – should promote an initiative in Brussels. We must have as our time horizon next spring, within which the institutional paths can be implemented.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Commissioner, for raising this issue and, of course, constantly forcing us to think again and again about our framework in Europe. Europe has a great advantage in terms of the global situation, historically, economically, weather and in many other ways. But Libya as a reliable partner, some will wonder? We must act together as the European Union and perhaps act as a valuable mediator, Commissioner Mogherini. Cooperation between the Member States is very important here. We must share responsibility – responsibility, after we as Europe have benefited greatly. Raw materials are only a very small part of it. If we are talking about an emergency now, part of it could be our emergency centre. Today it is Libya. The real need is probably much greater. A plan, a plan for the future: responsibility creates a completely new partnership relationship. How can Libya experience us Europeans as partners, free from strategic-military objectives, free from exploitation, free from demands that will never again allow Libya to find independent security? Libya as a first step against the great plight of the world.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow President Juncker will propose to federalise the EU's borders, not to put an end to the deaths at sea with a policy of rescues and resettlements, but to facilitate returns. I would therefore like to address the Commission: I would like to know how many deaths are needed because you realize that you are jointly responsible for them, having ousted the NGOs, without reducing the leaks. The push factor is stronger than the pull factors.  I would like you to remember the UN reports: they have been saying for two years that Libya is not a safe country. You say that sometimes, too. So why fund jailers disguised as border guards, why support an Italian policy of refoulement that began long before Salvini and was already condemned six years ago by the Strasbourg Court? The only thing you won't be able to say is: we didn't know the death toll from the arrivals.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, the time has come to lower the mask of hypocrisy. It is painfully clear that in Libya, years later, the essential process of dismantling and incorporating individual militias into a single army has never begun. Militias that are still masters of the territory, dictate the steps to politics and help support a lucrative situation of organized anarchy. The perverse spiral is all too clear: as long as they know that we need them to get rid of the migrant problem by hiding it, they will have a very powerful weapon of blackmail to gain political support and money. Pecunia non olet. There is no shortage of funding on both sides, and as long as they receive support from regional powers, and also from European countries, they will have the constant illusion that they can, if not win militarily, at least maintain a privileged position. This dismantling and unification will be a chimera, an evil and disintegrating game by actors who selfishly try to favor one group at the expense of another, only to be able to increase their influence. And it is time for them to tell us something about this too, such as the crazy idea of holding elections without security and without a legal framework. Some students don't really learn anything from history. In addition, there are other factors of instability: a resurgence of pro-Gaddafi supporters, the growing influence of the Radical Salafite Group of Madkhalists and the very serious situation in Fezzan, where endogenous militias are joined by rebel groups from neighbouring countries, as well as the consolidated presence of Al Qaeda and Isis militiamen.  We must strengthen the enlarged regional cooperation with the G5 Sahel, of course, but these tasks that we have abroad must first of all begin to do them at home. Without a compulsory preventive and permanent redistribution system, without a truly common asylum system and legal access routes, we will continue to feed libya's vicious circle. We need a real unity of purpose, a European position free from special interests, which we hope will finally reach the Rome Conference. Only in this way, avoiding the usual dangerous solo matches, we will be able to do not what is easy, but finally to do what is right.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, Libya is in a very serious situation: its government of national unity, recognised by the international community, is failing to maintain order. Tripoli has just been ravaged by fighting between two armed groups that are theoretically under its authority. Everywhere, Libyan territory is occupied by militias, many of whom are Salafists. Libya has become both a beacon of Islamist terrorists, a base of migrant smugglers and a dangerous state that seeks to destabilize its neighbors, notably Algeria. In such a context, to imagine that elections could be held there in December is an illusion. We must return to reality and put pressure on Libya to restore a minimum order on its territory, if necessary by demanding in return for our financial assistance the implementation of a real recovery plan.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this debate. I know that the Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies attach particular relevance to the Balkans, but the Mediterranean is also a priority. These are our southern neighbors, who have experienced very important events over the past decade. The presence, the european Union's aid are very much required. I saw him recently in Tunisia, where I travelled with the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Libya has been going through a very serious crisis for years. The political solution is kept waiting for the clashes and internal divisions and also for the faced interests of other Arab countries. The European Union must continue to accompany the efforts of the United Nations and the special representative for a political solution.  Unfortunately, the ceasefire achieved in Tripoli a few days ago is very precarious, very fragile: it seems to be jumping through the air. But there are also emergencies elsewhere, Mrs Mogherini; for example in Syria, but I know that the European Union there is no longer a relevant player. Others meet. And I conclude with a positive note: to highlight the importance of our relations with Morocco, a reformist and deeply pro-European country.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the progress that you and your team are making in very difficult circumstances, particularly on trying to empty the detention centres, which we saw as a Parliament delegation recently. Of course, what we saw was that the vast majority of people currently in those detention centres have actually been intercepted at sea and returned to Libya. So here is the paradox, because this is who we are dealing with. They are now trapped and arbitrarily held in these closed centres throughout the detention matrix. We are in a very difficult position in our discussions with the IOM and UNHCR. Last week we had a very difficult discussion, because on the one hand, we’re discussing disembarkation platforms for the future, and now the UNHCR has issued an updated position saying migrants rescued or intercepted at sea should not be returned to Libya. Really, what I want to ask you is: what do we do now? How are we criminalising NGOs, what do we do about the Libyan coastguard? I only have one minute, but I really have to ask you to go into more depth on these very difficult questions for the immediate future, because without doing this, we stay in this very difficult situation. No one is saying that you are not making progress on the tough questions, but we really need the answers on these more difficult immediate questions.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, one hundred more people have died today off the Libyan coast. One hundred more people, it's said fast. It would be chilling to know how many people have died since we talked about Libya in this Eurochamber. How many people have died, without our policies not only doing nothing to prevent it, but normally doing the opposite, justly favoring these deaths?  This summer, the Council discussed the possibility of giving more money to Libyan armed gangs to be a coastguard - 5 billion to be border police - and the creation of detention centres paid for with European money which are real concentration camps. When that was discussed, I was at sea on a ship of these NGOs that criminalizes Europe, with those rescued people who, if they could be looked in the face, ladies and gentlemen, if they could look them in the face and listen to their horror stories in Libya, would not be able to push the button to continue supporting these criminal policies that are making the Mediterranean the largest mass grave in the world. Our policies are staining our hands with blood. Keep that in mind, ladies and gentlemen, keep that in mind when you vote.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I very much appreciate you also dealing with the problems of immigration as well; but right now I would like to address the high representative and thank her for not giving in to work and support for Libyans, because they deserve it as much as the people who are forced to pass through Libya, who suffer with libyans. I believe that is what every time we make a speech in this House, and while Mr Urbán was at sea with the NGOs , which we have also proposed precisely for the Sakharov Prize - we entered Tripoli precisely to say not only that the centres had to be closed, that IOM and UNHCR had to be supported to help migrants leave voluntarily , that there was the agreement signed with Niger but that Member States are not fulfilling their obligations to remove those who cannot even ask to return to their places of origin. And, therefore, I think it is important that the voice of libyans is also heard in this speech, because we saw that the small steps, the policy of small steps that may seem to some criminals, is the opposite: that is, you cannot change everything, but the fact that the coastguards are framed by lifelong learning , makes it possible for NGOs to receive, disembark and give them a kit and register returnees. In other words, such an approach is possible.  We have also been able to visit the centres and verify and support those who should (and could) return. And, moreover, libyans, those who can and speak to us and with whom we had the opportunity to speak, also told us that they needed the European Union to have a stronger approach; not only observation, which we know is our role right now, but take it a step further and have a mediation role. They're asking us. I believe that the ceasefire agreement is very fragile, it has been broken again these days; but even so the words that are collected, the nerve centres and the obligations imposed on armed groups, which are the ones who are now lording — among other things also because they are looking to the future what their location will be — all of them are calling for more European policy, that European policy which, as Mrs Valencian said, we need to be definitively remembered in Salzburg.

name: President. –
text: Mr Urbán Crespo, I saw that you showed a blue card and I know that you have very good knowledge in the field. I let everybody speak a little bit longer so, if you don’t mind, I will not open this procedure because we are running late. Do you agree to this? It is the same as in the previous debate with no catch—the—eye and no blue cards. Thank you very much for your understanding.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in these hours, confirmation has arrived of another terrible shipwreck off Libya, with more than 100 missing, including twenty children and twins. Already 1,540 dead this year. According to the UNHCR, one in 18 people dies. Mortality has increased as a result of the shameful policies of closed ports, criminalisation of NGOs and outsourcing of our responsibilities to Libya, which was also criticised yesterday by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights. Instead, we need legal and safe routes for access to all EU countries and a European search and rescue mission. You are committed to emptying Libyan prisons but, as a result of these policies, the number of migrants detained has more than doubled from March to July. Libya is not a safe country and it is not a safe haven. The agreements with Libya, as we have always denounced, have forged those militias that are now inflaming Tripoli and creating further instability. The funds and training of the Libyan coastguard, which does not save lives at sea and violates human rights, are immediately interrupted. Madam High Representative, I would ask you to make every effort to give the EU a single, strong voice over Libya, which will overcome opposing national interests in order to stop complicating the crisis and to work with the international community on a peaceful and lasting solution.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the interests of Libya and of its people and those of the European Union are convergent if not identical. The country needs to go back as soon as possible to a strong and stable governance that will maintain national coherence to the Libyan borders while taking into account the expectations of the different forces present – this by bringing as many of them as possible to participate in running the country. The coming elections should be a crucial step in approaching this state of affairs, which is why it is important to ensure not necessarily that elections are held as soon as possible but that they are run transparently, with the widest possible agreement with Libya as to their relevance. As recent events in Tripoli confirm, there are still huge security problems that have to be overcome. Unless this has been done, the elections will be undermined. First things first: the interests of the Libyan people before other interests. The European Union should, without pre-judgment therefore, maintain dialogue with all non-terrorist organisations in Libya and support elections that will, realistically and as fairly as possible, provide the platform for the establishment of a governance that could bring back to Libya stability, peace and prosperity.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I started this debate by saying I hope, I trust that this debate tonight will give not only Europeans but also the Libyans the picture of a united European Union. Can I start by saying you’re 22 in this Hemicycle tonight discussing Libya, and I think you expressed at least 15 different positions. You’re asking me to represent a strong, united European position. If I had to represent your views (and it’s not my job), it would be a difficult task. This is to make you understand that the effort we are trying to do is to represent a united, strong – not only political – position, but action: action, with Libyans, putting the interest of the Libyans first, not the interests of one group, or one militia or one militia against the other, but the Libyan citizens. Because you are perfectly right: reality on the ground is different from the theory of the negotiations. But those thousands of Libyans that have been registering to vote in the last months are asking for normality in their lives and are knowing very well that the state doesn’t exist, has never existed in Libya. But they want it. They want the oil revenues to benefit a normal organisation of services. They want the richness of their country and their natural resources to benefit normal people. They’re asking for a normal life, and this is our first thought; this is what guides our action: trying to create the unity that maybe you cannot find in this Hemicycle – I hope yes – but among our Member States. And let me be very clear on elections, because I have heard your voices and I know very well what is the current debate, especially among commentators and in the media about that, but we do have a clear, common European Union position that I have been expressing in these months, including to our Libyan interlocutors and on which we have been working with the UN special representative in these months on a daily basis, which is that elections will need to take place first of all in a sustainable security environment. Secondly, with a clear constitutional and legal framework: Libyans need to know for what they are asked to vote. And we need to have the reasonable certainty that all different stakeholders will accept the result of the elections the day after the elections. Then it’s not for anybody else to define the date; that is why we have an electoral committee that we are supporting, because we want the Libyans to run the process, to decide the process, but they need our help, they need our support, from the basic financial need to have computers in the offices to the even more basic need to have offices, because with the attack they had in May, they couldn’t even use the offices anymore. So we are doing this work, we’re trying to empower the Libyans to decide for themselves and to try to help the United Nations to run this difficult political process in a way that gives an answer to the demand of the Libyan people to have institutions that function, which is, I think, a natural expectation of anybody in the world. And I will continue discussing this and working on this, not only with the UN special representative Salamé in New York in a couple of weeks’ time, but also with our Libyan interlocutors and with the main regional players, because what is essential is that we coordinate this work not only with the UN, not only among ourselves in the European Union, but also that we coordinate with the neighbouring countries, with the African Union and with the Arab League. And believe me, it’s quite something. But I think that, on the support of the process of political transition, compared to a few years ago, we have a better international and regional understanding of the needs that need to be addressed. On migration: for me personally it’s quite painful, after all the fights and all the work I have personally tried to make in these years, swimming against the, how do you say, nuotando controcorrente (I ask the help of the translators). And you know very well that the mainstream in the European Union Member States and even in this Parliament is not to put focus and priority on saving lives. This has been my priority, and this is why today we have Sophia at sea that is fighting the traffickers, trying to train the Libyan coastguards, together with the NGOs and with the UN humanitarian agencies that are doing the training. We cannot be selective on when we like the UN agencies or the NGOs and when we don’t, or when we ignore that they’re working with us. We cannot can pick and choose. The work we’re trying to do is exactly because we know there’s a problem. You can forget it and complain and do nothing, or you can try to engage and you can try to have a different kind of picture. Is it perfect? Far from it. Is it better than before? Starting to get better and may be at risk of getting worse now again, because the fight against militias is creating a different kind of dynamic. But this is the reason why we have added to the mandate of Operation Sophia the training of the Libyan coast guards, including on human rights standards and including with the UN agencies and with the NGOs, because we want that to start to be part of the DNA of the extremely limited institutional work that is done there. Because we cannot say we need to empower the Libyans without interfering and then say it’s useless, they cannot run either the country nor the territorial waters. It’s a contradiction in terms. So what we need to do is to work with them on the international standards and try to upgrade the levels not only of efficiency but also of respect of human rights. This is the same kind of work we have been doing and we are continuing to do in extremely difficult conditions on the detention centres, where we finally managed – together with the African Union, which I want to thank, and together with the IOM and UNHCR, which I’d like to thank, because when we started this work, they were not even present in the country, and we are there together. When we started this work a couple of years ago, I remember perfectly well the first meetings we had with the UNCHR and the IOM, and they were telling us: ‘no way we’re going back to Libya, we’re not there, we’re not operating there, we only have a few local staff.’ And we have been working together in these years to bring them back, to be ourselves back (and finally we are), and to work with our African partners. I fully share with you – and I said it at the beginning – most of our Member States are not doing their part, especially when it comes to giving international protection to those in need. The issue of the refugees that are entitled to protection that are in Niger needs to be addressed by Member States. There’s an engagement, there’s a commitment that needs to be respected. That’s clear. And I appreciate you raising your voice on this as well as – I have heard that much tonight from you on this, but I trust we agree on that – on the resources we allocate for our partnership with countries of origin and transit, because they need our support in this. So priority number one is to diminish the number of people dying inside Libya, at sea, and in the desert before they enter Libya. Second is also reducing the number of migrants arriving, because we are working in destroying the system of business of the traffickers. These are the objectives we have. Is it easy? Is it accomplished? No, it’s not easy and it’s not accomplished yet. But the trend compared to when we had nothing – no European Union policy or presence on this fight (and that was just four years ago, I would like to remind you all: you were here) – there was no policy at all. No European Union presence at sea at all, at land at all, no work on this file. It was left to single Member States. But by the way: change in government, change policies. So I think that we need to keep working very hard on this, keeping in mind first and foremost the facts some of you have mentioned. We cannot talk about Libya only because we are worried about the migrants. I agree with you: there is some frustration. My experience is this: the biggest frustration of the Libyans is when we remember that Libya exists only in relation to the number of migrants arriving in Europe, whereas they’ve been suffering for years, for different reasons: first because of a dictatorship and then because of a state of conflict, and they deserve to have a normal country and a normal life. (Applause)

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the context of the extremely precarious and volatile situation in Libya, the European Union is constantly encountering the problem of the libyan authorities' inament with the state's high authority, thus the impact of any attempt at stabilisation is questionable. It is in the European Union's interest to have a stable government in Libya that can get the country back on its feet and deal with migrant waves. The situation in the Mediterranean is closely linked to the ability of the Libyan authorities to react, and Europe must therefore seek to keep the situation under the control of the Government in Tripoli and to stop the activities of people smugglers. We must acknowledge that the problem is directly in Italy, but because of the secondary movement of migrants, it is a challenge for the whole of Europe. The stabilisation of Libya, and more broadly the North African states, is in the fundamental interest of European countries and the issue should also be given weight in the Commission's external action.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Next point is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the risk of destruction of Han al-Ahmar and other Bedouin villages [2018/2849(RSP)]

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this is one of those endless evenings we spend together. It is a pleasure. We have another debate after this, but I have got used to that now. On this debate, I want to say seriously that I share the sense of urgency that has made you call for this debate. The demolition of this small Palestinian village would not only affect a local community, as one would think; it would also be a blow against the viability of the State of Palestine and against the very possibility of a two-state solution.  The Israeli High Court last week rejected the petitions by the residents of the Palestinian village of Khan al-Ahmar and allowed the Israeli authorities to proceed with the plans for demolition within seven days. Any day now, the Israeli authorities could start demolishing this community and evict the residents from their homes, including parents and children. This is why last week I called once again on the Israeli authorities to reconsider this decision. That demolition would have grave humanitarian consequences and it would be contrary to Israel’s obligations under international humanitarian law, including the Fourth Geneva Convention. The demolition of Khan al-Ahmar, together with plans for further settlement expansions in the same area, would also severely threaten the viability of the two-state solution, as I said. The village is located in the so-called ‘E1’ area, which is of strategic importance for preserving the contiguity of a future Palestinian state.  The European Union and its Member States have been crystal clear about their opposition to this demolition. The Foreign Affairs Council has systematically drawn attention to the plight of Bedouin communities in the West Bank and has repeatedly stated its strong opposition to Israel’s settlements policy. Such a policy is illegal under international law, including the demolitions of Palestinian communities and the possible forced transfers of population. These are positions we share completely, as demonstrated by the European Parliament’s resolution in May last year. The EU and its Member States expressed their concerns about the imminent demolition through repeated statements, démarches and ministerial letters to the Israeli authorities, and the representatives of several Member States were present at the village on 5 July when the Israeli forces attempted to cordon it off. Until now, these efforts have been to no avail. Israel claims that the community has been built without the required building permits. It is important to note, however, that it is virtually impossible for Palestinians to obtain any building permits in Area C of the West Bank, as confirmed by the quartet report we produced in July 2016. We Europeans, together with our international partners, have worked intensively to speed up the approval of master plans in Area C, but again, with little success. Israeli authorities have advanced plans for thousands of new settlement units, including attempts to regularise buildings that have been built without any permit or planning in Israeli settlements. This is the situation on the ground: new settlements for Israelis are built, while Palestinian homes in the same area are demolished. This will only further entrench a one-state reality, with unequal rights for the two peoples, perpetual occupation and conflict. The two-state solution is today under serious threat – more than ever before – and yet there is no realistic and viable alternative that would end the conflict and achieve a just and lasting peace. This is also mainly, I would say, in Israel’s interest.  This is why the European Union does not and will not give up on a negotiated two-state solution. We will continue our engagement on the ground in support of building a viable Palestinian state, in support of the essential work that UNRWA (United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East) is doing, and in support of projects that keep the perspective of a two-state solution alive. Several Member States are involved in the funding of Khan al-Ahmar, in particular, the tyre school. Thanks to their engagement, hundreds of Palestinian children have been able to go to school and receive quality education, and I am glad that the European Parliament is also asking the Israeli authorities not to implement the decision to demolish and not to strip an entire Palestinian community of their homes and their children of the school. Again, I stress this: this would not be in the interests of Israel itself.  Any irregularity issues in the community should be solved in dialogue with its residents and not through demolition and displacement. All energy and resources should go into seeking political solutions for achieving peace, not into creating more grievances, which will only perpetuate the conflict.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Madam High Representative, my group has not supported the addition of this debate to the agenda. We have not been in favour because we believe that an isolated discussion of one aspect or another related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict cannot lead to a balanced debate. Such a debate on an isolated aspect will not contribute to a lasting peace in the Middle East, which remains our ultimate goal. Our efforts would be better invested if Europe became more involved in the peace process. Secondly, for us, the European Union - through the declaration that you yourself made on 7 September - has taken a fairly clear position on the threat of the demolition of Khan el-Ahmar. The European Union's position on Israeli settlements is also well known, including in terms of demolitions and possible transfers of Palestinian populations. Now, where there is a fairly broad agreement, I believe, in our Parliament, is on the need to find a decent solution for the situation of these people. They have been in makeshift facilities for years, where safety and safety conditions are very difficult to bear. These facilities were declared illegal in 2009 by the Supreme Court and since then much effort has been made to find an alternative with the Israeli authorities with the proposed resettlement in Jahalin West. Moreover, the recent decision of the Supreme Court, rejecting the complaints of the inhabitants of Khan el-Ahmar, acknowledges these efforts and expresses the hope that a solution can be found peacefully and by mutual consent. I add the fact that I have seen the text of the joint resolution proposed by some groups. We will not support a text that goes all the way. We want to focus on this aspect in accordance with the position already expressed by the High Representative. I think it doesn't make sense to do a mini-report with things that don't help us solve this problem.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr Preda's negotiating will has become clear before the negotiation begins. I suppose Mr. Preda, when he talks about residual aspects, is thinking of the 180 inhabitants of this small village. Of these 180 inhabitants, most are children and teenagers who will be expelled from their land, who live in wooden tents, with plastics, without water... precisely because the Israeli authorities deny them the right to a moderately dignified life. They are victims of a perverse system in which the occupiers—the settlers—have all the facilities, and the occupied are forced to live in unbearable conditions. I suppose Mr Preda refers to this collateral aspect of the lives of human beings who, because they are few and weak, should care nothing.  What is the crime of these people? None. They have done absolutely nothing, they only annoy Israel's expansionist plans. And for us, the expulsion of the local population by the occupying force is a serious violation of human rights. By the way, for us and for international law. That is, it is a violation of international law on the part of Israel. That's what we're talking about. Of course it goes far beyond a specific situation of 180 specific people, although it is already worth making this statement alone.  We share many values with Israeli society and, from that position, we want to ask the Government of Israel to stop the demolition of the people of Jan al-Ahmar. Stop this policy that makes innocent people suffer, based on flagrant non-compliance with international law and respect for human rights. We ask Mr Netanyahu's government with respect.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – During the summer recess, I paid a working visit to Israel's border strip with Gaza. There I saw the horrific consequences of Palestinian arson and rocket fire. With nostalgia, the kibbutz dwellers remember the bygone era of normal human contact with the Gazan people. Not a word of hate I heard. And passant continues the weekly hetze against Israel. That's why I went there to visit. Where is the voice of the European Parliament? It still sounds to Israel today, notabene because of the decision of the country's highest court against illegal construction in the Khan al-Ahmar area, despite all the generous, free government proposals to resettle the inhabitants. Where is the reasonableness of the EU and this Parliament towards the State of Israel? This debate only worsens relations between the EU and Israel, which my Israeli interlocutors are rightly concerned about this summer. In this way, we are increasingly eliminating ourselves as a credible player in the peace process. And that's sad.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the date of demolition of the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar represents just another step by the Israeli authorities towards a situation where reaching a real and not just hypothetical two-state solution to the long-standing Israeli-Palestinian conflict will not be possible anymore. This is the reason why Parliament should echo the statement of the High Representative as well as the joint statement by France, Germany, Italy and Spain. They have all called on the Israeli Government not to go ahead with its plan to demolish the village, including its school, and forcibly displace its residents. A couple of years ago I had the possibility to visit Khan al-Ahmar and listen to its inhabitants, who obviously knew a long time ago that their future had been sealed. Nevertheless, they have been using all legal possibilities to prevent a divorce scenario from happening. The decision of the Israeli High Court of Justice of 5 September did not come as a surprise, either for the Bedouins or for us. Israel is once again proving that it does not abide by international law, notably the 4th Geneva Convention, which prohibits the forcible transfer of a population unless the security of the population or imperative military reasons so demand. With our resolutions, we will once again call on the Israeli Government to put an end to its policy of humiliation, threat and demolition against the Bedouin communities and Palestinians living in the West Bank. This is definitely not in Israeli interests.

name: Margrete Auken
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to remind the Vice-President / High Representative, that you started your mandate, Ms Mogherini, by telling this House that the Israeli-Palestine conflict was your foreign policy priority.  You told this House that you would not accept any more demolitions of EU-funded projects. You told this House that you would do all you could to uphold international law and preserve the two-state solution. And what has this House witnessed under your mandate? No EU initiatives. An EU Special Envoy has gone missing in action; EU aid worth millions of euros destroyed in full impunity and no adequate labelling of settlement products.  The village of Khan al-Ahmar that I and countless friends of the Bedouins have visited is about to be destroyed. You have warned of severe consequences. This is your moment to save your record on this file, and that of all Europeans. Will you take action at last? If not, then when?

name: Martina Anderson
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the barbaric and insidious Israeli occupation of Palestine is the problem. All other catastrophes are the symptoms. Not content with stealing Palestinian land and building their own illegal settlements, the State of Israel continues to destroy people’s homes on an industrial scale.  Khan al—Ahmar is the most recent in a series of planned village destruction. The Bedouin residents, who valiantly fought the planned destruction for years, have suffered disproportionately because of this apartheid policy. To add insult to injury, the Israeli State plans to forcibly relocate the inhabitants to a site right next to a public rubbish dump. This House likes to think it stands up for political freedom and democracy. You would imagine, then, that all here would condemn – without reservation or equivocation – illegal occupation, illegal settlement construction and illegal destruction of property.  Recently we heard that Israel has prevented Ahed Tamimi from leaving Palestine. Where else would a state restricting the movement of a political opponent be tolerated? You would imagine that the EU High Representative would act decisively and go beyond fluffy words. I won’t hold my breath. Now more than ever, Palestine needs our support. With the Trump Administration actively undermining the two-state solution, the EU more than ever has a role to play in advancing peace and justice in the region. Inaction is acquiescence. Mere rhetoric with no follow—up in these cases of supreme human rights violation means only one charge is viable: rank hypocrisy.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Israel's decision to demolish the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar in the occupied West Bank serves only one objective: to seize bedouin land to expand existing illegal settlements that will also lead to the final division of the West Bank. In this way, Israel controls the territory and natural resources in Palestine while annexing East Jerusalem, while building the illegal wall in the West Bank and keeping the Gaza Strip under siege for more than ten years. Instead of ending Israel's occupation, it legitimizes it by continuing to expand settlements, by attacking the Palestinian people, by demolishing schools and houses, by imprisoning children, killing and raping. At last, the European Union, Madam High Representative, must react decisively; it must take action; it must put pressure on Israel not to proceed with the demolition of the Bedouin community and appeal to the Bedouin Palestinians for the third time. That is why we must take all measures to stop settlement, to bring about peace and finally to promote the two-state solution.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I shall contribute to compensating for our being behind schedule, and use less than five minutes, because I think I took more time in the introduction, when I said everything I had to say on this. As I said, Khan al-Ahmar is located in the ‘E1’ area, which is essential for the future of a Palestinian state. It is essential for the prospect of the two-state solution, and so we will continue to raise our strong concerns about Israeli settlement activity, as well as the demolition of Palestinian communities and livelihoods. We have repeatedly expressed our strong opposition to Israel’s settlement policy and actions taken in this context, including the forced transfer of Bedouins. I would add that Israel, as the occupying power, has humanitarian obligations vis-à-vis the Palestinian population in Area C, which it must meet, starting with halting demolitions and confiscations, and returning confiscated equipment and structures. We continue to call upon the Israeli authorities to reconsider their decision to demolish Khan al-Ahmar.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Six motions for resolutions have been sent to me in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 September 2018.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on bas belder's report on the state of EU-China relations prepared by Bas Belder on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (2017/2274(INI) (A8-0252/2018).

name: Bas Belder
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President. Under the absolute leadership of President Xi Jinping, the People's Republic of China is developing particularly dynamically and ambitiously internally and externally. Accurate tracing and interpretation of this complex process is necessary for a realistic European approach to close relations with Beijing. This report aims to make a responsible contribution to this. Thanks, much even, to the substantial input of the shadow rapporteurs. A crucial principle for solid EU-China relations is reciprocity. But please in all areas! In terms of market access, for example, but also in terms of press freedom. Reciprocity breeds mutual trust and forms a solid foundation of a strategic partnership between the EU and China that also deserves this promising name fairly. However, reciprocity is an ideal, and this report clearly points to this. In fact, the report makes no mistake that, from a European perspective, concerns about the policies of the sole Ruling Chinese Communist Party are growing. For example, when we talk about Tibet, Xinjiang, the sinification of all religions, the social credit system, the militarisation of the South China Sea, the law on international NGOs and the escalating tensions in relations with Taiwan, these are the sensitive issues of choice for Chinese censorship. This open view from the European Parliament on EU-China relations is appropriate, in addition to promoting European interests, the overall well-being of the citizens of the People's Republic. To use a winged official Chinese expression: a win-win situation on the ground of the citizens!  In the meantime, this report also encourages European self-criticism. China's ambitious global dynamism, and therefore to Europe (key word Belt and Road Initiative), urgently calls for a thoughtful European strategy. To name just one major challenge, Beijing is now considering northern and southern variants on our continent, following the controversial 16+1 format, with no less than eleven EU Member States from Central and Eastern Europe and five Balkan countries. Finally, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to underline the last sentence of paragraph 14 in the report: the strong promotion of our knowledge of China through substantial European support for independent think tanks of a high scientific level! I have been able to taste and benefit from such European expertise in the work on this report. From Berlin to Beijing! With the EU's adequate political application of in-depth knowledge of China and its people, I wholeheartedly want, a European dynamic will mate with the Chinese dynamics and promote balanced relations between the EU and China. Thank you very much. I have been very pleased to work on this report. It's my last year of office. But as long as I have health, my interest will certainly continue to be on the EU-China relationship, because we are dealing here with an extremely important trading partner and an emerging power on the world stage. I was moved and still impressed by the enormous expertise in the European delegation in Beijing. The participants really looked at the general European interests, but at the same time also took into consideration the overall, material and intangible well-being of the Chinese population. I mean this by mutual relations with a mutual view of each other.

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Madam President, the Committee on International Trade also worked on the EU-China report, together with the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and my thanks for the excellent cooperation go to rapporteur Bas Belder and Foreign Affairs Committee colleagues. The International Trade Committee appreciates the increasing role of China on the global stage. We call for responsible engagement on key issues such as WTO reform and climate change, to name but two. China has been very active lately in communicating new internal reforms and opening up various economic sectors. However, EU businesses in China do not report real progress on the ground. So China should complement its rhetoric with concrete measures to actually create the level playing field for European companies and investors, and especially for European SMEs.  To sum up my approach on EU-China trade relations, cooperation is needed rather than confrontation, but without compromises on any of the EU core interests.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I might take a few minutes more at the beginning but I promise I’ll be brief in my concluding remarks. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Belder, for a very balanced report which accurately reflects the state of EU-China relations and the key issues at stake. And thank you too, Mr Belder, for your work to find a broad consensus on such a strategic issue for Europe – one which in the past has been more divisive. This is a major achievement. I’m also glad to see that the report echoes the EU strategy for relations with China that we adopted two years ago and I am very satisfied with the work you’ve been doing with our delegation in Beijing and with all our teams working in China and with China. The European Union and China are two of the great powers of the world of today and we don’t always see eye to eye. On the contrary, we have some fundamental disagreements. They are very evident. But, as two global powers, we both understand that our cooperation is essential to address the main challenges we face. If we want to preserve the multilateral system and make it more effective, engagement with China is an absolute must. And I have to say I’ve seen, in the past six or seven months, very strong engagement from the Chinese side, and also from the European side, which I have been able to channel, working increasingly in the multilateral framework on global issues in general terms. In recent years, China has become much more active on the global stage and China looks to the European Union as a partner on many issues where our interests converge. Our cooperation is already intense on most foreign policy matters: we’re working together to preserve the nuclear deal with Iran; we both support the ongoing negotiations towards a reconciled and denuclearised Korean peninsula; we both want to see peace in Afghanistan and we are both actively supporting the Afghan Government’s efforts to bring forward the peace process. As you can tell from these examples, China sees the European Union now not just as a huge market and an investor, not just an economic player – the traditional view – but also increasingly as a global political player and a global security provider. Our security cooperation is getting stronger in various parts of the world. For instance, we cooperate on the ground in Mali and in Somalia, where we are both present with our security personnel. We work together in various parts of the world global issues, particularly in the UN framework. This summer, at the EU-China summit, we agreed a very substantial and ambitious statement on climate change, for instance. We have agreed to step up our cooperation to reduce emissions and implement the Paris Agreement. But even when our starting point is not the same, there is still room for working together and building win-win solutions. Take investment in Africa as an example. As you know, whenever we Europeans bring new investment to Africa we always bear in mind the Sustainable Development Goals. We want European investment to create quality jobs, to increase peace, stability and good governance in human rights, and to focus in particular on opportunities for women and youth. Everybody knows that China is already a major player in Africa. Our approach is not the same, but if we want to promote sustainable development and sustainable security in Africa, engagement with China is key to achieving results on the ground. Even if we come from different starting points we can explore the possibilities for trilateral cooperation among Europe, China and Africa and find common fields of work that are beneficial for all. Another good example is the ‘One Belt, One Road’ initiative. I believe we must not be afraid to engage with China, creating synergies between their initiative and our projects on connectivity. We believe that big infrastructure projects should, first of all, create opportunities and jobs in all the countries along the New Silk Road, and that these projects should be about sustainable development for local communities and not about crafting new spheres of influence. Only if we engage together with China can we make our interests, our goals, our vision and our connectivity converge. Both the European Union and China are part of the world’s economic G3, together with the USA. The choice ahead of us is straightforward. We could choose a conflictual approach, going for trade wars that would hurt everyone, or we can work together with China to make the global economic system more just and fair. We have a number of disagreements with China when it comes to trade – and I believe you have had the chance to discuss them at length, not only with me but also with Commissioner Malmström – ranging from the issue of over-capacity to intellectual property. Our choice is clear. We want to deal with these issues within the framework of a rules-based international system. We want our trade with China to be based on reciprocity and to be free and fair. This is the only way to achieve a solution that benefits both Europe and China, instead of going for a lose—lose trade conflict. Definitely we should go for the win—win solution, avoiding any scenario of a lose—lose confrontation. I believe we share the same approach here with China now on the need to find, or to build, cooperative win—win solutions and approaches, rather than entering on, or fuelling, the conflictual trends we are seeing. Dialogue and engagement are the best way forward for us, not just on trade but on all issues, when we disagree with China. I could mention – as you yourself – the situation in the South China Sea, or restrictions to freedom of expression in Hong Kong, and we regret that the dialogue with Taiwan has been frozen for the past three years. Of course, the most outstanding disagreement we have with China concerns the human rights situation in China as underlined in your report. During the last EU-China human rights dialogue we spoke up against the recent restrictions on freedom of religion, on minorities’ rights and on freedom of association and expression. We raised our position against the death penalty, as we always do with all countries that still have that penalty, and we discussed the impartiality of the justice system. We also focused on the situation in Xinjiang, especially the expansion of political re-education camps, and we discussed the detention of human rights defenders, including particular cases. We know that the Chinese Government does not share all our principles and values and they know that we are in different places in some issues. It is also very clear that we will not sacrifice our values in the name of ‘real politics’: we are always very clear on that. On the contrary, we will continue to engage with China precisely to advance our values and our interests, because Europe and China recognise and understand each other’s importance in shaping a more cooperative global order. I would say that this, in a nutshell, describes the state of play of our relations with China today. We recognise each other as fundamental key players on the global stage of today’s world. We know that, at this moment in world history, cooperation and engagement are simply the smartest choice and that, on some global and also some regional issues, if the European Union and China work together, this makes the difference in the world. Your report, Mr Belder, rightly points out that China is a complex partner, and our engagement takes different forms on different issues, but we should not be afraid of a more proactive and a more confident China. The Chinese look at Europe as a global power, and our dialogue can help the world to move beyond the current chaos towards a better global order. It is a dialogue based on clarity, on respect, and on our interests and values, and it can be one that benefits both Europe and China, as well as the rest of the world. I am glad this is also the spirit of your report, Mr Belder, and I’m glad that you built such consensus on what is a crucial issue for the present and the future of our continent.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, High Representative Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I am convinced that a strategic partnership with China is necessary, indeed a precondition, for us to achieve the objectives of the Paris agreement on climate change, after President Trump has terminated the agreement out of stupidity and pure profit-thinking.  China and Europe now need to work together even more to curb climate-damaging greenhouse gas emissions, but also to stimulate international trade and research. There is also a shared responsibility in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Conservation of Natural Resources. The concept of ecological civilisation recently adopted by the National People's Congress shows that China is living up to this responsibility.  I assume that, despite all the differences in political systems, Europe and China will work together to tackle the major problems on our planet. Europe will benefit from China and China from Europe. China may be a red dragon, but a peaceful one. It is certainly not the so-called yellow danger. And President Xi Jinping is also likely to be more reliable than the infantile climate denier Trump.

name: Julia Pitera
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab China is the European Union's second largest trading partner and the Union is China's largest trading partner. The ambitious 'One Belt and One Road' initiative requires cooperation on the assumption that China will create an open platform that meets market principles, EU and international standards. It is also important that cooperation between central and eastern European countries and China under the 16+1 format is transparent and does not adversely affect the cohesion of the Union. In the context of building Eu-China relations, this year's decision by the All-China Assembly of People's Representatives is of concern. The abolition of the constitutional two-tenure of the President of the People's Republic of China cemented his power and increased the control of the party's organs over the state apparatus, reversed the process of structural change and could have a negative impact on the state of human rights and the rule of law.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Mogherini, this is Parliament's second report on EU-China relations. This shows that we attach greater importance to this issue, and I would like to thank Mr Belder and the other shadow rapporteurs. In fact, we have reached 27 compromises, and there are no amendments in plenary. So, this House has broad agreement on how we see China and how we are developing our relationship with China.  We have a strategic partnership with China and, of course, we have to define what that means. Are these just words or does it have any practical benefit? And the EU must ask itself: what are the fields in which we can also carry out this strategy with China? As has already been said here: climate protection is doing very well, and certain peace initiatives are also progressing quite well.  China has launched a number of initiatives where the EU is lagging behind. Mrs Mogherini, you mentioned the Silk Road or the gigantic investment programme in Africa. We do not really have an answer to that yet. I would also ask you how we deal with this. We lament at the Silk Road that it is a one-sided Chinese project. How do we get there as Europe? And in Africa, I read in the Global Times, the English edition of the official Chinese newspaper, that Europeans are doing the education and training of Africans and that China is doing the infrastructure projects. So we do not want such a division of labour. And we must commit China to international standards, including to the Sustainable Development Goals, which they have also signed. And there is the question of whether we have dialogues and whether there are signals that China is taking part in this. Well, the economy is still at the heart of our cooperation. Indeed, we must also protect ourselves where necessary because there are unfair conditions.  I would also like to mention the Internet and innovation. We see all sorts of discrimination. We cannot accept that either, we have to speak a hard language. Last but not least, the 19th Party Congress has developed a model that competes with our liberal model of democracy. And democracies really need to arm themselves against this export of authoritarian structures from China.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is good that the motion for a resolution on relations between the Union and China draws attention to the persecution of Christians in the country. Paragraph R refers to restrictions on religious activities and religious groups, which are subject to increasing repression in China, and Christians in both underground churches and state-approved churches are the target of persecution attacks. Unfortunately, this is true of the visual diplomatic words.  If we look at many other paragraphs of our resolution – and there are 92 of them – we will see how often they start by highlighting the EU-China Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (for example paragraphs 1 and 2) and that China is the EU's second largest trading partner and the EU is China's largest trading partner. And if so, it means that we can realistically influence not only through the provisions of the resolution, Mrs Mogherini, the Chinese partner, to stop the shameful persecution of Christians at all.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Belder for his comprehensive report. Undoubtedly China is one of the most important and valuable strategic partners of the EU. I warmly welcome the good progress which has been made by deepening the EU-China Comprehensive Strategic Partnership. I believe that the strengthening of this partnership will create many opportunities, and will have a significant global impact when it comes to addressing global challenges, common security threats, climate change, global economic growth and the promotion of multilateralism. On the other hand, the EU has pledged that human rights, democracy and the rule of law are at the centre of its relations with all third countries, including strategic partners like China. Unfortunately, China continues to have a bad human rights record. The authorities must stop their repression of human rights defenders, activists, ethnic and religious minorities. I strongly believe that strict restrictions on Muslim and Christian practices, including a complete ban of ethnic language and culture in the case of the Uighur language and minority, do not fit with China’s ambitions for leadership in a democratic and liberal world order and have been a real obstacle in our growing partnership.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am disappointed by what Ms Mogherini said. The language that the report speaks is completely different from the language you spoke, Ms Mogherini. You are sweet-talking China. You say there is a confident China. I see an overbearing China. You say the Taiwan dialogue has been frozen. I see the efforts from the Chinese side to strangle Taiwan. You say China does not share all our principles. In reality, China rejects completely all of our sacred principles.  You say we share the same approach and China is not fuelling conflictual trends. I see China fuelling so many conflictual trends. I do not know which China you are talking about. I think we should be speaking clearly and it would be nice to do so by starting to demand from China that they start pursuing a ‘One EU’ policy.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank mrs Mogherini for her work on this Nearly 47 years ago, the world was amazed when, after years of no relations and communication, Richard Nixon suddenly traveled to Beijing. The US wanted China as a partner in the fight against Russia. They were prepared to make economic concessions. None of this constellation is present today. If China prospers and has a strong influence on all world economic processes, after the social catastrophe of the Cultural Revolution, this is above all the self-determined way of guaranteeing social and economic progress to its population, which is almost one-fifth of the world's population. But this has implications for the entire world – for the economy, the environment, peace, resource consumption, international coexistence, and democratic constitution both internally and externally – and also requires political positions of all other partners. Much of the developments in China, the indivisibility of political and social human rights, and personal freedoms require justified criticism and open dialogue to resolve contradictions. For the European Union – and I have heard this from you, Mrs Mogherini – it is crucial to stick to the previous approach of working in partnership with China on rules-based solutions to the common challenges. There will be no way around this in the medium and long term, even if there are short-term differences of opinion. The EU should not succumb to the temptation to enter into trade deals at the expense of third parties, for example. This is deeply contrary to the interests of the citizens.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I'm going to do some pedagogy.  Why do I always talk about the Havana Charter? Because my colleagues may not know it, but it predates the GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) and the WTO (World Trade Organization). The Havana Charter was the first regulation of trade after the war, in 1948, 53 countries agreed.  The facts: the United States has a 375 billion deficit compared to China, it wants to reduce it to 200. Europe has had 170 in the last ten years, almost 1,500 billion. Why do we need to regulate trade? Because it means loss of know-how, unemployment, relocation and loss of sovereignty. On the WTO, China should not have become a member, but Paulson, president of Goldman Sachs at the time, had negotiated in return for the purchase of bonds, issued by Goldman Sachs. It does not apply reciprocity, it has not lifted tariffs, thirteen on average: three for Europe, thirteen for Europe, three in the other direction. It has more than 50 domains reserved, we do not have any. It refuses access to public procurement, we do not. So let's find a balance, this is necessary for world trade.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by welcoming the fact that the report being discussed today does not hesitate to criticise the appalling human rights situation that has been observed in China for years. Indeed, since our last report three years ago, there have been serious violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Above all, I want to draw attention to the massive repression of local religion and culture in minority areas. The Chinese authorities continue to prevent Tibetans from exercising their fundamental rights and it cannot even be said how many imprisonments for dissenting opinions have taken place in recent years. Regarding the situation in Xinjiang, the latest report shows that up to one million Uighurs are believed to be held in internment camps. In this context, I believe that a clear message must be sent to China: deepening the strategic partnership will also depend on concrete results in the field of human rights. I want to remind you how important it is to speak with one voice on the international stage on China, in order to avoid being in a situation like the meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva in June 2017.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Union has a strategic interest in relations with China and for this it has to engage in dialogue with Beijing on all azimuths, from global security to reciprocity in trade relations, from climate agreements to sustainable development policies, data protection, cybersecurity, synthetic drugs and other forms of organised crime coming from China or passing through China. A strategic relationship that is even more crucial when Trump's United States is a dangerous factor in questioning multilateralism and international destabilization. But this strategic relationship has to seek to build synergies in which we do not expect China to act consistently with its obligations from the outset as a member of the Permanent Security Council, a member of the WTO and on the basis of the agreements with the Union. And for that we, the European Union, cannot in any way exempt ourselves from talking about human rights, from making Beijing look at a counterproductive shot in the foot, it is unacceptable to internally repression of human rights activists, trade unionists, Uighur, Tibetan, Christian minorities, falun gong, whatever. The credibility of the global power that is China depends, it is concerned, by its influence or by the fears it inspires, from the outset in its own region, therefore in the Korean peninsula, Taiwan and the South Seas and which is projected globally. But in to have this win relationship, as Ms Mogherini says, we have to know what our strategic interests are as the European Union, we must know how to assert our strategic autonomy. However, it was not wary when these last years of neoliberal policies led several companies and critical sectors of the European Union itself and the Member States to become controlled by the Chinese Communist Party.  Over the past ten years, China has invested more than US$318 billion in assets in Europe and today controls critical infrastructure, ports, energy networks, telecommunications, even defence and security technology companies in Greece, portugal, portugal and other Member States. So while we do not really assume that this has to stop and the Commission has woken up, woke up late, but agreed, what I see is that the Member States have not yet woken up and there are many who continue to live in a mercantilist illusion about China.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The EU-China Summit in July 2018 called for a bilateral strategic partnership. As a member of the 16-plus Hungary also supports a partnership based on shared values and interests. Never mind the favourable development of our relations, the issue of democracy and the rule of law, the provision of political and human rights cannot be avoided.  China has experienced a steady decline in this area over the last five years. European democracy cannot negotiate with the Communist dictatorship. We must continue to stand up for Muslim Uighurs in Xinjiang Province, who are subjected to millions of political consciousness re-educations and deported from their homeland by the atheist Chinese regime. Uighur university professor Ilham Tohti was sentenced to life in prison just four years ago. Nor can we stand by and watch the brutal disenfranchisement of the Tibetan people. Respect for human dignity, human and community rights is an essential condition for the Chinese partnership that is desirable above it.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I think three steps are necessary. Firstly, China shoud be pulled into the complete system of international order, especially at a time when the Trump Administration is going to destroy it. Secondly, a structure of EU strategic interests should be created, especially in the areas of technology, trade, financial services and militarily sensitive issues. In this context, we need a clear strategy on how to support European values and the European political model. Thirdly, cooperation should be enhanced with China, especially in Africa, in the areas of investment, infrastructure projects, peacekeeping and conflict resolutions, but based on our social and environmental standards. This report is a welcome step towards those three strategic intentions of the European Union.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, China's rise in the world is one of the most important events of the past thirty years. The world stage has changed. We Europeans need to maintain a constructive relationship with China, and that does not mean abdicating our values or our interests, nor hiding our differences. China's collaboration is obviously very relevant to successfully addressing global challenges, such as climate change. On this possibility of bilateral problem-solving agreements in Africa or African countries, those triangular agreements which you mentioned, Mrs Mogherini, I am somewhat skeptical. But, finally, we are in a world where economic and trade relations have become globalized, and this economic openness and the momentum of trade have enabled China's great economic and social development; but we too are a great exporting power, and many jobs in Europe— I always say this — depend on our ability to penetrate trade, even in Chinese space. That's why we should try to reach solutions to our trade discrepancies, while avoiding dumping. And I stress— and I conclude — the need to conclude the bilateral investment agreement. I think it is essential to seek this balanced playing field for reciprocal investment, and I hope that the momentum given by the recent summit on 16 July will allow for an early conclusion.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Madam President. My appreciation goes to Mr Belder for his competent engagement on this file. We need to fully acknowledge the role that China plays currently on the global scene. We could build a strategic partnership with that country only if we are united in our policy towards it. We can further develop our trade relations, work on issues such as climate change, and also talk seriously about security issues. I am sure that we can benefit from such relations, but we cannot afford to be divided by a particular interest. We need to be realistic about relations with China. China is already inside the EU. Its soft power has impact on many countries in the EU in our close neighbourhood. We should be cautious, especially when it comes to its growing acquisition of critical technologies, investments and political influence in Europe. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of relations with Taiwan. We have a responsibility to call for peace and stability in cross-trade relations. Therefore, it is important to support all initiatives to resume the official dialogue between Beijing and Taipei. Thank you very much.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, thanks to Mr Belder, our approach to China is clear, critical and broad-based, but in general our relations with third countries must proceed from the balance between political and economic interests, on the one hand, and human rights, on the other hand. I am a bit worried that individual EU countries are conducting very different policies, often avoiding sensitive political and humanitarian issues. As a result, the EU’s fragmented approach to China risks giving the appearance of EU complacency regarding human rights there.  Second, we need to support actively the continuation of stability and peaceful relations between China and its neighbours, especially Taiwan. Therefore, we urge Beijing to refrain from taking any unilateral action to change the existing status quo and to stop military provocations in the Taiwan Strait.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, first of all, I thank my colleague Bas Belder for his report.  Although China presents the OBOR strategy as a strategy for economic cooperation, it was born in China's national security and defense agencies. OBOR is a strategy of economic expansion aimed at China's global dominance, a new world order, a reduction in us economic power and global influence. Moreover, the aim is to confront the European Union and the US.  The Chinese are not kidding, according to the Example of Greece: the seaport of Piraeus is already in the hands of a Chinese state company. We also have more examples: the production and transfer of Electricity in Portugal is also in Chinese hands. The 16+1 format targets eastern and central European countries as members of the European Union. China is turning into an internal force of the European Union, let us stop it. China is also a partner to be respected and welcome, but reciprocity and compliance with the rules are essential for a successful partnership.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I promise to be brief. I will do so also because I want to stress once again what I said in the beginning – my full appreciation for an excellent, very balanced report which, as I said, reflects perfectly well the state of play, the strategy and the policy we have with China, regardless of some interpretations of something I did or did not say in this Chamber.  It is obviously a complex partnership, a complex relationship, where neither of the two sides hides, or intends to hide, the differences and the disagreements – even the profound disagreements – we have. We have two completely different institutional and political systems, based on two completely different sets of priorities and values. That is clear, but it is not a mystery either for us or for the Chinese.  The point is that in the current geopolitical context of today, we are finding out more and more that on some issues that are of strategic relevance and priority for us, the European Union, autonomously determined, and for China, we have convergent views on some issues or possibly a convergence of interests that we can explore together, obviously in a very realistic way. We know very well how China approaches the rest of the world and the region. We are not shy in pointing out not only the differences, but also the problems when we see them, starting with the regional ones, from the South China Sea to others, but we also see the potential for cooperation in some other areas. Let me tell you, for instance, that the work that we do with China on Afghanistan has an added value that is real. The same goes for the work we are trying to do with North Korea. Obviously we have different viewpoints, but there is common ground and a common interest in trying to move forward a policy that is compatible. Let me stress two things that were raised here, namely our approach to two issues that are top priorities in China’s strategy and policy and where I see, finally – I think Ana Gomes was saying – an awakening on the Commission’s side and hopefully for the Member States as well.  One is the work we are doing with Africa on economic, infrastructure, energy and digital issues – on the non—traditional fields of EU-Africa cooperation. I think you will hear a bit about this from President Juncker tomorrow in the State of the Union speech. I will present, together with other colleagues in the Commission, the package we have adopted today in the College and about which President Juncker will speak tomorrow regarding our sustainable economic partnership with Africa. We are not doing it for China, but I think this response mirrors well the need we have to find potentially common ground or balancing ground when it comes to economic development in Africa. The same goes for connectivity. I do not know if I can announce this, but I think that I can. Next week we will present a communication in the Commission on connectivity between Europe and Asia, based on our European approach, where we will see very clearly the differences we have, and I mentioned some of them.
