One is to avoid investments playing into the hands of a few, or one, but ensure that they benefit the people and the communities of the countries concerned – this is especially important for Central Asia, but also for Europe – and that they respond to certain standards that are ours and not Chinese standards. So clearly there are differences, but there is also a convergence of interests in improving the connectivity between Asia and Europe. Coming from different points of view, we can on certain issues find common ground for work. I think this is exactly the spirit of the report, which highlights the differences – clearly, with no mystery and in a very candid manner – but also the potential areas for cooperation. That is why I would really like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done.

name: Bas Belder
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Madam High Representative, thank you very much for your appreciative words for this report. This is the result of cooperation with colleagues – first and foremost the shadow rapporteurs – but also all of those who have spoken. I appreciate that commitment very much. She was a support for me as rapporteur and I want to continue working on it, because the work with China continues. So I will continue to read quietly and hope to travel to Beijing again in this last year of office. Finally, I would also like to express my great appreciation for my political collaborator Walter van Liège, here to my left. He was my right-hand man, who read with him extremely accurately, thought along and also maintained contacts with colleagues. Because, let's face it, without a good staff, you'll soon feel "disentanged." I wasn't "disenhanded." I even had two hands that helped me.  Thank you again, ladies and gentlemen. My pleasure. I am also thinking of the meeting with the shadow rapporteurs. You've sharpened my mind. What do you want more as a Member of the European Parliament? I can also say to the home front that the European Parliament is working and thinking. In short, the 2019 elections are very important for the Member States and for the whole political process in which the European Union is located. I come from a critical environment in Europe, but I would like to emphasise one thing: the expertise and help I have received from the European delegation shows the added value of an excellently functioning, competent European embassy in a superpower such as China. I've wanted to underline that for a long time, and I'm going to do it with this one. Thank you very much!

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 September 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The world workshop of the future: it is the one that Africa is becoming "thanks" to the investments of the Chinese dragon. In ten years, Mlingotini's mud and straw houses and many small fishing villages along Tanzania's northern coast will be razed to the ground to make way for a $10 billion Chinese mega port. With its investments, China is changing not only the face of Africa but that of the world, without demanding political but only economic conditions. There's no doubt that the former Middle Empire is a global player we need to talk to, all the more so now that Trump has announced tariffs of another $267 billion on Chinese imports. Commercial interests must not, however, overshadow human rights, the indiscriminate repression of journalists, minorities and the use of the death penalty. I would like to thank the rapporteur for making it so clear that he calls for a clear European position on these issues. Europe must speak with one voice and leverage its negotiating power and defend democratic principles against Chinese influence.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Cooperation with China is both an opportunity and a challenge for the EU. First of all, the country is the Union's second largest trading partner. There is a steady increase in trade between the two partners, but increasingly the balance of trade in goods is distorted in China's favour. However, there are many areas where cooperation could bring mutual benefits. Beijing, through its presence in Africa, Afghanistan or Pakistan, could help stabilise these areas and reduce migration to Europe. Also in the face of Washington's increasingly isolationist policies, EU-China cooperation could contribute to finding solutions to global problems, such as climate change. However, there are many areas where this cooperation is no longer so seamless. Since 2008 China has acquired assets in Europe worth more than €300 billion, which shows the scale of their presence in the Union. Since 2016, the country has been a net investor in the Union, but as many as 68% of Chinese investment in Europe has been carried out by state-owned enterprises, which are primarily guided by political guidelines. China's public procurement market continues to be closed to European suppliers. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that the Commission should take action to develop, in cooperation with the Member States and the European Parliament, a common economic strategy for that country.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Mady Delvaux and Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on controls on cash entering or leaving the Union (COM(2016)0825 – C8—0001/2017 – 2016/0413(COD)) (A8-0394/2017).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would first like to thank my co-reporter Juan Fernando Lopez Aguilar and the shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation between the ECON (economic and monetary affairs) and LIBE (civil liberties, justice and home affairs) committees, which enabled us to arrive in a trilogue with a text of which I am quite happy, because it strikes a good balance between, on the one hand, , the effectiveness of national authorities' means of action and, on the other hand, the protection of citizens' privacy.  The Regulation on cash controls entering or leaving the EU helps to strengthen the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing by giving the competent authorities of the Member States, customs, the instruments they need to carry out their mission at the EU's external border. It establishes a system of control for persons entering or leaving the EU by carrying cash of EUR 10,000 or more, or equivalent to other currencies. The definition of cash obviously includes cash, but also gold or certain types of anonymous prepaid cards that are not linked to any bank account. A key role is, of course, the financial intelligence cells of the various Member States, which receive and process information from various sources and are therefore well placed to determine whether this money should be investigated further. This is why national information systems need to be interconnected and information to be made available quickly to the authorities. The European Parliament has also asked the Commission to consider whether it is appropriate to set up a financial intelligence unit at EU level. It is not a question of casting any suspicion on people who act in good faith, but it is not acceptable that within the European Union we do not have sufficient information on the sums that smuggle our borders because this information is dispersed between the Member States and the criminals rely precisely on non-cooperation between the authorities of the Member States. The regulation provides that a person with a sum of EUR 10,000 or more should make a declaration informing the recipient, the economic origin and the intended use of that money, and the competent authorities will have the opportunity to withhold the money on a temporary basis - under certain conditions, of course: when the obligation to report has not been met and when there are indications of criminal activity. This period of temporary withholding must be limited to the time required to decide whether further investigations are required, and of course a minimum amount should remain available to the bearer to enable him to support himself. In any event, the authorities are required to provide an explanation and describe the reasons for the temporary seizure. It is the Member States that set the sanctions for non-performance of the reporting obligation - they must be proportionate and effective - and the European Parliament calls on Member States to bring the sanctions applied at national level as close as possible, to prevent criminals from choosing the Member State of entry or exit in which the sanctions are the lightest. Finally, finally, I would like to mention that regular information campaigns should take place to remedy the current situation, where many people do not know that they are obliged to declare their cash beyond a certain amount.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, to this late night and until certainly after midnight, this Parliament finally debates legislative acts — European legislation — after a few hours of discussing strategic relations with third countries over which we have no legislative competence, we now discuss European legislation, and not less, certainly.  Firstly, a regulation – a directly binding rule – of border cash control, which is part of the european Commission's set of initiatives to respond to the counter-terrorism security emergency that took place, in general, throughout 2016, following the horrific terrorist attacks that swept through and devastated Europe in 2015. This is indeed a regulation in which Mrs Delvaux and I have worked together as rapporteur for the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and I am grateful for all the cooperation over this time and also for the willingness to meet with the Council, which has not been precisely available for any legislative commitment to the European Parliament during this mandate. But here it has been possible, as in the Directive on combating money laundering through European criminal law, that we will discuss immediately afterwards.  This initiative seeks to strengthen European responsiveness in the area of money laundering, illicit cash flow and asset freezing and confiscation. It does so through a Regulation which is part of the fight against transnational economic fraud, money laundering and, in particular, the financing of terrorism. The purpose is to address a legal basis (Article 114 of the Treaty on European Functioning, in combination with Article 33), which provides for the strengthening of customs cooperation between Member States and the Commission on cash control. With a legislative precedent, 2005, a Regulation which at the time established the control of cash — cash up to an amount of EUR 10 000 — but with clear flaws that we are now correcting. First, incomplete coverage of cross-border cash movements. It is a question of completing a full statement and that criminals who send cash or resort to employment modalities know that these troops will be better and more effectively controlled from now on.  Secondly, the difficulties of exchanging information between member state authorities, because until now there has been an obligation to make available to a State financial intelligence unit, but from now on there will be an active obligation — not just the making available — to transmit that information.  Thirdly, to address the impossibility of the competent authorities temporarily retaining the cash reaching the threshold set. Fourth, the definition of cash, which includes not only the amount of liquid money, but also other high-liquidity commodities, such as gold; information can therefore also be transmitted at border entrance. Fifthly, to respond to the wide disparity in sanctions applied by the Member States, the heterogeneity of the levels of implementation. In this report we have tried to address all these elements and, in addition, we have tried to have the cash statement completed regardless of whether travellers carry the money in person or if they send it by any other means of transport, which is called unaccompanied cash, with a disclosure statement.  The authorities of the Member States should exchange all information where there are indications that this cash is related to any criminal activity which may adversely affect the financial interests of the European Union and should transmit this information to the European Commission. Customs administrations play a leading role in this front line. We have failed to establish a European financial intelligence unit, but we have a strong review clause which instructs the Commission to meet this demand from the European Parliament for the articulation of a European financial intelligence unit. And finally, the efforts of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs have also suggested that this European legislation directly binding on Member States and callable by citizens in court, is respectful of European data protection law, because we have a General Data Protection Regulation that must be consistent and should inspire , as directed by the Supervisor European Data Protection Agency, all European legislation. We put it in connection with the European criminal law file against money laundering which we will discuss immediately afterwards. We are taking a step forward and I can only welcome the exercise of parliamentary cooperation and the willingness to reach an understanding with the Council at this point.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to be here today to discuss a major issue, which is the fight against the financing of terrorism. The Commission's proposal to strengthen the rules on the entry and exit of cash at the borders of the European Union is one of the key features of our strategy to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, and I would like to warmly thank the rapporteurs Mrs Delvaux, Mr L'Pez Aguilar for their work, their commitment, including their passion on this crucial issue. We are facing an ever-increasing inventiveness of terrorist networks, and there was an urgent need to update our rules on the control of cash movements in Europe. Indeed, terrorists and criminal organizations are now, as we know, able to circumvent existing rules, either by sending money in the mail or by using goods used as a reserve of highly liquid securities, such as gold or prepaid cards - it is an innovation - elements not covered by the current regulation which, by definition, did not incorporate certain technological advances. The Commission's proposal to be put to your vote tomorrow is to close the loopholes in the current regulation and to ensure tighter control of cash entering or leaving the European Union. We therefore proposed to amend the existing regulation, which we thought was obsolete: by strengthening the controls that apply to cash worth more than 10,000 euros, sent by mail parcel or freight; Expanding the definition of cash so that new means of transporting securities, such as prepaid cards or precious metals such as gold, can also be controlled; Creating a simplified and more robust mechanism for the exchange of information between national customs authorities and national financial intelligence cells; and finally, by allowing the competent authorities to act on amounts of less than EUR 10,000 in cash entering or leaving the EU, when there are indications that these amounts are linked to criminal activity. I would like to emphasise two aspects that underlie the architecture of this text: flexibility and cooperation. First, flexibility. Our legislation must, as far as possible, stand the test of time and be flexible enough to deal with the creativity of terrorist networks and criminals. That is why we have proposed that prepaid cards should, if necessary, be incorporated into this regulation by delegated deed. I am pleased that this aspect is present in the draft agreement between the co-legislators. Second, cooperation. Cooperation at European level, first of all. Greater cooperation between all relevant authorities is essential if we are to improve the effectiveness of the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, and this regulation will provide them with the appropriate aspects and tools and strengthen their operational capabilities to detect cash movements that may be linked to organised crimes or terrorist networks. Second, global cooperation. The new regulation will also bring our rules in line with standards, on the most successful international practices in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. It is also fully in line with the recommendations of the FATF (Financial Action Task Force) and is a strong point of the proposal. I would also like to point out that this proposal is part of the Commission's broader strategy on counter-terrorism and its financing. I will say a few words about some of the initiatives taken during this mandate. As Commissioner of Customs and Taxation, I am fully committed to this fight. Firstly, in the area of customs controls, I have proposed to strengthen customs controls on the importation of the most at-risk cultural goods, which can contribute to the financing of terrorism. Tax evasion and tax evasion are also a source of financing for the terrorist networks that we have tackled, and I am delighted to be able to count on the support of this European Parliament on this issue. Since the beginning of my mandate, as you know, the fight against tax evasion has been one of my priorities, so I have called on the Member States to define the first European list of tax havens. This fight for tax transparency, I am also leading it with the European Union, I am thinking of the complete reform of the current VAT system or the strengthening of trade information between tax administrations. Tax evasion is not the preserve of tax havens, and we have evidence that it is one of the means of financing criminal and terrorist organizations. To conclude this introductory remark, I would like to emphasise the complementarity that exists between our proposal to strengthen the control of cash and the fifth directive against money laundering. This complementarity is reflected in cooperation between financial intelligence cells at EU level. By 1 June 2019, the Commission will have to assess the obstacles and also the possibility of strengthening them, including by creating a coordination and support mechanism. The revision of the regulation on the control of cash movements was highly anticipated, as you know, to allow the sources of income used by terrorist organizations to be dried up, and it is by also hitting them in the portfolio that they will be reduced. These new rules bring more transparency on financial transactions to improve the fight against money laundering throughout the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that the Commission's proposal, which your rapporteurs are considering and about to vote on, provides effective solutions to the challenge of terrorism. I hope that I can count on your support in this vote, because we must all be aware, on all the benches, that this is an issue on which European citizens expect us to act, expect us to act strongly. It is our responsibility to ensure their protection and safety.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, one of the oldest forms of money laundering is through their physical smuggling, of course, without being declared. Even nowadays, despite the increasing use of non-cash payment methods, between 46% and 82% of all transactions worldwide are made in cash. Money laundering through their physical smuggling is linked to both organised crime and terrorism. In recent years, due to strict controls on bank payments, undeclared carried-over cash across borders has become even more important for the financing of terrorist activities. This requires tightening controls on cash entering and leaving the Union, as well as updating the rules available to the European Union since 2005. In order to respond to these developments, the customs authorities must have the appropriate powers to carry out checks while not violating the rights of ordinary travellers. I believe that the agreement reached in a trilogue, which we will vote on tomorrow, achieves these objectives – modernies the rules of control, supports the work of customs officers and strengthens cooperation between Member States.

name: Maria Grapini
text: on behalf of the S&D group. – Madam President, Commissioner, as it has emerged here, it was necessary to amend the regulation on cash control and the reasons were also well set out by the Commission, in the Commission proposal, and by the rapporteurs. I fully support the report, because, of course, money laundering, illicit cash flow creates a distortion in the market, unfair competition, but, as the Commissioner said, it funds terrorism and ultimately affects the security of our states and the European Union. I am glad that this report explains the concept of cash, because the old regulation did not include, for example, gold or other value transported. Then it was explained very clearly how to check not only the ceiling of 10 000 euro cash (cash) carried by individuals entering and leaving, but also transport by other means of transport. I therefore support the report and hope to make an important contribution to the elimination of money laundering.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Thank you, Chairman. "Safe home", that is the slogan of the N-VA team in Koksijde-Oostduinkerke. This is also what the N-VA stands for: ensuring the safety of our inhabitants and fighting crime, at the Flemish level, at the federal level, at European level, but certainly also at local level in our own municipality. Fighting this crime is really necessary, especially with our open economies in Europe and our open Flemish economy, with our seaports. Recently, in the news, we have been given extensive attention to the drug traffic and how we can tackle it.  But what do we see? In Europe, large sums of money shift between borders within the European Union, but also beyond European borders. That is why this dossier is important so that we can introduce new, strict rules with controls on, among other things, cash entering and leaving Europe. Any measure that helps to strengthen our fight, we must take so that the criminals can no longer slip through the cracks.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, cash remains a predominant source of financing, including for terrorists and other criminal organisations in Europe. The current rules on cash control need to be updated to address the new challenges. Recent events have shown that terrorists have managed to find ways to circumvent the current rules on cash control. In particular, public authorities have noted that criminals have resorted to sending or receiving cash via post, or in a parcel, in order to escape the obligation to make a declaration under the current rules. Moreover, French customs authorities found non-declared cash and gold worth EUR 9.2 million in postal parcels and freight packages during an investigation at Charles de Gaulle airport in 2015. National authorities have also seen that certain precious high-value commodities, such as gold, are now being used to escape the obligation to declare, since gold is not considered as cash under existing rules. I believe this new regulation will target these loopholes by imposing a simple rule. If you plan to enter or leave the EU with EUR 10 000 or more in cash, you must declare it to customs. As for cash sent by freight or post, the disclosure will have to be made. I was among those who believe that no differentiation should be made between accompanied and non-accompanied cash, and I was thus calling for a mandatory declaration for cash sent by freight or post. Unfortunately, the Commission was not convinced by this approach, nor were the other political groups. However, we all agreed to introduce this possibility in a review clause, and I hope the Commission will conduct these assessments thoroughly and update us on the outcome. Overall, I am satisfied with the outcome of the negotiations with the Council. I encourage Members to support this text and Member States to implement these new rules quickly.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, the European Union is updating and improving its rules to combat financial crime more effectively, which is great news. This regulation will better detect the entry into the European Union, and the exit, of cash for all sums above 10,000 euros, whether the money is sent by mail or carried on itself, and whether it is tickets or prepaid cards. These improvements will make it easier to open investigations and better track financial flows. But our fight against dirty money doesn't end there. The European Union must tackle the problem of golden visas: these programmes allow us to buy a country's citizenship in exchange for financial investment and without any real control over the origin of the sums of money. Too many European Union countries offer these golden visas: Greece, Portugal, Malta and others. The Commission has promised to respond by the end of the year. Time is running out, and I'm asking him to do it as soon as possible.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, EU restrictions on how much cash or gold you can take out of the EU is an unacceptable infringement of the freedom of the individual. EU bureaucrats who dreamed up this nonsense have evidently never run a business in their lives. When you go to a car sale, antiques fair or any other international market you need cash and EUR or GBP 10 000 is simply not enough. The excuse is always terrorism, money laundering, crime, tax cuts and all trigger words to keep you silent. Pure George Orwell. It’s absolute twaddle. That is not the real reason for removing privacy of the individual and for any bureaucratic police or customs official confiscating your hard-earned money on a whim, and giving it back when they choose to give it back, even if your business goes bust, is simply not good enough. The real reason is not crime and terrorism; the real reason is fear on the part of the EU Weimar State teetering on the brink of financial catastrophe: Argentinian banks going bust, Italian banks to follow, followed by contagion across Europe – even Deutsche Bank is in trouble. The EU fears decent, hard-working and wise taxpayers getting their money out of the EU, perhaps to Great Britain. What may be acceptable in France in terms of the droit fiscal on motorways ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. After the last speaker, I would like to return to the subject. The aim of the Regulation is to adapt the system of control of cross-border cash flow, money in the European Union to the requirements related to the need to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.  Cash flows are a favourite way for all kinds of criminals to convey value and action for criminal purposes, and it is very good that this initiative was taken by the European Commission and I also congratulate both rapporteurs – Mrs Delvaux and Mr Lopez Aguilar – for preparing this report. I believe that this report is needed because it fills the gaps in the current cash flow control system. Firstly, it also includes money sent by post or as goods, which has so far eerily eerily been controlled by the tax authorities. Secondly, declarations relating to the movement of those funds are mandatory. Moreover, these declarations should now be systematically transferred to the institutions responsible for financial control to the so-called financial investigation units. Thirdly, it is possible to retain subliminal amounts, i.e. those which do not exceed EUR 1 000 but may at the same time constitute financial resources. Fourthly and finally, we have an extended definition of cash covering gold and many other issues, so that I support this initiative and we will support this project during the vote.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this agreement on controls on cash entering and leaving the EU is an important step in the fight against money laundering and terrorism financing. The sharing of information between financial intelligence units and customs authorities has to be strengthened. The recent scandals surrounding many of the well—known European banks demonstrate how criminals have exploited weakness in the banking system to launder vast amounts of cash. Ten years after the beginning of the financial crisis, whilst we have strengthened the capital requirements of major banks, and they are supervised by the ECB, the policing of anti-money laundering rules is not covered under this system. Instead the responsibility for making sure that the banks carry out customer checks is down to national watchdogs, which leads to patchy implementation. This is the real core of the problem. So this system has to change. Tomorrow, President Juncker’s State of the Union address will announce the strengthening and enforcement of the powers of the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office in the fight against money laundering, but it is important that we have resources to back it. We only have 1.8 persons in the ECB who deal with this.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is a pity that we cannot give green cards in this plenary, otherwise I would immediately subscribe to a colleague's speech and explain to him that he will still be able to transport money to the UK, but he will have to report it, fill out one simple form that may solve the problem that currently is that cash is being transported across the border without any control and that various activities related to terrorism or illegal activity are being financed. Yes, colleague, perhaps you should ever sit among the victims of terrorist acts and explain to them how the terrorists obtained weapons or how they obtained explosives, for example, and how they paid for them. We are talking about the single market, we are talking about the need to really fight against different forms. It's not just money, gold has been mentioned here, but we can talk about other ways of financing today. This Directive must not be stopped. I thank the rapporteurs very much for their excellent work, but it is also necessary to start looking at the issue of cryptocurrencies and how the activities of various terrorist groups are financed.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs and all the other Members for their speeches and, let us say, lively debate. I observe that this is a subject in which you are fully invested and I welcome your commitment, because the Commission needs your support, simply because this cause deserves to be defended. I always listen to Mr. Coburn with pleasure. We rarely agree, but I respect his taste for freedom and, after all, our disagreements. But now, Mr. Coburn, tonight, no, I'm not following you. I believe that the love of freedom and what makes it possible to do business should not go against the safety of our fellow citizens when they are struck by terrorism, because that is what it is and nothing else. That is the only reason why the Commission has s heard of legislation in a context... (in response to an off-mic intervention by Mr. Coburn) Listen, you're talking to a commissioner who's also a Frenchman, and who was in bed, when, in Paris, we killed 100 people at the Bataclan. Believe me, to set up this type of operation, we need funding and that is why the fight against the financing of terrorism is a top priority that we must all share. We cannot put ideology where it has no place. I therefore fervently hope that this proposal to strengthen control of cash entering and leaving the European Union will be adopted as soon as possible. This is imperative, because the terrorist threat is still very present in Europe and it is the responsibility of all European decision-makers to give national authorities the means to fight this scourge effectively. We owe it to the 500 million European citizens who rely on us. I am convinced that this will go a long way to strengthening europe's arsenal in the fight against the financing of terrorism. As has been pointed out by some of you, the draft regulation will now allow customs authorities to obtain more data, to share it more quickly between customs authorities, as well as with financial intelligence cells, but yes, that is what this is about, and this is also electronically. I would also like to stress that the Commission will take its role to heart in the implementation phase of this proposal. As I have explained to you, this Commission has made the fight against terrorism one of its priorities and we are and will remain fully engaged with the Member States to facilitate their collective action, since we have been entrusted with many responsibilities: to adapt the computer tool for the exchange of data between authorities and to keep the Council and Parliament informed of the operation of the new provisions. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that you are now all or almost all convinced of the need to adopt this proposal tomorrow in order to ensure its implementation as soon as possible. This is essential because the terrorist threat persists in Europe, because innocent people are still the victims, because we know that this threat is evolving and that it will take increasingly sophisticated forms, because we know that the current rules are outdated and no longer allow us to combat this phenomenon effectively. Finally, and I will end with this message, we must act quickly because the fight against terrorism is an area on which our fellow Europeans legitimately expect an effective and common response. We are a few months away from a European election, it is absolutely necessary to provide this proof of Europe. We are judged on our action, it is natural, and the time has come to demonstrate to the citizens, to the Europeans, the added value of our collective action and the interest of our common project, here tonight there is a beautiful concrete translation.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I think that everything has been said, I have rarely seen a regulation find such a broad consensus in this Parliament, with one exception, which I would interpret more as bad faith than as a valid argument. While I am satisfied with this consensus, the reason for the consensus is much more worrying. We have all realized the importance of terrorist financing and criminal activity in Europe, and it was necessary for us to come together to reach agreement on a regulation that helps to combat criminal activity. I do not want to say that this is a panacea, but it is an important contribution, and we will have to be just as vigilant on other issues as the cash controls. I would like to thank the Commissioner for his commitment to closely monitor the implementation of this regulation and to say that Parliament too has made many appeals to the Commission and to the Member States, and that we would like this collective effort to be respected by all participants. All that remains for me to thank all colleagues for their cooperation and to wish a very positive vote in plenary tomorrow.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would just like to reiterate my thanks in this exercise of cooperation which allows us to give the green light to European legislation which strengthens our capacity against money laundering, organised crime and the financing of terrorism. I have had the honour of being Minister of Justice of Spain, a country in the fight against terrorism, and the same sensitivity with which I understand that security is a fundamental right of Europeans has led me to underline the importance of the compatibility of this European legislation and the Directive on combating money laundering through criminal law , which is discussed immediately afterwards, with fundamental rights and, in particular, with the limitation of the period of data retention. I would just like to regret that this legislative exercise, in which the European Parliament and the Council have finally reached a point of understanding, has to do with an initiative which underlines security, which is certainly a fundamental right, because the Council has not sought any compromise with the European Parliament in all aspects of the Dublin Regulation , asylum package, free movement of persons and so many important initiatives such as the Dublin Regulation and the visa code, which are pending unlocking by the Council.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 September 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is difficult to disagree with the statement that improving control over cash flow between EU countries helps to combat international terrorism and can counter so-called money laundering. From this point of view, the current legislative initiative is very necessary - in particular, extending the scope of controls to include travellers' cheques, bearer shares or gold. However, I support limiting the control of prepaid cards to only anonymous (unregistered) prepaid cards. This is a reasonable compromise between increasing supervisory restrictions and respect for civil liberties. On the other hand, I do not support the amendment in Article 12(4) providing for the creation of an EU financial intelligence unit at the initiative of the Commission. I believe that this project should strengthen the activities and coordination of national analytical units, without introducing an additional harmonisation tool. I am therefore also not enthusiastic about the harmonisation of national sanctions; a better solution would be, for example, to establish high minimum thresholds for such offences rather than fully harmonising them within the EU. I also agree with the rapporteur's diagnosis of the need for training for customs and other national authorities on how to identify cash money laundering. It is also commendable that our amendments have taken into account the problem of processing and storage of personal data, setting maximum deadlines for their processing. At the end of the day, I believe that the text of the report deserves my support in plenary.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Ignazio Corrao, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on countering money laundering by criminal law (COM(2016)0826 – C8-0534/2016 – 2016/0414(COD)) (A8-0405/2017).

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, tomorrow we will vote on the result of a long work, which has lasted more than a year, on an objectively important directive that is particularly close to my heart, because it is aimed at combating a heinous crime, the social danger of which is often underestimated: money laundering. Money laundering is a global problem, which requires a strong response from the legislator if it is to be tackled effectively. Money is the element that allows criminal organisations to run their dirty business. That is why it is essential to draw up rules that affect their most valuable resource, the source of funding that feeds their criminal activities. Money laundering also has a further odious indirect effect: proceeds from illegal activities are put into the legal economy through hedging companies. In this way, the market is drugged, to the great detriment of companies that comply with the rules and are destroyed by this illegal and unfair competition.  Criminal organisations operate like large multinationals, diversifying their activities to maximise profits, and they are very good at taking advantage of legislative loopholes and ensuring impunity. For example, the proceeds of drug trafficking in Italy can be reinvested by buying restaurants in the Netherlands or Germany, which will remain on the market supported by such financing of illicit origin, regardless of their actual turnover.  For this reason, we have long worked on a text that will allow law enforcement authorities across Europe to investigate and prosecute this crime wherever it takes place. To do this, we have ensured that European legislation is brought into line with international standards in this area and we have gone further with the Warsaw Convention on Recycling. We have worked assiduously to conclude, as soon as possible, the institutional process leading up to the adoption of this directive tomorrow.  I would like to thank all my fellow Members here, the Commission and the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council for their excellent cooperation throughout the interinstitutional negotiations, which has enabled us to dismiss a truly comprehensive text and which marks an important step in the fight against organised crime at European level, offering the judicial and law enforcement authorities effective and incisive instruments. Since the beginning of our work, we have aimed to obtain a legislative text that is effective, clear and comprehensive, and that closes once and for all the meshes of the laws of the Member States exploited by criminals to escape justice, not forgetting respect for fundamental rights. The directive provides for a common definition and alignment of penalties for money laundering. We started with the Commission's excellent proposal and, together with the other shadow rapporteurs, we carried out extensive preparatory and consultation work involving the highest experts in this field, whose valuable contributions we then translated into amendments to the Commission's proposal. I would now like to say a few words about the main achievements of this directive. Thanks to our work, we have removed the main potential obstacle to investigations and ensured the punishability of money laundering. In fact, we have removed the requirement of double criminality of criminal conduct, from which the proceeds of particularly serious crimes, such as trafficking in human beings, terrorism or corruption, come from. This means that investigators in one Member State will be able to take action against money launderers without having to worry about whether or not such conduct constitutes a crime for the law of other countries that may be involved. As far as penalties are concerned, we felt it was essential not to limit ourselves to prison sentences, but we have focused on ancillary sanctions that we consider to be particularly effective and dissuasive.  (The President asked the speaker to speak more slowly) Member States will have to provide for sanctions such as a permanent ban on contracts with the public administration and access to public funding, a ban on the pursuit of a commercial activity or a ban on running for elected or public office. Those who commit such serious and dangerous crimes must stay away from the public administration. This is also our commitment in Italy, as we are already demonstrating with the decree "spazzacorrotti". The directive also lays down rules on the confiscation of the proceeds of this crime. On this point we would have liked to see a greater effort on the part of the other institutions to comply with Parliament's requests. My report, which was dismissed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and home affairs, indeed, provided for much stricter and more innovative rules which, unfortunately, were firmly opposed by the other institutions involved in the negotiations. I hope that the Commission will honour the commitments it made during the trialogues and will soon present a revision of the existing directive on the freezing and confiscation of capital goods and the proceeds of crime, in order to provide for the seizure also for a non-final conviction, in the event of the limitation period or the death of the offender. This directive also includes rules on cooperation between judicial and law enforcement authorities which, as we have always said, is an essential prerequisite for ensuring the practical effectiveness of the rules. Finally, we wanted to significantly strengthen the exchange of information and the obligation to cooperate between the authorities and the Member States and, in expressing the position of the Committee on Development of which I am a member, we wanted to introduce specific rules to encourage ever more effective cooperation with third countries in the future with regard to the European Union, including developing countries.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to our rapporteur Mr Corrao and his shadow rapporteurs, as well as the Council, for this excellent outcome of the negotiations on our proposal for a directive on countering money laundering by criminal law. Mr Corrao, I do not see many of your colleagues here tonight in this Chamber at this late hour, but as you see there are two Commissioners present given the importance of this debate.  Today we are bringing all our Member States up to international standards in the money laundering fight. Money laundering, as you all know, is a serious affliction in our economies and in our societies. Never far from the news, it is a practice which undermines trust in financial institutions and entire economies.  Dirty money is unfortunately also a key security concern because laundering is instrumental to the operations of criminal, and even terrorist, groups. Terrorist organisations and organised crime need financing to maintain their criminal networks, to recruit and supply, and to commit terrorist acts themselves. Money laundering allows criminal organisations to reap fruits from illegal activities and maintain operations. Our existing criminal law framework against money laundering in the European Union suffers from gaps and loopholes. All Member States criminalise money laundering but the differences in how they do this, in the scope and sanctions for money laundering offences, affect in a negative way cross-border police and judicial cooperation. Information exchange becomes difficult and criminals slip through the cracks left by divergent national systems. Crime, of course, follows the path of least resistance and the criminals do their business where they see anti-money laundering measures to be weakest. The agreement you have reached in the trilogues will remedy these problems. Our new rules will reinforce our capacity to tackle organised crime and terrorist financing more effectively by providing police and prosecutors with the tools to crack down on money laundering. First, they will provide minimum common rules on the definition of criminal offences and sanctions relating to money laundering, including profits from all offences defined in EU criminal law.  Second, they will also provide common provisions to improve investigations of money-laundering related offences. Third, a comprehensive definition of money laundering, ranging from conversion and concealment to mere possession or use of criminal property and including self-laundering. Fourth, liability and punishment for both natural and legal persons involved in money laundering, and fifth, maximum sanctions for those convicted of money laundering of at least four years imprisonment.  This is the European Union providing added value to the Member States. My thanks once again to Mr Corrao and his shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work on this initiative.

name: Eva Joly
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Madam President, the fight against money laundering requires a complete and coherent legal arsenal. This directive is therefore welcome because it harmonizes at European level the definitions and criminal sanctions for money laundering offences. It also incorporates international obligations. This will facilitate judicial cooperation and strengthen our fight against financial crime. This is also the opinion of the European Parliament's Committee on Economic Affairs, which gave its opinion on this proposed directive in November 2017, an opinion adopted without any vote against it. As rapporteur, I am very pleased to see that many of our recommendations are in the final text. It was important, for example, to add tax offences to the list of underlying offences in order to also punish money laundering for tax evasion. It was also useful to add the possibility of additional sanctions, such as the prohibition of access to public procurement for a condemned company. I would like to thank all my colleagues for this important work, and I call on the Member States to apply the European anti-money laundering rules rigorously and without delay.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am very pleased that at half past noon two Commissioners and their teams are with us and are delighted that Mr Corraro and also us, the shadow rapporteurs – I see Ana Gomes and Mrs Joly – have managed to take a very good step towards the fight against money laundering under criminal law. It has not been an easy piece of work, because the Member States have been extremely heterogeneous here. It is still not quite as far as we might have imagined, but we have made significant progress. I warmly congratulate the rapporteur on the fact that, for example, we have succeeded – which was really more than questionable before, because the Member States were very opposed – in achieving partial exceptions to the requirement of double crime. After all, we have been able to achieve exceptions in six areas. I think it is essential that, in future, we should no longer be sitting opposite prosecutors at our hearings on money laundering, who tell us that, in almost 95% of cases, money laundering does not end up in court and cannot be punished. I hope that, with this joint harmonisation, much more can happen in investigative results and in actual punishment of money launderers, especially as this is a very important component for the networks, both in the area of terrorism and in the area of organised crime.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I congratulate rapporteur Corrao and the other shadow colleagues on the progress made in this negotiation under the Presidency of Bulgaria on an issue that should be a priority for European governments. This is the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. It should be, but it is not, because if some progress has undoubtedly been made, as has already been said, we have also seen Member States reject important recommendations from this Parliament, for example, on the extent of freezing and confiscation of property as products of crime, by the death of the perpetrator or suspect, or by reaching the limitation period, or on the criminalisation of negligence , or even, astonew, about aggravating circumstances for politically exposed people.  This has been shamefully rejected by the Member States. Finally, I have come out of this negotiation, one more in this area, increasingly convinced that some Member States do not therefore want to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. They just want to pretend they do.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it was perhaps a rare situation when the Commissioners played a power play, to use an ice hockey expression. But, more importantly, I believe that the text we agreed will complement another important directive we are working on, the Fifth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, by introducing a strong and efficient criminal law instrument to tackle money laundering.  The new rules, combined with other legislative instruments, will contribute to a cutting of the financial sources of criminals. The amount of money generated from criminal activity in the main illicit markets in the EU has been estimated at EUR 110 billion per year, corresponding to 1% of EU GDP. For criminals to benefit fully from the proceeds of their crimes, these criminal proceeds need to be laundered and the number of money laundering cases in the EU has been growing, according to Europol. In my capacity as Chair of the Special Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance, I can only recall here how important it is to agree on common minimal rules on the way Member States criminalise money laundering. The investigation we conducted in Parliament’s previous Committee of Inquiry on Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion clearly shows that differences in national legislation on money laundering are a major obstacle to cross-border cooperation and exchange of information.  By harmonising the definition of what constitutes a criminal offence, we facilitate the possibility for financial intelligence units to exchange information regarding criminal investigation of money laundering or terrorist financing. I believe we did it right and I am convinced that the trilogue outcome will gain overwhelming support in the House.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, money laundering is a criminal activity with multiple ramifications and dire consequences. We look at the impact that laundering has on our security, on the financing of terrorism or on organized crime. But they're not the only risks. Often, the actors in these criminal activities are well-positioned people.  The fight against money laundering through the Penal Code is an essential tool to punish these practices and to limit their extent as well. We have no doubt that European scale is an appropriate dimension in combination with states, as long as they have political will, which unfortunately are quite often lacking.  The European Union must be put on the offensive in this area; go beyond the FATFI's own recommendations; establish mechanisms for assessing and monitoring agreed measures. To this end, it is essential to make the laws homogeneous, precisely so that these offences associated with laundering are punishable by prison sentences which are also deterrent. It is important that we do not lose this battle and that we work on it right away.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in hockey terminology, I would say, Commissioner, that you are already starting to weaken, because there are no more two, but one. But let's get to something more serious. Today marks the anniversary of the tragic attacks on the World Trade Center in New York, which was perhaps the biggest impetus to start the war on terrorism. And we all know what a huge phenomenon terrorism is. These are diverse dimensions that cannot be cut off by one initiative. They need to be combated systematically, and every effort must be made to suppress any groups and to create acts of terrorism. I therefore welcome the European Commission's action plan, which has a head and a stalemate and at least seeks to limit its funding and thus seeks to prevent its creation from scratch.  Most of all, However, I welcome parliament's successful in the trilogue to enforce sanctions on European funds. I welcome the operational provisions on the freezing and confiscation of the proceeds of crime. I also think that excluding these people from the possibility of receiving public funds or money from EU funds, together with criminal and administrative fines, is a very good solution.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, an effective fight against money laundering requires, at European level, a coherent framework of common minimum standards in order to provide national judicial authorities with modern and appropriate criminal instruments and to fill the gaps caused by the diversity of Member States' legislation.  I am thinking, for example, of differences in the definitions of money laundering, or of the legal concept of a pre-existing crime, or the absence of rules on self-laundering in certain national legislations. Differences that have in fact hindered cooperation between judicial authorities, weakening action to combat the most serious crimes of a cross-border nature. The proposal on which we will vote tomorrow is definitely a step towards greater effectiveness in the fight against money laundering, terrorism and criminal organisations, and prepares for a broader reflection on a fundamental issue, which is now inescapable, for the development of a genuine European criminal policy: that of a common definition of organised crime, taking into account the transnational dimension of the phenomenon and the more advanced law enforcement strategies developed by some Member States.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, thank you to Madam Commissioner for staying with us this late. As you may know, I worked hard on the Regulation on the recognition of freezing and confiscation orders, and I am happy to vote tomorrow for a directive on countering money laundering by criminal law. The achievements of the new rules, as mentioned also by Commissioner Avramopoulos (who is not here any more): money laundering activities will be punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of at least four years; additional sanctions and measures may be imposed by judges, together with imprisonment; aggravating circumstances will apply to cases linked to criminal organisations or for offences conducted in the exercise of certain professional activities; legal entities will also be held liable for certain money laundering activities and can face a range of sanctions. The compromise also includes clear rules to define which Member State has jurisdiction and the cooperation between Member States concerned in cross-border cases, as well as the need to involve Eurojust. Thank you for your work, and please do support this directive tomorrow.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members for their engagement on this subject, including at this late hour. It hasn’t quite struck midnight yet. Preventing terrorists gaining access to funding is, as has been said, a key security consideration, but more widely, the strengthened criminal response to money laundering helps counter the financial incentives that drive a whole range of serious criminal activity. It goes along with the proposal on controls on cash entering or leaving the EU that you were discussing just before this item. We very much welcome and support the new directive. We think that the rules on the definition of criminal offences and sanctions are an important step forward. We think the establishment of corporate liability for money laundering in certain circumstances and the specific sanctions are a key strengthening of our panoply of instruments for fighting this challenge. We welcome the fact that we have been able to find various compromises in discussion. I think the compromise on the issue of double criminality follows a clear logic and will make the EU more robust against money laundering. Likewise, the agreement on aggravating circumstances, proposed by this House, for example, cases concerning property of significant value or that relate to certain serious crimes, which are now going to be punished more severely. The potential risks posed by virtual currencies and politically-exposed people have been properly highlighted, and the Commission will continue to play close attention to those risks. Ultimately, the agreed text ensures that the laundering of proceeds of tax crimes will be criminalised in each Member State. Moreover, as has already been stressed, it ensures that differences in the definition of tax crimes from Member State to Member State will not be allowed to hamper cooperation between national authorities. Overall, the new directive is an important part of our comprehensive approach to tackling money laundering and terrorist financing. We will now consider the impact of the measures introduced under the 2016 Action Plan on terrorist financing and, based on the assessment, the Commission will make further proposals as necessary. Thank you again for the contribution of all those involved in this work, in particular the rapporteur and his shadows. We look forward to a positive outcome to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall be very brief. I would like to thank the Commissioner, who is still here, and my colleagues who are here almost at midnight. I would simply like to conclude by saying that, on the starting from the European Commission's good proposal, we have had the ambition to do what legislators have to do, then to improve the text and to aim to innovate European Union legislation as well, to make progress. I think we have succeeded in some respects, when we have included aggravating circumstances, innovative ancillary penalties, such as the ban on haggling with the public administration and the ban on running for elected office. This is also part of a broader logic that we are pursuing, including at national level, in the fight against corruption and therefore in the fight against money laundering, but it serves precisely to improve the fight against organised crime and terrorism, and we are pleased about that. We expect, as I said earlier, to be able to see the Same ambition from the Commission in the future. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again and, as we have arrived at midnight, I wish you a good night.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 September 2018.
